story:
AN ECO-PROJECT TO MAKE YOU THINK

Sunseed Desert Technology is a non-profit educational project within an eco-village in Spain. Our mission is to research, demonstrate and communicate methods of sustainable living and environmental stewardship in a semi-arid environment.

Through accessible, low-tech and practical learning, our research is directly applicable to low-income societies and a transition to an environmentally sustainable future.

Originally conceived 30 years ago as a non-governmental organisation (NGO), we identified desertification as our central research objective. We now offer hands-on educational experiences for volunteers to gain practical knowledge in many diverse areas such as eco-construction, clean energy technologies, permaculture, naturally-sourced household and cosmetic products, and water management.

WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT

Over the past year, Sunseed has incurred a number of extraordinary maintenance costs. These have included urgent structural repairs to our traditional Andalusian buildings that were crucial to ensure the safety and well being of our guests. We've had to recondition our van's engine (a vital resource as we live in one of the largest deserts in Europe) and to pay for new batteries for our solar power energy systems. We've also had to re-build our bio-gas stove in our main house which is crucial to survive the extreme cold winters in the region.

Taken all together, the timing of the above mentioned expenditures have been tragically unfortunate. We now face a precarious financial situation where the possibility of Sunseed's closure is a reality. We are seeking funding to ensure the continuation of the practical environmental education and research undertaken at Sunseed, and improve our volunteer programmes.

WHAT WE NEED TO KEEP THE PROJECT ALIVE

To keep Sunseed alive, altogether we seek to raise 10 000€ (This includes asking   5 000€ from our community, as we are attempting to raise funds from other sources as well - To this date we have raised just over 4 000€). The indiegogo budget breaks down as follows:

HOW WE PLAN TO SUSTAIN SUNSEED

Over the years, Sunseed has attracted volunteers from across the 5 continents. They are guided through immersive and holistic learning journeys in order to gain practical skills related to environmental stewardship. The quality of Sunseed programmes have been recognised in the past by major international bodies, such as the European Union's Lifelong Learning programme.

Sunseed has been self-sustainable for over 30 years and we have a clear strategy to stay this way.  We would like to reiterate that we have never needed to ask for funds through a crowdfunding campaign before, and we have had to do so due to the aforementioned circumstances.

We will continue to stand true to our reputation and offer education in areas such as:

  • Permaculture courses
  • How to build photovoltaic and wind powered systems
  • Eco-construction methods
  • Techniques for managing soil quality in semi-arid conditions 


SOME OF OUR KEY FUTURE PROJECTS

Projects that will become a reality through this campaign include:

Appropriate Technology 

  • Create and share guides to pedal powered washing machine that can be used in any climate and without electricity
  • Construct two wind turbines – primarily from reclaimed materials – and creating detailed plans for replication across the world
  • Design and build a GEK (Gasifier experimental kit). The GEK is an open source design utilizing common materials and automation electronics for a very efficient gasifier that can also power a generator for electricity, heat up water, and produce bio-char or tar

Drylands Management 

  • Continue to research and educate on practical, low-cost methods for combating desertification. Methods include 'key-line' technology, and mycorrhiza techniques for plant germination
  • Restoration of water catchment systems to increase water sustainability.
  • Complete our waste water management system for the treatment of all greywater at Sunseed

Organic Gardens

  • To create a self-sufficient Seedbank of local and old seed varieties. Sunseed will also collaborate with local seed networks to coordinate this work at a regional level

  • Incorporate biodynamic and vegan horticulture techniques into our gardens whilst highlighting to volunteers how to create and manage thriving gardens without the need for animal fertilisation

Eco-construction 

  • Develop and share techniques on making naturally-sourced plaster mixes and experiment with natural water-proofing materials such as chumba
  • Research and develop natural insulation materials, such as slip straw, and educate on their applications

Sustainable Living

  • Make all milk on-site from own produce such as almonds and oats. Continue with grain and seed milk trials and communicate research through the internet
  • Research and develop information and practice on vegan nutrition methods


A FEW MEMBERS OF OUR TEAM OF EXPERTS 

All our departments are operated by our visionary full-time voluntary staff team, who work tirelessly to ensure volunteers visiting Sunseed gain an enriching education. From self-sustainability, green energy, and low-impact living, visitors ultimately gain the knowledge to replicate the skills learnt in their own countries and around the world.

Jack (34), England, Eco Construction Coordinator        

Jack originally developed his construction skills working with strawbale houses and earthships: both innovative methods based on reusing recycled materials. In recent years he has focused on construction techniques that utilise the locally abundant renewable resource of Caña (Cane).

“The positive energy found at Sunseed, the eagerness to research and experiment, the beauty of the place itself and the international diversity allows borders to disappear. It creates an open space to share knowledge and integrate with a mix of cultures.”

 Delphine (27), France, Drylands Management Coordinator

Delphine draws upon her academic foundations, as a trained engineer and her specialisation in environmental management to combat desertification.

“An aspect of my role is to sustainably plant trees, with the aim of disrupting erosion. We apply new techniques to regenerate the soil.”

Marina (25), Spain, Education Coordinator

Marina has her roots grounded within teaching and a passion for permaculture projects – two vital veins of Sunseed life.

“We are dedicated to sharing the information and knowledge that Sunseed volunteers and coordinators create with local schools and universities. Sunseed offers opportunities for practical work experience and internships.”

Tom (29), England, Facilitation Coordinator

                

   

Tom has recently joined Sunseed and provides oversight on the administrative, financial and funding of Sunseed. His previous experience includes working with numerous environmental campaigning and human rights organisations. 

“In addition to ensuring financial sustainability for Sunseed, it’s my goal to continue to develop and implement non-hierarchical organising structures. I believe many who come to Sunseed can learn from such progressive techniques and continue to exercise them in their own lives."

WHERE TO FIND US

We are located in the valley of Rio de Aguas, near Almeria, in the Southeast of Spain. The natural vegetation is typically Mediterranean: thyme, sage, saltbush and ground shrub, with scarce trees, such as olive and carob. There are also many pita (agave) and chumba (cactus), introduced to Spain from Mexico. It is a beautiful environment that inspires locals and visitors alike.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US

As we move through uncertain times ecologically, politically, and socially, we feel it's more important than ever to ensure sustainability, permaculture, community, and clean energy are pegged as priorities to everyone's personal agenda. Can you help us continue to achieve this and create a sustainable future?

To our knowledge, we are the only practical education project researching desertification and other environmental threats in Europe. We now need funds to ensure the continuation of our important work and that generations of volunteers can benefit from the unique learning programmes that we offer.

If you can't support us through monetary donations, you can help publicise Sunseed's work through social media, or contact us with ideas. Even better, come and visit us in Spain. You're more than welcome any time!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Programas únicos en energía limpia, permacultura, desertificación y estilos de vida de bajo impacto ambiental

UN ECO-PROYECTO PARA HACERTE REFLEXIONAR

Sunseed Desert Technology es un proyecto educacional sin ánimo de lucro que se desarrolla dentro de una eco-aldea en las montañas de Almería (España). Nuestro objetivo es investigar, probar y difundir métodos de vida sostenible y administración medioambiental en entornos semiáridos.

Gracias a un aprendizaje accesible, práctico y basado en tecnologías básicas, nuestra investigación es de aplicación directa a entornos con escasos recursos, y representa una puerta de entrada a un futuro sostenible desde un punto de vista medioambiental.

Sunseed nació hace 30 años como una organización no gubernamental (ONG),cuya prioridad era investigar la desertificación. Ahora también ofrecemos experiencias educativas prácticas para voluntarios, con las que obtener conocimientos de aplicación directa en multitud de areas, como la bioconstrucción, tecnologías y energías limpias, permacultura, productos cosméticos y del hogar de origen natural, y gestión del agua.

POR QUE NECESITAMOS TU AYUDA

A lo largo del último año, Sunseed ha tenido que hacer frente a unos gastos de mantenimiento extraordinarios. Entre otros, una reparación de urgencia de la estructura de nuestras casas, imprescindible para asegurar la seguridad y bienestar de nuestros invitados; la reparación el motor de nuestra furgoneta (un recurso fundamental, puesto que vivimos en uno de los mayores desiertos de Europa); y la compra de nuevas baterías para nuestro sistema de energía solar. También hemos tenido que reconstruir la estufa de bio-gas de la casa principal, fundamental de cara a sobrevivir a los inviernos extremadamente fríos de esta zona.

En su conjunto, la concurrencia de estos gastos ha supuesto un duro golpe para nuestros fondos. Nos vemos enfrentados a una situación financiera muy precaria, en la que el cierre de Sunseed es una sería posibilidad. Buscamos financiación para poder seguir trabajando en nuestro proyecto de educación e investigación medioambiental, y para mejorar los programas de voluntariado.

QUE NECESITAMOS PARA QUE EL PROYECTO SIGA ADELANTE 

Para mantener Sunseed vivo necesitamos recaudar 10.000€ (de los cuales ya hemos recaudado algo más de 4000€). El desglose del proyecto de Indiegogo es el siguiente

Lo que necesitamos

· Mantenimiento de urgencia de la furgoneta

· Reparaciones estructurales de la casa principal

· Estufa de bio-gas de la casa principal

· Eco-proyectos de Sunseed

· Financiación para recompensas y coste de la campaña

· Tasas de Indiegogo

NUESTRO PLAN PARA HACER SUNSEED SOSTENIBLE

A lo largo de los años Sunseed ha atraído voluntarios de los cinco continentes. Tras una experiencia alternativa y de inmersión, dichos voluntarios adquirieron habilidades prácticas relacionadas con la gestión medioambiental. La calidad de los programas de Sunseed ha sido reconocida en el pasado por importantes agencias internacionales, como el Programa de Aprendizaje Permanente de la Unión Europea.

Sunseed ha sido autosostenible durante 30 años, y tenemos una estrategia clara para seguir siéndolo. Nos gustaría destacar que nunca hemos solicitado fondos a través de una campaña de crowdfunding, y que han sido las circunstancias anteriormente explicadas las que nos han forzado a hacerlo.

Seguiremos siendo fieles a nuestra reputación y ofreciendo formación en areas como:

· Permacultura

· Construcción de sistemas alimentados por energía eólica o solar

· Métodos de eco-construcción

· Técnicas para gestionar la calidad del suelo en condiciones semiáridas

Nuestras fuentes de financiación

· Ventas en eco-mercados y cursos

· Donaciones de voluntarios

· Subvenciones

ALGUNOS DE NUESTROS PROYECTOS MAS IMPORTANTES

Algunos de los proyectos que se harán realidad a través de esta campaña:

Tecnologías Apropiadas:

· Crear y compartir guías para lavadoras activadas a pedales que puedan usarse en cualquier clima y sin electricidad.

· Construir dos turbinas eólicas(principalmente a base de materiales reciclados) y crear planos detallados para que puedan ser fabricadas en otras partes del mundo.

· Diseñar y construir un GEK (Kit experimental de gasificación). El GEK es un diseño abierto que utiliza materiales normales y dispositivos automáticos para crear gasificadores de un alto nivel de eficacia, capaces también de alimentar un generados de electricidad, calentar agua, o producir bio-carbón o alquitrán.

Regeneración de Zonas Aridas:

· Continuar investigando y educando en métodos prácticos y de bajo coste para combatir la deserfificación. Entre los métodos se incluye y la germinación de plantas con micorrizas.

· Restauración de Sistemas de Captación de Aguas para incrementar la sostenibilidad hidráulica.

· Completar nuestro sistema de procesamientos de aguas residuales para el tratamiento de todas las aguas grises de Sunseed.

Jardines Ecológicos

· Crear un Banco de semillas autosuficiente con semillas autóctonas y variedades tradicionales. Sunseed colaborará con redes locales de semillas para coordinar sus esfuerzos a nivel regional.

· Investigar y desarrollar materiales aislantes de origen natural, como la combinación de arcilla y paja, y educar en sus diferentes usos.

· Incorporar técnicas biodinámicas y de horticultura vegana en nuestra huerta, al tiempo que enseñamos a nuestros voluntarios a crear y gestionar una huerta vigorosa sin necesidad de fertilizantes animales.

Bioconstrucción

· Desarrollar y compartir técnicas para la elaboración de compuestos para el enlucido, similares al yeso, pero de origen natural, y experimentar con materiales naturales e impermeable, como las chumberas.

· Investigar y desarrollar materiales aislantes de origen natural, como la combinación de arcilla y paja, y educar en sus diferentes usos.

Vida Sostenible

· Crear un centro de producción de leche a partir de recursos propios, como almendras o avena. Seguir experimentando con leche de granos y semillas y difundir los resultados de investigación a través de internet.

· Investigar y desarrollar información y practicas en métodos de nutrición vegana.

PARTE DE NUESTRO EQUIPO DE EXPERTOS

Todos nuestros departamentos están dirigidos por un equipo de personal voluntario a tiempo completo, que trabaja sin descanso para cerciorarse de que los voluntarios que visitan Sunseed reciben una enriquecedora educación. A través de una estancia basada en al auto-sostenibilidad, las energías limpias y un estilo de vida de bajo impacto medioambiental, los que nos visitan adquieren conocimientos con los que poder reproducir las habilidades aprendidas en sus propios países y a lo largo del mundo.

Jack (34), Inglaterra, Coordinador de Eco-construcción

Jack se inició en el campo de la construcción trabajando con el uso de balas de paja en construcción de casas, y construyendo viviendas tipo earthship: ambas técnicas usan material reciclado de forma innovadora. En los últimos años se ha especializado en técnicas que hacen uso de un abundante material renovable, la caña.

“La energía positiva que puede encontrarse en Sunseed, las ganas de investigar y experimentar, la propia belleza del paraje y la diversidad internacional hacen que las fronteras desaparezcan. Sunseed crea un espacio abierto en el que compartir conocimiento e integrarse en una mezcla de culturas”.

Delphine (27), Francia, Coordinadora de la Gestión de zonas áridas

Delphine emplea su formación académica, tanto como ingeniera como gracias a su especialización en gestión medioambiental, para combatir la desertificación.

“Un aspecto de mi labor es plantar árboles de forma sostenible, con el objetivo de detener la erosión. Aplicamos nuevas técnicas para regenerar el suelo”.

Marina (25), España, Coordinadora de Educación

Marina se apoya en su pasión por la enseñanza y los proyectos de permacultura - dos aspectos fundamentales de la vida en Sunseed.

“Nos dedicamos a compartir la información y el conocimiento creado por los coordinadores y voluntarios de Sunseed con escuelas locales y universidades. Sunseed ofrece la posibilidad de realizar estancias y trabajos prácticos”.

Tom (29), Inglaterra, Coordinador de Instalaciones

Tom se ha unido recientemente a Sunseed, y colabora con la supervisión de la financiación, administración y contabilidad en Sunseed. Sus experiencias previas incluyen el trabajo con numerosas organizaciones medioambientales y de derechos humanos.

“Además de asegurar la estabilidad financiera de Sunseed, mi objetivo es continuar desarrollando e implementando estructuras de organización no jerárquicas. Creo muchos de los que vienen a Sunseed puede aprender de este tipo de técnicas progresistas y seguir aplicándolas en su vida diaria”.

DÓNDE NOS ENCONTRAMOS

Nuestras instalaciones están en el valle del Rio Aguas, cerca de Almería, al sureste de España. La vegetación circundantes es típicamente mediterránea: tomillo, salvia, orgaza, arbustos y árboles dispersos, como olivos o algarrobos. También hay bastantes pitas (ágapes) y chumbos (cactus), introducidos en España desde México. Es un hermoso paraje capaz de inspirar por igual tanto a los visitantes como a los residentes.

OTRAS FORMAS DE AYUDARNOS

En estos tiempos de incertidumbre política, ecológica y social, sentimos que es más importante que nunca asegurarnos de que la sostenibilidad, la permacultura, la comunidad y las energías limpias son una prioridad destacada en la agenda privada de cada uno. ¿Puedes ayudarnos a lograr esto y crear un futuro sostenible?

Hasta donde sabemos, somos el único proyecto educativo en Europa con un enfoque práctica que investiga la desertificación y otras amenazas medioambientales. En este momento necesitamos fondos para asegurar la continuidad de nuestra importante labor y que las futuras generaciones de voluntarios puedan beneficiarse de los programas de aprendizaje que ofrecemos, únicos en su clase.

Si no puedes ayudarnos financieramente, puedes hacerlo difundiendo el trabajo de Sunseed a través de las redes sociales, o haciéndonos llegar tus propias ideas. O aún mejor, ven y visítanos. ¡Siempre serás bienvenido!

5€

¡Agradecimiento especial!

Tu nombre aparecerá en una sección especial de agradecimiento en nuestra página web y perfil de Facebook. ¡Serás parte del salón de la fama de los salvadores de Sunseed!

15€

Postal de Sunseed hecha a mano

Te enviaremos una postal hecha a mano con un mensaje personalizado y nuestro amor eterno.

25€

¡Planta un árbol en el desierto!

Le pondremos tu nombre a uno de los árboles o arbustos del jardín forestal o del jardín botánico de Sunseed. Te enviaremos una foto y un mensaje personalizado de agradecimiento.

50€

Libro de fotografía digital de edición limitada

Recibirás un libro de fotos digitales hecho por fotógrafos profesionales, donde podrás disfrutar de una visión de una vida alternativa en Andalucía, incluyendo información extra sobre los proyectos que has ayudado a mantener con vida.

75€

Camiseta de edición liitada

¡Recibirás una camiseta de edición limitada de Sunseed, hecha de algodón orgánico! También te enviaremos un exclusivo libro de fotografías digitales. Por favor, indícanos tu talla cuando elijas esta recompensa.

150€

1 semana legendaria en Sunseed

Serás afectuosamente recibido como uno de nuestros salvadores, y podrás experimentar nuestros programas prácticos de educación ambiental. También disfrutaras de nuestra increíble cocina vegetariana. Y por supuesto, ¡nos aseguraremos de que te lo pases fenomenal! Si eliges esta recompensa, haznos saber cuándo preferirías venir.

500€

Libro de fotografías en tapa dura

Recibes todas las recompensas anteriores, más una copia en tapa dura del libro de fotos y un agradecimiento personalizado en la cubierta trasera del libro.

1000€

¡Conviértete en una leyenda de Sunseed!

¡Le pondremos tu nombre a una de nuestras habitaciones! Te mandaremos una foto de tu nombre en la puerta, y te invitaremos a pasar 2 legendarias semanas en tu propia habitación.
story_txt:
AN ECO-PROJECT TO MAKE YOU THINK




Sunseed Desert Technology is a non-profit educational
project within an eco-village in Spain. Our mission is to research, demonstrate
and communicate methods of sustainable living and environmental stewardship in
a semi-arid environment.
Through accessible, low-tech and practical learning, our
research is directly applicable to low-income societies and a transition
to an environmentally sustainable future.
Originally conceived 30 years ago as a non-governmental
organisation (NGO), we
identified desertification as our central research objective. We now
offer hands-on educational experiences for volunteers to gain practical
knowledge in many diverse areas such as eco-construction, clean energy technologies,
permaculture, naturally-sourced household and cosmetic products, and water
management.




   WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT
Over the past year, Sunseed has incurred a number of extraordinary maintenance costs. These have included urgent structural repairs to our traditional Andalusian buildings that were crucial to ensure the safety and well being of our guests. We've had to recondition our van's engine (a vital resource as we live in one of the largest deserts in Europe) and to pay for new batteries for our solar power energy systems. We've also had to re-build our bio-gas stove in our main house which is crucial to survive the extreme cold winters in the region.

Taken all together, the timing of the above mentioned expenditures have been tragically unfortunate. We now face a precarious financial situation where the possibility of Sunseed's closure is a reality. We are seeking funding to ensure the continuation of the practical environmental education and research undertaken at Sunseed, and improve our volunteer programmes.
WHAT WE NEED TO KEEP THE PROJECT ALIVE

To keep Sunseed alive, altogether we seek to raise 10 000€ (This includes asking   5 000€ from our community, as we are attempting to raise funds from other sources as well - To this date we have raised just over 4 000€). The indiegogo budget breaks down as follows:




HOW WE PLAN TO SUSTAIN SUNSEED
Over the years, Sunseed has attracted volunteers from across the 5 continents. They are guided through immersive and holistic learning journeys in order to gain practical skills related to environmental stewardship. The quality of Sunseed programmes have been recognised in the past by major international bodies, such as the European Union's Lifelong Learning programme.

Sunseed has been self-sustainable for over 30 years and we have a clear strategy to stay this way.  We would like to reiterate that we have never needed to ask for funds through a crowdfunding campaign before, and we have had to do so due to the aforementioned circumstances. 
We will continue to stand true to our reputation and offer education in areas such as: 



Permaculture courses
How to build photovoltaic
     and wind powered systems
Eco-construction methods
Techniques for managing
     soil quality in semi-arid conditions 





SOME OF OUR KEY FUTURE PROJECTS



Projects that will become a reality through this campaign include:


Appropriate
Technology 


Create and share guides to pedal
     powered washing machine that can be used in any climate and
     without electricity
Construct two wind
     turbines – primarily from reclaimed materials – and creating
     detailed plans for replication across the world
Design and build a GEK
     (Gasifier experimental kit). The GEK is an open source design
     utilizing common materials and automation electronics for a very efficient
     gasifier that can also power a generator for electricity, heat up water,
     and produce bio-char or tar

Drylands Management 

Continue to research and educate on practical, low-cost methods for combating desertification. Methods include 'key-line' technology, and mycorrhiza techniques for plant germination


Restoration of water catchment systems to increase water sustainability.
Complete our waste water management system for the treatment of all greywater at Sunseed


Organic Gardens

To create a self-sufficient Seedbank of local and old seed varieties. Sunseed will also collaborate with local seed networks to coordinate this work at a regional level
Incorporate biodynamic and vegan horticulture techniques into our gardens whilst highlighting to volunteers how to create and manage thriving gardens without the need for animal fertilisation




Eco-construction 

Develop and share techniques on making naturally-sourced plaster mixes and experiment with natural water-proofing materials such as chumba

Research and develop natural insulation materials, such as slip straw, and educate on their applications


Sustainable Living


Make all milk on-site from own produce such as almonds and oats. Continue with grain and seed milk trials and communicate research through the internet
Research and develop information and practice on vegan nutrition methods





   


A FEW MEMBERS OF OUR TEAM OF EXPERTS 
All our departments are operated by our visionary full-time voluntary staff team, who work tirelessly to ensure volunteers visiting Sunseed gain an enriching education. From self-sustainability, green energy, and low-impact living, visitors ultimately gain the knowledge to replicate the skills learnt in their own countries and around the world.




Jack (34), England, Eco Construction Coordinator        




Jack originally developed his construction skills working with strawbale houses and earthships: both innovative methods based on reusing recycled materials. In recent years he has focused on construction techniques that utilise the locally abundant renewable resource of Caña (Cane).
“The positive energy found at Sunseed, the eagerness to research and experiment, the beauty of the place itself and the international diversity allows borders to disappear. It creates an open space to share knowledge and integrate with a mix of cultures.”

 Delphine (27), France, Drylands Management Coordinator


Delphine draws upon her academic foundations, as a trained engineer and her specialisation in environmental management to combat desertification.
“An aspect of my role is to sustainably plant trees, with the aim of disrupting erosion. We apply new techniques to regenerate the soil.”




Marina (25), Spain, Education Coordinator
Marina has her roots grounded within
teaching and a passion for permaculture projects – two vital veins
of Sunseed life.
“We are
dedicated to sharing the information and knowledge that Sunseed volunteers and
coordinators create with local schools and universities. Sunseed
offers opportunities for practical work experience and internships.”

Tom (29), England, Facilitation Coordinator                   
Tom has recently joined Sunseed and provides oversight on the administrative, financial and funding of Sunseed. His previous experience includes working with numerous environmental campaigning and human rights organisations. 
“In addition to ensuring financial sustainability for Sunseed, it’s my goal to continue to develop and implement non-hierarchical organising structures. I believe many who come to Sunseed can learn from such progressive techniques and continue to exercise them in their own lives."


WHERE TO FIND US
We are located in the valley of Rio de Aguas, near Almeria, in the Southeast of Spain. The natural vegetation is typically Mediterranean: thyme, sage, saltbush and ground shrub, with scarce trees, such as olive and carob. There are also many pita (agave) and chumba (cactus), introduced to Spain from Mexico. It is a beautiful environment that inspires locals and visitors alike.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US


As we move through uncertain times ecologically, politically, and socially, we feel it's more important than ever to ensure sustainability, permaculture, community, and clean energy are pegged as priorities to everyone's personal agenda. Can you help us continue to achieve this and create a sustainable future?
To our knowledge, we are the only practical education project researching desertification and other environmental threats in Europe. We now need funds to ensure the continuation of our important work and that generations of volunteers can benefit from the unique learning programmes that we offer.
If you can't support us through monetary donations, you can help publicise Sunseed's work through social media, or contact us with ideas. Even better, come and visit us in Spain. You're more than welcome any time!
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

“Un aspecto de
mi labor es plantar árboles de forma sostenible, con el objetivo de detener la erosión. Aplicamos
nuevas técnicas para
regenerar el suelo”.
Marina (25), España, Coordinadora de Educación
Marina se apoya
en su pasión por la enseñanza y los proyectos de permacultura - dos aspectos
fundamentales de la vida en Sunseed.
“Nos dedicamos a
compartir la información y el conocimiento creado por los coordinadores y voluntarios de
Sunseed con escuelas locales y universidades. Sunseed ofrece la posibilidad de
realizar estancias y trabajos prácticos”.
Tom (29),
Inglaterra, Coordinador de Instalaciones
Tom se ha unido
recientemente a Sunseed, y colabora con la supervisión de la
financiación, administración y
contabilidad en Sunseed. Sus experiencias previas incluyen el trabajo con
numerosas organizaciones medioambientales y de derechos humanos.
“Además de asegurar la estabilidad financiera de Sunseed, mi objetivo es
continuar desarrollando e implementando estructuras de organización no jerárquicas. Creo muchos de los que vienen a
Sunseed puede aprender de este tipo de técnicas progresistas y seguir aplicándolas en su
vida diaria”.
DÓNDE
NOS ENCONTRAMOS
Nuestras
instalaciones están en el valle del Rio Aguas, cerca de Almería, al sureste
de España. La vegetación circundantes
es típicamente
mediterránea: tomillo,
salvia, orgaza, arbustos y árboles dispersos, como olivos o algarrobos. También hay bastantes
pitas (ágapes) y
chumbos (cactus), introducidos en España desde México. Es un
hermoso paraje capaz de inspirar por igual tanto a los visitantes como a los
residentes.
OTRAS FORMAS DE AYUDARNOS
En estos
tiempos de incertidumbre política, ecológica y social,
sentimos que es más importante que nunca asegurarnos de que la sostenibilidad, la
permacultura, la comunidad y las energías limpias son una prioridad destacada en la
agenda privada de cada uno. ¿Puedes ayudarnos a lograr esto y crear un futuro sostenible?
Hasta donde
sabemos, somos el único proyecto educativo en Europa con un enfoque práctica que investiga
la desertificación y otras amenazas medioambientales. En este momento necesitamos
fondos para asegurar la continuidad de nuestra importante labor y que las
futuras generaciones de voluntarios puedan beneficiarse de los programas de
aprendizaje que ofrecemos, únicos en su clase.
Si no puedes
ayudarnos financieramente, puedes hacerlo difundiendo el trabajo de Sunseed a
través de las redes
sociales, o haciéndonos llegar tus propias ideas. O aún mejor, ven y visítanos. ¡Siempre serás bienvenido!
5€
¡Agradecimiento especial!
Tu nombre
aparecerá en una sección especial de agradecimiento en nuestra página web y perfil de Facebook. ¡Serás parte del salón de la fama de los salvadores de Sunseed!
15€
Postal de
Sunseed hecha a mano
Te enviaremos
una postal hecha a mano con un mensaje personalizado y nuestro amor eterno.
25€
¡Planta un árbol en el
desierto!
Le pondremos tu
nombre a uno de los árboles o
arbustos del jardín forestal o del jardín botánico de
Sunseed. Te enviaremos una foto y un mensaje personalizado de agradecimiento.
50€
Libro de
fotografía digital de edición limitada
Recibirás un libro de fotos digitales hecho por fotógrafos profesionales, donde podrás disfrutar de una visión de una vida
alternativa en Andalucía, incluyendo
información extra sobre los proyectos
que has ayudado a mantener con vida.
75€
Camiseta de
edición liitada
¡Recibirás una camiseta
de edición limitada de Sunseed, hecha
de algodón orgánico! También te enviaremos
un exclusivo libro de fotografías digitales.
Por favor, indícanos tu talla cuando elijas
esta recompensa.
150€
1 semana
legendaria en Sunseed
Serás afectuosamente recibido como uno de nuestros
salvadores, y podrás experimentar nuestros
programas prácticos de educación ambiental. También disfrutaras
de nuestra increíble cocina vegetariana. Y
por supuesto, ¡nos aseguraremos de que te
lo pases fenomenal! Si eliges esta recompensa, haznos saber cuándo preferirías venir.
500€
Libro de
fotografías en tapa dura
Recibes todas
las recompensas anteriores, más una copia en
tapa dura del libro de fotos y un agradecimiento personalizado en la cubierta
trasera del libro.
1000€
¡Conviértete en una
leyenda de Sunseed!
¡Le pondremos tu nombre a una de nuestras
habitaciones! Te mandaremos una foto de tu nombre en la puerta, y te
invitaremos a pasar 2 legendarias semanas en tu propia habitación.
campaign_city: Los Molinos del Rio Aguas, Spain

story:
Burkina Faso, Africa where 85% of the country does not have access to clean water sources.  The United Nations ranks Burkina Faso as the third poorest country in the world. The population of Burkina Faso is approximately 14.8 million people, the average income is only about $400 per year. The average life expectancy of men is 51 years and women is 54 years. One out of three children will probably die before they ever reach the age of ten.   12,000 under age 5 die annually from poor water & sanitation.  

The deaths are mostly due to a lack of fresh water. The women and children of Burkina Faso often walk several miles a day to a dirty stream or stagnant pool, just to fill a bowl with water.  This also prevents many children from going to school and being able to break the poverty cycle.


I’m asking you to consider helping us bring clean water to Africa.  I had done research on ways to provide clean water.  One well costs $2,000.  I like that these wells are dug on church property so people can get clean water and also learn about the Living Water.

Once the money is received by Clean Water in Africa Inc. , 100% goes to wells.  The man that heads it up covers all expenses and administration costs personally. 

You can also send a check directly to Clean Water.  Clean Water In Africa, Inc, 2009 Westover Lane, Kennesaw, GA 30152.  Please specify Pearl Taylor Memorial in the memo line. 

Here's the website if you want to read more www.cleanwaterinafrica.com

Thank you for considering this.  Please feel free to encourage others to donate as well.

story:
Imagine Life on a Planet without Healthy Soil and Pure Water...


Climate change variability and over use of chemical fertilizers in our soils, coupled with destructive farming practices, have caused extensive degradation of agricultural soil and forest land.  There is an increase in scarcity and contamination of our water resources, and major pollution of the earths' atmosphere. Numerous examples exist across the globe.



What if there was an innovative, carbon negative, and sustainable way to bring new life back into our soil and water systems, using only Biomass waste, which profits the environment and our communities?


Terra preta - 2000 year old practice

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Terra preta (Portuguese pronunciation: [ˈtɛʁɐ ˈpɾetɐ], locally [ˈtɛhɐ ˈpɾetɐ], literally "black earth" or "black land" in Portuguese) is a type of very dark, fertile anthropogenic soil found in the Amazon Basin. Terra preta owes its name to its very high charcoal content, and was made by adding a mixture of charcoal, bone, and manure to the otherwise relatively infertile Amazonian soil. It is very stable and remains in the soil for thousands of years.[1][2] It is also known as "Amazonian dark earth" or "Indian black earth".





After discovering this amazing soil, we started finding ways to re-introduce Terra Preta through the production and application of Biochar:

  • By developing Biochar production systems, placed in our communities, that generating income for local businesses
  • Creating jobs by processing waste into valuable products
  • Producing Biochar that is used by the local farming community to enhance the soil, purify water, and increase retention of nutrients in the soil
  • Helping local farmers produce greater, and healthier crops


Key Benefits of Biochar in the Soil:
  1. Increases water retention in the soil - for each 1% Biochar added to 1000 kg of sandy soil, 250 kg of water can be captured and slowly released for up to 30 days in the soil
  2. Increased nutrient retention in the soil - 10 - 20% of organic / chemical fertilizer can be replaced with Biochar increasing the availability and effectivity of the remaining 80 - 90% in the soil. With the addition of Biochar, Soil fertilizers are not easily washed out of the soils making it available to plants.
  3. Soil microbes - the life of the soil - loves Biochar, making it their preferred home!
  4. Biochar increases plant growth up to 51% while reducing fertilizing requirements up to 50% for certain crops.





Why are we crowdfunding?
With this campaign we want to raise awareness of Biochar, our technology, and gain your support to complete the construction of the first NewCarbon Prototype and run our first production and testing campaigns.

The information gained from our Research and Development work, using the NewCarbon Prototype, will be used to develop specific environmental-socio-economic projects within our poorer communities. We aim to have our first community project up and running towards the later part of 2015.

Our crowdfunding dream: we would like 5,000 crowdfunding backers to help us revolutionize our way of living.  We need you to join us! With your support we will reach our fundraising goal of $50,000.


Please consider to help us help our local charity orginisation by selecting the FRESH START perk, where 90% of your generous contribution will be donated to them. Please visit http://www.freshstart.org.za/ to find out more. In the meantime, we'd love you to continue reading...


Please check out the great perks* we have prepared to express our gratitude, and join the NewCarbon revolution by supporting us. Help us realize the dream to revitalize life through the production and application of Biochar.

Here are some examples of our great perks. To see the full range please scroll to the bottom.




NewCarbon Innovation
NewCarbon has been developing innovative ways to modernize a 2000 year-old practice by producing BioChar in a novel, clean, and cost effective way using only biomass waste and solar energy.



BioChar is a powerful tool that can be used to fight climate change, increase the health of our soils, and purify water thereby boosting food and water security.


What is Biochar?
BioChar is a natural, organic based, carbon product obtained from the carbonisation of various forms of Biomass.  These forms include by-products of plant extracts, wood waste, crop residues, and green waste.


BioChar is applied to the soil to enhance water and nutrient holding capacity. It provides a home for microbial life in the soil, boosting food security through soil health, and improving green growth. The application of BioChar to agriculture can increase crop production by up to 51% while lowering chemical fertilizing requirements by 50%.



Biochar is a powerful tool that can be used to fight global warming by creating a carbon negative cycle through Carbon Sequestration. Each 1 ton of Biochar put back into the soil has the potential to sequester ±3.5 tons of CO2 from the atmosphere.

* pictures from the International Biochar Initiative (IBI).

Normal carbon sequestration by photosynthesis is Carbon neutral, which means that all the carbon dioxide (CO2) being captured by trees and plants is released back into the atmosphere during the decomposition process.


Biochar sequestration is achieved using the process of pyrolysis to produce a beneficial, solid, organic based carbon, that can be stored in the soil for up to 1000 years, thus decreasing the carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere.




How does NewCarbon's technology work?

The NewCarbon technology converts biomass waste into valuable BioChar through the process of pyrolysis.  Pyrolysis is the process of transforming Biomass, by a thermo-chemical process, into valuable products that include Syngas, Bio-Oils and Biochar. 



NewCarbon’s technology is unique. Energy from syngas and bio-oil is used to dry and convert the biomass to BioChar, and power the machine. The control and monitoring system is powered by solar energy. The clean-burn product gas from NewCarbon's technology is ideal for stimulating growth in greenhouses, where a further carbon sink is created.




What do we aim to achieve with NewCarbon's technology?

From our research into Biochar production technologies and application opportunities, it became apparent that a clean, low-tech, low-cost, semi-mobile, self-sustaining technology was required.


The capacity to process between 1 and 5 tons of Biomass per hour, and the ability to place the operation anywhere where there is a biomass waste source, proved to be critical for the economic viability of Biochar production and use.


NewCarbon technology enables the creation of a renewing lifecycle, continuously increasing the health of the planet through restoration of food and water systems.




This NewCarbon technology will enable the cost effective production of Biochar on a  scale small enough to be run as a local business unit, and large enough to make a substantial impact on local agriculture and communities.


What's been achieved so far?
From September 2014, when the value of Biochar dawned on us, we have been investing our time, money, and energy into:

  • General research of the world-wide Biochar industry, type of feedstock, processes, products, and potential markets - Sept to Nov 2014
  • Process design and conceptualizing of the NewCarbon technology - Oct to Nov 2014
  • Concept development and testing - Nov and Dec 2014
  • Preparation and testing of various feedstock - Nov and Dec 2014
  • Technology scouting, and commercialization potential - Dec / Jan 2015
  • Prototype design and construction - Feb to June 2015
  • Project development planning, and fundraising - April to June 2015




What is the plan for the immediate future?
We're at a critical point in the development process. We have prepared and cast a strong foundation for the NewCarbon Prototype, metaphorically and physically speaking, and now need you to help us complete the construction.


Our plan for the immediate future includes:

  • Complete the construction of the 1 ton per hour NewCarbon Prototype - June to July 2015
  • The first Biochar produced will be used for applied research at the University of Fort Hare, Eastern Cape, South Africa titled "The use of Biochar in Rural Community Development and Agriculture" - July to December 2015
  • Test the NewCarbon Prototype performance with readily available feedstock with various properties e.g. sizes, shapes, moisture content
  • Evaluate the NewCarbon Prototype durability, and identify design optimization opportunities
  • Test various feedstock materials in the NewCarbon Prototype, for example saw mill biomass waste, invader species, and poultry farm bio-waste
  • Benchmark the NewCarbon Prototype against similar production units across the globe
  • Production testing of NewCarbon Prototype for commercial roll-out
  • Process and design optimization of NewCarbon Prototype for commercial roll-out
  • Business Plan set-up and development for commercial roll-out



Achieving these goals, with your help, will be a major achievement for all of us.

The project will advance the global strategy of moving towards a lower-carbon economy, and:
  • create new jobs,
  • stimulate growth,
  • promote science and innovation partnerships,
  • develop skills and expertise,
  • provide a focus opportunity for environmental reform,
  • boost food security,
  • build science and technology capacity, and
  • address the challenges of climate change.


Thank you very much,
Marius, Belinda, Mario, Geoff, Hendrik, Clint and Fred
www.newcarbon.co.za
prototype@newcarbon.co.za

NewCarbon Team



NewCarbon Founders:
Marius van der Merwe. Director, Engineer and Inventor.
Belinda France-Brotherton. Partner and Health practitioner.
Mario du Plooy. Initiator, Innovator, loves the soil, passionate, carbon runs through his veins.

Research and Engineering Partners:
Hendrik de Waal. Mr. Pyrolysis, works like a machine, prototype builder.
Geoff Osch. Engineer, electrical and controls, automation man.
Clint NIemand. Machine builder, feeders and product handling.

Advisory Board:
Fred Brown. Environmental, Corporate Strategy.
Peter Brodrick. Business Development, Financial.
Francois Hanekom. Former Senior Professor at UNISA; Director-General of Environmental Affairs and Tourism South Africa.
PERKS

Baseball Cap



Bags



T-shirts
Ladies (examples)



Men's (examples)



Flip-Flops



Hoodies (front only)


Hoodies (back only)



Water Bottles



Apron and Gloves



Farmers Hat



*Please note that combinations of colors and logos will be finalised after the campaign. Colors of items might vary slightly from that shown in the illustrations.

story:
Intro:

Climate mitigation action with low cost environmentally enhancement techniques is essential to counteract the current warming trends; our team will project manage cutting edge technology to meet those goals.

Why is important we get funded?

If successful we will be able to fund construction of a pilot project that showcases Sea Water Farming Systems that could green desert climates and mitigate global sea level rise. Waste Water Treatment systems can create water abundance in arid climates through reclamation treatment. Algae Cultivation can be used for carbon sequestration, biofuel production and bio plastics. Our primary goal is focused on job creation and environmental revitalization with large scale climate adaptation opportunities. These are the first steps in true climate action with a small price tag which utilizes biomimicry.

"Professional management, for a better environment"

Every contribution makes a difference and every dollar counts. 

If every person in Southern California gave one dollar we could use $22,000,000  to clean all the water inlets at the Salton Sea and the majority of the water in the sea.    

If every person in the USA gave one dollar we could use $319,000,000 to help Clean all of the major waterways in the USA, as well as the Pacific and Atlantic oceans.  

If every person in the world a gave one dollar we could use $7,125,000,000 to help clean all of the major polluted waterways and oceans around the world.

Our Mission: 

To develop and implement proven ideas at the Salton Sea. Our goal is to help solve the problems surrounding the sea by combining various innovative technologies. By utilizing a project management background, AGESS will help coordinate the multitude of technological efforts required to preventenvironmental degradation. By integrating these systems, we will be able to create a self sustaining revitalized sea, ultimately restoring the environment ecology and economy.

Current Focuses: 
Provide solutions to nutrient pollution and carbon sequestration at the Salton Sea. Strategies include habitat restoration, salt water agriculture and aquaculture implementation

Problems at the Salton Sea: 

In the last thirty years, Salton Sea has been a well known problematic spot in southern California. Eutrophication used to be the only problem in the sea causing concerns of deteriorated water quality and damaged environment for the locals. However, over the years more problems have developed, such as high salt concentrations and a shrinking water supply. As the sea continues to dry up, the dust created by the exposed seabed sediment can be carried away in windy conditions and spread across southern California. The majority of the fine dust particles measure less than 10 microns in diameter and have already been targeted as the main culprit behind increased occurrences of respiratory system diseases of children in the Coachella and Imperial Valley. Any large-scale dust storms in the future are of great health concern to not only Southern California, but expanding to regions in Arizona, Nevada and Mexico. 


Technical Study Description: 


The extreme degradation of the Salton Sea can be directly attributed to the eutrophication of the aquatic ecosystem. A body of water is considered to be of eutrophic status when nutrients such nitrogen and phosphorous are elevated beyond their natural levels.  As a result of the excess nutrients in the system, opportunistic species such as algae can leave a wake of problems if left uncontrolled. As algae growth takes over on the surface, an increased amount of algal biomass enters the ecosystem. As algal cells naturally die off, the aerobic bacteria involved in the decomposition process must consume an increased amount of dissolved oxygen. As oxygen is depleted below the surface of the water, a hypoxic environment is created and fish begin to die off. The Salton Sea has known “dead zones” in which anaerobic bacteria thrive on the high amount of decaying detrital biomass and produce smelly hydrogen sulfide gas as a byproduct. The nutrient in-flow to the sea has been occurring since the sea was formed more than one hundred years ago, and has never had any source of nutrient out-flow. Establishing a nutrient extraction mechanism is the key to the decontamination of the waters. For many years, the restoration of the Salton Sea has been focused on eliminating the nutrient in-flow, however this has failed to be an effective method to remove the nutrients. Our team is proposing to both effectively remove nutrients from the drainage water leading to the sea , as well as to utilize the extracted nutrients as a raw material for a second series of production through aquaculture and agriculture. With the future commercial expansion we will also remove nutrients for the Salton Sea itself to reuse the nutrients for algae harvesting and biomass processing as an income stream.

To create an outflow of nutrients, it is necessary to determine the point at which eutrophication occurs and what variables can be removed. Nutrients cycle through the food chain from producers to consumers, and are then made available to the producers again through decomposition. The inorganic nutrients nitrogen and phosphorous in an aquatic ecosystem will be consumed by the primary producers such as algae and other plants. In turn, algae and plant populations are then controlled by primary consumers such as fish, shrimp and clams. Fish, shrimp, and clam populations are then controlled by secondary consumers such as animals and humans. This is how nutrients are removed from the aquatic ecosystem and flow into the regional food chain. Animal and human waste (in the form of waste water treatment plant effluent) is then degraded by bacteria and nutrients are stored in the soil. Rainwater will carry these nutrients back to the waterway to start a new cycle. In the case of eutrophication, the nutrient in-flow exceeds the consumption capacity of regular algae. The excess nutrients promote an abrupt and unhealthy growth of algae in the system. If marine animals cannot deplete the algal cells, for any reason, bacteria will flourish on the debris of algal cells. The rapid growth of bacteria exhausts the dissolved oxygen in water and suffocates all plants and animals in the water forming the “dead zone.”  The only survivors in a “dead zone” are anaerobic bacteria, which release the rotten smelling gasses.

To prevent eutrophication requires slowing down the nutrient in-flow or accelerating the nutrient out-flow. By removing the algae, or the food source of the aerobic bacteria, the aerobic bacteria will then become a variable that can be removed or controlled. By harvesting the flourishing algae, the oxygen-depleting aerobic bacteria, or even the smelly anaerobic bacteria, the progression of eutrophication can be stopped at any of these stages by creating an outflow for the excess nutrients. For example, the removal of nutrients could prevent algae growth, which stops eutrophication from starting. This removal of algal biomass could cut off the food supply for aerobic bacteria preserving dissolved oxygen for aquatic life and saving the environment. Controlling the aerobic bacteria will in turn maintain the growth of anaerobic bacteria, stopping further deterioration of the ecosystem. In practice, removing nutrients can only be achieved by harvesting the algae and limiting the bacteria growth. If the right technology is adopted, both of these goals can be completed in one procedure.

Indiegogo funds totaling $150,000 will be allocated in the following ways:

·  $30,000 will be allocated to mobilization, design & construction documents, lease of excavation / rental equipment, concrete water intake structures from the river and other miscellaneous purchases for project set-up. We will also purchase Geo-Tube material for artificial wetland construction. A portion of this amount will also be allocated to the research, proving each system is working to which their standards have been set.

·  $20,000 will be allocated to the purchase and installation of algae cultivation & harvesting systems, including, but not limited to, AGESS algae proliferator system, algae photo bioreactors and Water Wagon from, Eco Pond Rescue Dewatering systems. Also maintenance and operation.

·  $35,000 will be allocated to the purchase and installation of a Leviathan unit from Floating Islands West, LLC. To be installed in an artificial wetland filtering Salton Sea water.

·  $30,000 will be allocated to the construction and site preparation for constructed wetland and H20 Futures, Sea Water Farming systems.

·  $30,000 will be allocated to the Gulp Clear Water, LLC. Waste water treatment systems.

·  $50,000 is an In-Kind Contributions from the Torres-Martinez Tribe of Cahullia Indians will include long term land lease, permitting, monitoring, and environmental reports.

·  $25,000 Additional In-Kind Contributions will be provided by AGESS, Inc and consultants for design, construction documents and project management services.


Biography

1. Alternative Generating Energies and Sustainable Solutions

Our Mission: 
To develop and implement proven ideas at the Salton Sea. We want to help solve the problems surrounding the sea by combining various innovative technologies. AGESS, by utilizing a project management background, will help coordinate the multitude of techno-logical efforts required to prevent an environmental & health disaster. By integrating these systems, we will be able to create a self sustaining revitalized sea, ultimately restor-ing the environment and the community there as a whole. Moto: "Professional manage-ment, for a better environment."

Team Members: 
Nathan White, CEO /Co-founder 
Aaron A. Borja, COO /Co-founder 
R. Barrett Miesfeld, CTO 
Albert Fabriquer, CDO 
Mike Giannini, CCO

2.Floating Islands West, LLC.

Floating Islands West, LLC is the West Coast manufacturer and distribution center for BioHaven® Floating Islands. We provide an innovative approach to world water and habitat issues by providing a full range of services, including island design, co-design, in-stallation, as well as training. As a license holder of BioHaven® Floating Islands we are able to custom create islands to your specifications. We are the single supplier of the smaller line of BioHaven products throughout the US and Canada; if you are short on space, but would like your own floating island, we can help. With products starting at 5 square feet in size, you'll be sure to find something that fits your needs.

Laddie Flock, CEO

3. Gulp Clear Water, LLC

Our mission is to establish a new quality and standard for water purification and conser-vation through the Gulp Clear Water System. By utilizing a proprietary and programma-ble blend of advanced purification media, along with the next generation of germicidal technology, we are able to deliver pure, inexpensive water from any source.

Team Members- 
Keith Ervin- CTO/Co-founder 
Jerry Hagemann- CEO/Co-founder 
Milt Stewart- CFO 
Chad Ervin- Vice President of Sales

4. H2O Futures, Architecture Consultants-

With decades of experience, H2O Futures revolutionizes water availability. Our unique design approach and our proprietary methods leverage systems have sustained ecologies on Earth for 3.5 billion years. They capture and clean existing wastewater, storm water, and/or seawater for reuse. Thus, land – whether urban or rural – becomes greener, more robust and more profitable.

Team Members: 
Edwin F. Daugherty, Licensed Architect, Registered Landscape 
Norm Allenby, LLB, Onsite Water Treatment 
Hany Elwany, Ph.D., Engineer, Oceanographer and Coastal Engineer 
Barney P. Popkin, Cal/PG & REA, contractor, Hydrologist 
Chris Stransky, M.S., AMEC Earth & Environmental, Water and Sediment Quality Assessment

5.Nag, Inc. Geo-Spatial Consultant-

Established in 1991, Nag, Inc. (NAG) is a geospatial visualization consulting firm special-izing in the development of products and services that enable real time intelligent map-ping of actionable events viewable through an easy to use geospatial visualization inter-face. NAG currently supports bi-coastal operations within the United States, with offices in Los Angeles, CA and the Washington DC Metro area. Our core products and services are cloud based and accessible on any device, designed to leverage the power of existing client infrastructure to reduce costs and implementation times, and are configurable to en-able use in almost any industry or customer need. Specialized versions of our products and services are available for U.S. Federal, State, Regional, and Local Governments agencies throughout the nation.

Intro:Climate mitigation action with low cost environmentally enhancement techniques is essential to counteract the current warming trends; our team will project manage cutting edge technology to meet those goals.Why is important we get funded?If successful we will be able to fund construction of a pilot project that showcases Sea Water Farming Systems that could green desert climates and mitigate global sea level rise. Waste Water Treatment systems can create water abundance in arid climates through reclamation treatment. Algae Cultivation can be used for carbon sequestration, biofuel production and bio plastics. Our primary goal is focused on job creation and environmental revitalization with large scale climate adaptation opportunities. These are the first steps in true climate action with a small price tag which utilizes biomimicry.
"Professional management, for a better
environment"
Every contribution makes a difference and every dollar counts. If every person in Southern California gave one dollar we could use $22,000,000  to clean all the water inlets at the Salton Sea and the majority of the water in the sea.    If every person in the USA gave one dollar we could use $319,000,000 to help Clean all of the major waterways in the USA, as well as the Pacific and Atlantic oceans.  If every person in the world a gave one dollar we could use $7,125,000,000 to help clean all of the major polluted waterways and oceans around the world.

ecology and economy.

Focuses: Provide solutions to nutrient pollution and
carbon sequestration at the Salton Sea. Strategies include habitat restoration, salt water agriculture and aquaculture implementation

Problems at the Salton Sea: 
In the last thirty years, Salton Sea has been a well known problematic spot in southern California.
Eutrophication used to be the only problem in the sea causing concerns of
deteriorated water quality and damaged environment for the locals. However,
over the years more problems have developed, such as high salt concentrations
and a shrinking water supply. As the sea continues to dry up, the dust created
by the exposed seabed sediment can be carried away in windy conditions and
spread across southern California. The majority of the fine dust particles
measure less than 10 microns in diameter and have already been targeted as the
main culprit behind increased occurrences of respiratory system diseases of
children in the Coachella and Imperial Valley. Any large-scale dust storms in
the future are of great health concern to not only Southern California, but
expanding to regions in Arizona, Nevada and Mexico.
