story:
(Für die deutsche Version bitte nach unten scrollen)


"We must take care of the oceans as if our lives depend on it,

because they do.”

(Sylvia A. Earle)



Who I am

My name is Julia Hager and I am a marine biologist. Starting this coming December, I will have the opportunity to lead the project Fishing for Microplastic as part of the Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research team in the Andaman Sea off Myanmar for the winter season.


What is Fishing for Microplastic about?

The project will provide insight into the microplastic pollution in one of the last mostly untouched regions on Earth, the Mergui Archipelago. Our overall goal is to find out how much this pristine ecosystem in a remote area is affected by plastic pollution. We will take samples on beaches and from the water surface and determine the amount and composition of debris items. Also, we will examine stomach contents of fish in cooperation with local fishermen in order to assess the number of fish that mistake plastic pieces for food. Those particles will undergo a detailed analysis in the lab using Raman and/or FTIR spectroscopy. Additionally, we will undertake visual surveys of the sea floor for larger debris and document animals that got entangled in marine litter.


Where is the Mergui Archipelago and what is so special about it?

The Mergui Archipelago in the Andaman Sea comprises about 800 islands belonging to Myanmar. It is characterized by an extensive coral reef system, wide sea grass beds and beautiful mangrove forests forming an ecosystem with an outstanding biodiversity. These characteristics have led Mission Blue to designating the Mergui Archipelago as one of their Hope Spots – “places that are critical to the health of the ocean”. Furthermore, the UNESCO nominated the region as candidate for a World Heritage Site.

Our work will provide valuable data and might help in the UNESCO evaluation process.


Why doing research in a remote, mostly uninhabited place?

The Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research project offers the unique opportunity to explore a pristine, largely undisturbed region. It is one of the last spots with near-intact ecosystems and a rich biodiversity providing food and oxygen. Life advances in those places that show how ecosystems develop and function without human influence. To some extent the Mergui Archipelago is naturally protected by its virtual isolation. However, global influences like climate change or ocean acidification cannot be kept away from those islands. This is also true for anthropogenic debris. Even if the debris sources are thousands of kilometers away, the ocean currents will transport the remains of human activity in every corner of the world.


Our expedition platform

Sea Nomad, a sail catamaran designed for research will serve as platform for our project. The scientific equipment includes plankton nets and various other sampling devices, a sonar, a microscope, a refractometer, DSLR cameras, underwater housings and more.


Why should you care about our oceans?

The answer is quite simple. Every drop of water we drink and every other molecule of oxygen we breathe have their origin in the ocean. Without healthy oceans humankind and almost all other species will not be able to survive. Realizing that is essential.


Want to know more?

Already, a minimum estimate of 5.25 trillion (!!) plastic pieces are floating in our oceans: from microbeads, found in cosmetics, to plastic bags and large items like containers and derelict fishing gear; from the North and South Pacific Oceans to the Atlantic and Indian Oceans and the Mediterranean Sea. And those trillions of plastic pieces are only the visible ones on the water surface.  Some even presume that there may be six times more plastic floating in the oceans than plankton.

The plastic fragments themselves already impose great threats to marine creatures. Sea turtles ingest plastic bags, whales get entangled in derelict fishing gear, sea bird chicks starve to death with a stomach full of plastic particles, only to name a few examples. Every year, hundreds of thousands marine animals die from eating plastic. 
The indirect danger, also for human health, is the ability of plastic to adsorb chemical pollutants (e.g. pesticides) and release them along with plasticizers and flame retardants when ingested. Once eaten and released in the tissue of an animal, the chemicals work their way up the food chain and eventually land with the tuna, swordfish, salmon or cod on our plates.

Sadly, there are many problems our oceans are struggling with – global warming leading to acidification, noise pollution, overfishing, chemical pollutants. Anthropogenic plastic pollution is one that reached public attention only recently. Hopefully not too late... 


Where the funds go

Seagoing scientific expeditions are always a financial challenge due to maintenance costs of the boat and scientific equipment. Travel expenses and regional fees are adding to the overall costs.

Your donation will help cover the costs for the 2015/2016 season for the following items:

-  expedition
-  sampling gear (nets, test sieves)
-  USB microscope
-  analytical scale
-  other equipment (sample tubes, containers, …)
-  traveling
-  visa & regional fees


What if I can’t donate?

No worries, there is a way how you can still help. Just spread the word and share this campaign among your friends or coworkers. That will make a big difference.


Last but not least…

In whatever way you help I am very thankful for your contribution! I hope you understand that there are no perks for your donation as I dedicate every donated cent to the project. But make sure to check back for news and pictures!

_____________________________________________________________________________

„Wir müssen auf unsere Meere achtgeben als würde unser Leben davon abhängen, weil es so ist.“

(Sylvia A. Earle)


Über mich

Mein Name ist Julia Hager und ich bin Meeresbiologin. Ab Dezember diesen Jahres habe ich die Gelegenheit, das Projekt „Fishing for Microplastic“ zu leiten als Teil des Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research Teams in der Andamanen See vor Myanmar.


Worum geht es bei Fishing for Microplastic?

Das Projekt wird Einblicke in die Mikroplastik-Verschmutzung liefern in einer der letzten fast unberührten Regionen der Erde, dem Mergui Archipel. Unser Ziel ist es, herauszufinden wie groß die Auswirkungen von marinem Plastikmüll auf dieses ursprüngliche Ökosystem sind. Um die Menge und Zusammensetzung der Plastikpartikel zu bestimmen, werden wir Proben an den Stränden und der Wasseroberfläche nehmen. Außerdem werden wir in Zusammenarbeit mit einheimischen Fischern den Mageninhalt von Fischen auf Mikroplastikpartikel untersuchen. Die gefundenen Partikel werden wir dann im Labor mit Raman und/oder FTIR Spektroskopen detailliert analysieren. Ebenso soll größerer anthropogener Müll am Meeresboden erfasst werden sowie Tiere, die sich z.B. in Leinen oder Netzen verfangen haben.


Wo ist der Mergui Archipel und warum ist dieser so besonders?

Der Mergui Archipel in der Andamanen See umfasst mehr als 800 Inseln und gehört zu Myanmar, dem früheren Burma. Ausgedehnte Korallenriffe, weite Seegraswiesen und herrliche Mangrovenwälder formen ein Ökosystem mit einer herausragenden Biodiversität. Diese Merkmale haben Mission Blue veranlasst, den Mergui Archipel als einer ihrer „Hope Spots“ zu nominieren – „Gebiete, die entscheidend sind für die Gesundheit der Ozeane“. Darüber hinaus hat die UNESCO die Region ihrer Liste als mögliches Weltnaturerbe hinzugefügt.


Weshalb die Forschung in einer abgeschiedenen, fast unbewohnten Region?

Das Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research Projekt bietet die einzigartige Gelegenheit, ein ursprüngliches und weitgehend unberührtes Gebiet zu erforschen. Es ist einer der letzten Orte mit nahezu intakten Ökosystemen und einer außergewöhnlichen Artenvielfalt, die die Grundlage für Nahrung und Sauerstoffproduktion bilden. Solche Regionen mit blühendem Leben zeigen, wie Ökosysteme sich entwickeln und funktionieren ohne den Einfluss des Menschen. Durch seine scheinbare Isolation ist der Mergui Archipel zu einem gewissen Grad natürlicherweise geschützt. Globale Auswirkungen wie die anthropogene Verschmutzung können jedoch ebenso wenig von diesen Inseln ferngehalten werden wie der Klimawandel oder die Versauerung der Ozeane. Auch wenn die Quellen der Verschmutzung tausende Kilometer entfernt liegen – die Hinterlassenschaften des Menschen werden von den Meeresströmungen in jeden Winkel der Erde transportiert.


Unsere Expeditionsplattform

SeaNomad, ein Segelkatamaran, der speziell für Forschungszwecke entworfen wurde, ist die Basis für unser Projekt. Die wissenschaftliche Ausrüstung umfasst Planktonnetze und andere Probenahmegeräte, ein Sonar, ein Mikroskop, ein Refraktometer, Spiegelreflexkameras mit Unterwassergehäuse und mehr.


Warum sollten Sie sich für das Wohlergehen unserer Meere interessieren?

Die Antwort ist ganz einfach. Jeder Tropfen Wasser, den wir trinken und mehr als jedes zweite Sauerstoffmolekül, das wir einatmen haben ihren Ursprung im Meer. Ohne gesunde Ozeane wird die Menschheit sowie fast alle anderen Arten der Erde nicht überleben können. Dies zu erkennen ist essentiell.


Sie möchten mehr wissen?

Eine minimale Schätzung ergab, dass bereits heute 5,25 Billionen (!!) Plastikpartikel in unseren Meeren schwimmen: von Mikrokügelchen, die in Kosmetik verwendet werden, zu Plastiktüten und größeren Teilen, wie Flaschen, Behälter und alten Fischernetzen und –leinen; vom Nord- und Südpazifik zum Atlantischen und Indischen Ozean und dem Mittelmeer. Und diese Schätzung umfasst nur diejenigen Partikel, die sichtbar an der Wasseroberfläche schwimmen. Es wird sogar angenommen, dass mittlerweile sechsmal mehr Plastik in den Ozeanen treibt als Plankton.

Die Plastikfragmente an sich stellen bereits eine große Gefahr für die Lebewesen im Meer dar: Meeresschildkröten verwechseln Plastiktüten mit Quallen, Wale verfangen sich in alten Netzen und Leinen, die Küken der Seevögel verhungern mit einem Bauch voll von Plastikteilchen, nur um ein paar Beispiele zu nennen. Jedes Jahr verenden hunderttausende Meerestiere, weil sie versehentlich Plastik gefressen haben. Die indirekte Gefahr jedoch, auch für die Gesundheit des Menschen, besteht in der Fähigkeit des Plastiks, Schadstoffe (z.B. Pestizide) aus der Umgebung zu adsorbieren und diese zusammen mit Weichmachern und Flammschutzmitteln im Inneren von Tieren wieder abzugeben. Sind die mit Giftstoffen beladenen Plastikteilchen einmal verspeist und haben die Schadstoffe ihren Weg ins Gewebe gefunden, arbeiten sie sich über die Nahrungskette nach oben voran und landen früher oder später mit dem Thunfisch, Schwertfisch, Lachs oder Kabeljau auch auf unseren Tellern.

Leider gibt es sehr viele Probleme, mit denen unsere Ozeane kämpfen müssen – globale Erwärmung, die zur Versauerung führt, Lärmverschmutzung, Überfischung, schädliche Chemikalien. Anthropogene Verschmutzung durch Plastik hat erst vor kurzem öffentliche Aufmerksamkeit erlangt. Hoffentlich noch nicht zu spät...


Wofür werden die Spenden verwendet?

Wissenschaftliche Expeditionen auf See sind immer eine finanzielle Herausforderung aufgrund der Wartungskosten für das Schiff und der wissenschaftlichen Ausrüstung. Hinzu kommen Reisekosten und die Kosten für regionale Gebühren.

Ihre Spende wird helfen, die Ausgaben für die Saison 2015/2016 für die folgenden Posten abzudecken:

-  Expedition
-  Probenahmegeräte (Netze, Analysensiebe)
-  USB Mikroskop
-  Analysenwaage
-  Kleinteile (Probenbehälter u.a.)
-  Reisekosten
-  Visum & regionale Gebühren


Sie können nicht spenden, möchten aber trotzdem helfen?

Keine Sorge, verbreiten Sie meine Kampagne gern unter Freunden oder Kollegen weiter. Somit leisten Sie auch einen großen Beitrag.


Last but not least...

In welcher Weise auch immer Sie Ihren Beitrag zur Verwirklichung dieses Projekts leisten – ein herzliches Dankeschön!! Sobald wie möglich nach Beginn des Projekts werde ich auf dieser Seite Neuigkeiten und Bilder hochladen – schauen Sie also gern wieder vorbei!
story_txt:
(Für die deutsche Version bitte nach unten scrollen)"We must take care of the oceans as if our lives depend on it,because they do.”(Sylvia A. Earle)

Who I
am
My name is Julia Hager and I am a marine
biologist. Starting this coming December, I will have the opportunity to
lead the project Fishing for Microplastic as part of the Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research team in the Andaman Sea off Myanmar for the winter season.

What is
Fishing for Microplastic about?
The project will provide insight into
the microplastic pollution in one of the last mostly untouched regions on
Earth, the Mergui Archipelago. Our overall goal is to find out how much this
pristine ecosystem in a remote area is affected by plastic pollution. We will
take samples on beaches and from the water surface and determine the amount and
composition of debris items. Also, we will examine stomach contents of fish in
cooperation with local fishermen in order to assess the number of fish that
mistake plastic pieces for food. Those particles will undergo a detailed
analysis in the lab using Raman and/or FTIR spectroscopy. Additionally, we will
undertake visual surveys of the sea floor for larger debris and document
animals that got entangled in marine litter.
Where
is the Mergui Archipelago and what is so special about it?
The Mergui Archipelago in the
Andaman Sea comprises about 800 islands belonging to Myanmar. It is
characterized by an extensive coral reef system, wide sea grass beds and
beautiful mangrove forests forming an ecosystem with an outstanding
biodiversity. These characteristics have led Mission Blue to designating the Mergui
Archipelago as one of their Hope Spots – “places that are critical to the
health of the ocean”. Furthermore, the UNESCO nominated the region as
candidate for a World Heritage Site.
Our work will provide valuable data and
might help in the UNESCO evaluation process.

Why
doing research in a remote, mostly uninhabited place?
The Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity
Research project offers the unique opportunity to explore a pristine, largely
undisturbed region. It is one of the last spots with near-intact ecosystems and
a rich biodiversity providing food and oxygen. Life advances in those places
that show how ecosystems develop and function without human influence. To some
extent the Mergui Archipelago is naturally protected by its virtual isolation.
However, global influences like climate change or ocean acidification cannot be
kept away from those islands. This is also true for anthropogenic debris. Even
if the debris sources are thousands of kilometers away, the ocean currents will
transport the remains of human activity in every corner of the world.
Our
expedition platform
Sea Nomad, a sail catamaran designed for
research will serve as platform for our project. The scientific equipment
includes plankton nets and various other sampling devices, a sonar, a
microscope, a refractometer, DSLR cameras, underwater housings and more.
Why
should you care about our oceans?
The answer is quite simple. Every drop
of water we drink and every other molecule of oxygen we breathe have their
origin in the ocean. Without healthy oceans humankind and almost all other
species will not be able to survive. Realizing that is essential.
Want to
know more?
Already, a minimum estimate of 5.25
trillion (!!) plastic pieces are floating in our oceans: from microbeads, found
in cosmetics, to plastic bags and large items like containers and derelict
fishing gear; from the North and South Pacific Oceans to the Atlantic and
Indian Oceans and the Mediterranean Sea. And those trillions of plastic pieces
are only the visible ones on the water surface. 
Some even presume that there may be six times more plastic floating in
the oceans than plankton.
The plastic fragments themselves already
impose great threats to marine creatures. Sea turtles ingest plastic bags,
whales get entangled in derelict fishing gear, sea bird chicks starve to death
with a stomach full of plastic particles, only to name a few examples. 
Every year, hundreds of thousands marine animals die from
eating plastic. The
indirect danger, also for human health, is the ability of plastic to adsorb
chemical pollutants (e.g. pesticides) and release them along with plasticizers
and flame retardants when ingested. Once eaten and released in the tissue of an
animal, the chemicals work their way up the food chain and eventually land with
the tuna, swordfish, salmon or cod on our plates.
Sadly, there are many problems our
oceans are struggling with – global warming leading to acidification, noise
pollution, overfishing, chemical pollutants. Anthropogenic plastic pollution is
one that reached public attention only recently. Hopefully not too
late... 
Where
the funds go
Seagoing scientific expeditions are
always a financial challenge due to maintenance costs of the boat and
scientific equipment. Travel expenses and regional fees are adding to the
overall costs.
Your donation will help cover the costs for
the 2015/2016 season for the following items:
-  expedition-  sampling
gear (nets, test sieves)-  USB microscope-  analytical
scale-  other
equipment (sample tubes, containers, …)-  traveling-  visa
& regional fees
What if I can’t donate?
No
worries, there is a way how you can still help. Just spread the word and share
this campaign among your friends or coworkers. That will make a big difference.
Last but not least…
In
whatever way you help I am very thankful for your contribution! I hope you
understand that there are no perks for your donation as I dedicate every donated
cent to the project. But make sure to check back for news and pictures!

_____________________________________________________________________________
„Wir müssen auf unsere Meere achtgeben als würde unser Leben
davon abhängen, weil es so ist.“
(Sylvia
A. Earle)



Über mich
Mein Name ist Julia Hager und ich bin Meeresbiologin. Ab Dezember
diesen Jahres habe ich die Gelegenheit, das Projekt „Fishing for Microplastic“
zu leiten als Teil des Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research Teams in der
Andamanen See vor Myanmar.

Worum geht es bei Fishing for
Microplastic?
Das Projekt wird Einblicke in die Mikroplastik-Verschmutzung liefern in
einer der letzten fast unberührten Regionen der Erde, dem Mergui Archipel.
Unser Ziel ist es, herauszufinden wie groß die Auswirkungen von marinem
Plastikmüll auf dieses ursprüngliche Ökosystem sind. Um die Menge und
Zusammensetzung der Plastikpartikel zu bestimmen, werden wir Proben an den
Stränden und der Wasseroberfläche nehmen. Außerdem werden wir in Zusammenarbeit
mit einheimischen Fischern den Mageninhalt von Fischen auf Mikroplastikpartikel
untersuchen. Die gefundenen Partikel werden wir dann im Labor mit Raman
und/oder FTIR Spektroskopen detailliert analysieren. Ebenso soll größerer
anthropogener Müll am Meeresboden erfasst werden sowie Tiere, die sich z.B. in
Leinen oder Netzen verfangen haben.

Wo ist der Mergui Archipel
und warum ist dieser so besonders?
Der Mergui Archipel in der Andamanen See umfasst mehr als 800 Inseln
und gehört zu Myanmar, dem früheren Burma. Ausgedehnte Korallenriffe, weite
Seegraswiesen und herrliche Mangrovenwälder formen ein Ökosystem mit einer
herausragenden Biodiversität. Diese Merkmale haben Mission Blue veranlasst, den
Mergui Archipel als einer ihrer „Hope Spots“ zu nominieren – „Gebiete, die
entscheidend sind für die Gesundheit der Ozeane“. Darüber hinaus hat die UNESCO
die Region ihrer Liste als mögliches Weltnaturerbe hinzugefügt.

Weshalb die Forschung in einer
abgeschiedenen, fast unbewohnten Region?
Das Mergui Archipelago Biodiversity Research Projekt bietet die
einzigartige Gelegenheit, ein ursprüngliches und weitgehend unberührtes Gebiet
zu erforschen. Es ist einer der letzten Orte mit nahezu intakten Ökosystemen
und einer außergewöhnlichen Artenvielfalt, die die Grundlage für Nahrung und
Sauerstoffproduktion bilden. Solche Regionen mit blühendem Leben zeigen, wie
Ökosysteme sich entwickeln und funktionieren ohne den Einfluss des Menschen.
Durch seine scheinbare Isolation ist der Mergui Archipel zu einem gewissen Grad
natürlicherweise geschützt. Globale Auswirkungen wie die anthropogene
Verschmutzung können jedoch ebenso wenig von diesen Inseln ferngehalten werden
wie der Klimawandel oder die Versauerung der Ozeane. Auch wenn die Quellen der
Verschmutzung tausende Kilometer entfernt liegen – die Hinterlassenschaften des
Menschen werden von den Meeresströmungen in jeden Winkel der Erde
transportiert.

Unsere Expeditionsplattform
SeaNomad, ein Segelkatamaran, der speziell für Forschungszwecke
entworfen wurde, ist die Basis für unser Projekt. Die wissenschaftliche
Ausrüstung umfasst Planktonnetze und andere Probenahmegeräte, ein Sonar, ein
Mikroskop, ein Refraktometer, Spiegelreflexkameras mit Unterwassergehäuse und
mehr.

Warum sollten Sie sich für
das Wohlergehen unserer Meere interessieren?
Die Antwort ist ganz einfach. Jeder Tropfen Wasser, den wir trinken und
mehr als jedes zweite Sauerstoffmolekül, das wir einatmen haben ihren Ursprung
im Meer. Ohne gesunde Ozeane wird die Menschheit sowie fast alle anderen Arten
der Erde nicht überleben können. Dies zu erkennen ist essentiell.

Sie möchten mehr wissen?
Eine minimale Schätzung ergab, dass bereits heute 5,25 Billionen (!!)
Plastikpartikel in unseren Meeren schwimmen: von Mikrokügelchen, die in
Kosmetik verwendet werden, zu Plastiktüten und größeren Teilen, wie Flaschen,
Behälter und alten Fischernetzen und –leinen; vom Nord- und Südpazifik zum
Atlantischen und Indischen Ozean und dem Mittelmeer. Und diese Schätzung
umfasst nur diejenigen Partikel, die sichtbar an der Wasseroberfläche
schwimmen. Es wird sogar angenommen, dass mittlerweile sechsmal mehr Plastik in
den Ozeanen treibt als Plankton.
Die Plastikfragmente an sich stellen bereits eine große Gefahr für die
Lebewesen im Meer dar: Meeresschildkröten verwechseln Plastiktüten mit Quallen,
Wale verfangen sich in alten Netzen und Leinen, die Küken der Seevögel
verhungern mit einem Bauch voll von Plastikteilchen, nur um ein paar Beispiele
zu nennen. Jedes Jahr verenden hunderttausende Meerestiere, weil sie
versehentlich Plastik gefressen haben. Die indirekte Gefahr jedoch, auch für
die Gesundheit des Menschen, besteht in der Fähigkeit des Plastiks, Schadstoffe
(z.B. Pestizide) aus der Umgebung zu adsorbieren und diese zusammen mit
Weichmachern und Flammschutzmitteln im Inneren von Tieren wieder abzugeben.
Sind die mit Giftstoffen beladenen Plastikteilchen einmal verspeist und haben
die Schadstoffe ihren Weg ins Gewebe gefunden, arbeiten sie sich über die
Nahrungskette nach oben voran und landen früher oder später mit dem Thunfisch,
Schwertfisch, Lachs oder Kabeljau auch auf unseren Tellern.
Leider gibt es sehr viele Probleme, mit denen unsere Ozeane kämpfen
müssen – globale Erwärmung, die zur Versauerung führt, Lärmverschmutzung,
Überfischung, schädliche Chemikalien. Anthropogene Verschmutzung durch Plastik
hat erst vor kurzem öffentliche Aufmerksamkeit erlangt. Hoffentlich noch nicht
zu spät...

Wofür werden die Spenden
verwendet?
Wissenschaftliche Expeditionen auf See sind immer eine finanzielle
Herausforderung aufgrund der Wartungskosten für das Schiff und der
wissenschaftlichen Ausrüstung. Hinzu kommen Reisekosten und die Kosten für
regionale Gebühren.
Ihre Spende wird helfen, die Ausgaben für die Saison 2015/2016 für die
folgenden Posten abzudecken:
- 
Expedition- 
Probenahmegeräte (Netze,
Analysensiebe)- 
USB Mikroskop- 
Analysenwaage- 
Kleinteile (Probenbehälter u.a.)- 
Reisekosten- 
Visum & regionale Gebühren

Sie können nicht spenden,
möchten aber trotzdem helfen?
Keine Sorge, verbreiten Sie meine Kampagne gern unter Freunden oder Kollegen
weiter. Somit leisten Sie auch einen großen Beitrag.

Last but not least...
In welcher Weise auch immer Sie Ihren Beitrag zur Verwirklichung dieses
Projekts leisten – ein herzliches Dankeschön!! Sobald wie möglich nach Beginn
des Projekts werde ich auf dieser Seite Neuigkeiten und Bilder hochladen – schauen
Sie also gern wieder vorbei!

story:
Why the Science 4 Action Scholarship Fund?

All around the country, we see communities living on the fenceline of toxic industry. Whether it’s a toxic landfill or an oil refinery, air pollution is coming across the fenceline into community homes, schools and businesses. Often, residents of these communities have very high rates of asthma and other diseases, including cancer and reproductive harm. They are plagued with chemical odors and acute health effects such as frequent burning eyes and sore throats.

Many community leaders devote hours of time as volunteer activists, advocating for a clean and healthy environment for themselves and their children. They often take time off of work to attend important meetings and reach into their own personal savings accounts for campaign expenses.  

For over a decade, Global Community Monitor  (GCM) has been supporting community leaders like this in community based environmental monitoring with the Bucket Brigade, a specific type of community-based environmental monitoring.  

Community Based Monitoring

Community based monitoring empowers neighbors to collect samples when & where they want to, and then allows them to use that data to advocate for policies that will help keep toxic air pollution out of their communities.

GCM, along with the Louisiana Bucket Brigade and Public Lab, is hosting the first ever Community Based Science for Action Conference this November in New Orleans, Louisiana.  This conference will be an opportunity to connect leaders of fenceline communities to each other and the tools needed to be successful.  Community Based Science for Action puts the power of scientific data back in the hands of people.  

The Scholarship

By covering travel expenses, we can ensure that folks on the frontlines of industrial pollution are connected with the tools they need to be successful.

Grassroots community leaders need your help to cover travel costs to join us this November. In New Orleans, they will discover the right monitoring tools and learn how to successfully implement a community based monitoring project in their own communities.

Proven Success

GCM has worked with community members living on the fenceline of industrial pollution since 2001.  By launching the Bucket Brigade, residents are empowered to collect their own data- when & where they want to. This helps to identify toxic hot spots and eliminate gaps among government agencies.

For example, thousands of residents were impacted by the Chevron Refinery Fire in Richmond, California in 2012. The fire occurred outside of regular business hours and the local agencies were not available to collect air samples. Thousands of affected individuals rushed to the nearby hospitals, but without adequate air monitoring, community members could only imagine what they were exposed to.

Residents of Louisiana have enjoyed huge success with their Bucket Brigade.  Margie Richard of the Diamond community of Norco, Louisiana, won the 2004  Goldman Prize, the most prestigious environmental award granted to individuals,  after working for over 20 years to win a fair and just relocation of 300 families living in the toxic shadow of a Shell chemical and refinery complex.

Ms. Richard and the Concerned Citizens of Norco continued to work with GCM, the Delta Chapter of the Sierra Club and others to take air tests over the next year to show high levels of chemicals were drifting from Shell into their community. Eventually a new statewide group, the Louisiana Bucket Brigade, was formed to assist the Concerned Citizens of Norco and other groups in similar air testing efforts.  Read more about it here .

Margie Richard is one of six Goldman Prize winners that have partnered with GCM and launched a Bucket Brigade within their community.

100% of your donation is tax-deductible and will go directly toward the sponsorship of a community member’s attendance.

What We Need & Why We Need It

We need $3,750 to provide full scholarships to five grassroots community leaders who do not have the funds to attend on their own. And if we raise more, we give more!

A full scholarship provides-

  • Travel

  • Lodging

  • Meals

  • Conference registration

If we do not reach our full goal, all funds raised will go towards the scholarship fund to cover as many expenses as possible for community leaders.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate to our IndieGoGo campaign, there are other ways to be part of this exciting event!  You can

  • Share this campaign with community and network

  • Join our newsletter and follow us on social media

  • Donate directly to GCM

Share this campaign with community and network
Join our newsletter and follow us on social media
Donate directly to GCM

story:
Have you ever wondered if the world will ever get off fossil fuel?



Well it's here and Pineapple Tech is determined to get it to the world! Yet, we simply can't do it without your help! In 3-4 month HEAE (Formally Global Energy International) will be on Coast2Coast Am as a guest to present the product with no way to feed the masses! Pineapple Tech is taking on the burden; so time is of the essence, hence a 10 day fund raiser.

Before you make judgment, please understand: THIS IS NOT ABOUT WEALTH… It’s about HEALTH,.. and the air our children breathe on a daily basis. In Ohio and the surrounding States, they continue to drill and Frac in order to get Natural Gas and Oil; yet continue to charge us for Foreign Oil and in the mean while DESTROYING our planet! I know this first hand due to being in the industry for 12 months and having inside information on the danger they bring. I personally designed software

to help cut cost to the drilling/Fracing industry and our team decided money didn’t matter, OUR CHILDREN DO! So, Pineapple Tech went green by pulling our product, costing us millions and believes in HEAE & Mr. Boyle’s dream by refusing to help BIG Energy’s quest to keep you dependent on their service!
We now have purpose We can believe in!


Other companies I've launched:

Some successful, some not so much! Yet, always willing to help others meet their dreams.

We’ve looked at over 300-hydrogen web-sites, unable to find any tested by the US Government EPA or CARB. You wouldn’t buy a vehicle unless it passed the government crash test and other tests, so why on earth help fund a hydrogen system that hasn’t been tested by the government required and authorized testing agencies?!

The California Air Resources Board (CARB) has the most stringent requirements on the entire face of the planet!

California Air Resources Board (CARB) Executive Order (EO): Approved Executive Order! , C.A.R.B. Non adverse Impact , C.A.R.B. On Rd Study

Arnold Schwarzenegger and Jay Leno now have a Hydro system in their personal vehicles! Why not everyone?

This technology has been used by Governments since WWI! It was in the first auto in 1807! It’s been used in Electrical Power Plants for over 100-years! This isn’t a scam; the Space Shuttle used hydrogen to launch into space and other Military engines run on water! Check this out!

High End Alternative Energy (HEAE, formerly known as Global Energy International) & Mr. Arnie Boyle have worked for years to make it safe and efficient for the general public and Pineapple Tech is determined to make the dream come true by putting up distribution centers for the general public with qualified techs to install the system safely.  We wish to streamline the process and in the meanwhile you get: Clean air, less fossil fuel consumption and educating the World. OPEC continues to deceive the population on fossil fuel and now its judgment day! The truth is out and only we can change things by refusing to be lied to any longer by using the technology now available to the public if we can get it to them.

.

    What You Get & What We Need

    • ZERO emissions! Clean air out of your tailpipe.
    • 1/3rd MORE HORSE POWER!
    • Cleaner engine means less vehicle maintenance. Spark plugs and other components last longer.
    • SAVING OUR PLANET from Oil and Gas companies!
    • 30% to 800% fuel efficiency!  The 99 Benz is getting over 160 miles per gallon now and only getting better!
    • Warranty on your vehicle is intact! Manufacturers are not allowed to void their warranty just because aftermarket parts are added.The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) posted the Magnuson-Moss Warranty Act for your protection: Warranty act! Check it out!
    • Efficiency is determined on make and model of the vehicle and driver tendencies


    We need 100k U.S. dollars per distribution center to hire, train, and stock our center to serve the public like a oil change center. We will live on a modest income as a team in order to saturate the world with centers until the work is complete. Your support will help the world breathe clean air. Note: You can no longer order these systems online! HEAE.biz is making reactors only and no longer offer packages! That's where we come in!


    The Impact:

    The average American household spends over 41% of their gross income on energy! That’s like working 5-months, nearly half one’s life just to pay BIG Energy! UK... probably worse!

    Imagine that money returned to us, then being spent back into the economy! Economic BOOM!!! I was in Slough, England 2 years ago and its worse! Petrol IS OUTRAGEOUS! 


      Risks & Challenges:

      For every 100k we can open a U.S. center to help people and want one in every State. However it won't be easy! I'm willing to see it through but capital hinders my quest due to investing all my capital in the D.O.G. pad system that Pineapple Tech pulled for planetary reasons! If most of the capital is raised in the UK/GB we will focus there first or anywhere else for that matter! Yet we need to open at least one center in U.S. Ohio to work out the bugs before opening centers there to ensure our process is sound and the cost is reasonable for consumers. The average car is a 2k U.S. dollar cost and pays for itself in 6 months time. I have faith that we can cut cost by 50% by mass producing the kits that will be installed by professionals. Is it a challenge? YES! Yet, I'm willing! The big question is the world willing to help! That's the biggest question!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

      • PLEASE SHARE! With Environmental groups you are affiliated with!
      • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

general public and Pineapple Tech is determined to make the dream come true by putting up distribution centers for the general public with qualified techs to install the system safely.  We wish to streamline the process and in the meanwhile you get: Clean air, less fossil fuel consumption and educating the World. OPEC
continues to deceive the population on fossil fuel and now its judgment day! The
truth is out and only we can change things by refusing to be lied to any longer
by using the technology now available to the public if we can get it to them.

.
  

What You Get & What We Need
 

ZERO emissions! Clean air
     out of your tailpipe. 
1/3rd MORE
     HORSE POWER! 
Cleaner engine means less
     vehicle maintenance. Spark plugs and other components last longer.

SAVING OUR PLANET
     from Oil and Gas companies!

30% to 800% fuel efficiency!  The 99 Benz is getting over 160 miles per gallon now and only getting better!
Warranty on your vehicle is intact! Manufacturers are not allowed to void their warranty
just because aftermarket parts are added.The Federal Trade Commission (FTC)
posted the Magnuson-Moss
Warranty Act for your protection: Warranty act! Check it out!
Efficiency is
determined on make and model of the vehicle and driver tendencies




We need 100k U.S. dollars per distribution center to hire, train, and stock our center to serve the public like a oil change center. We will live on a modest income as a team in order to saturate the world with centers until the work is complete. Your support will help the world breathe clean air. Note: You can no longer order these systems online! HEAE.biz is making reactors only and no longer offer packages! That's where we come in!
  The Impact:


The average American household
spends over 41% of their gross income on energy! That’s like working 5-months,
nearly half one’s life just to pay BIG Energy! UK... probably worse!
Imagine that money returned to
us, then being spent back into the economy! Economic BOOM!!! I was in Slough, England 2 years ago and its worse! Petrol IS OUTRAGEOUS!  
 
Risks & Challenges: 
For every 100k we can open a U.S. center to help people and want one in every State. However it won't be easy! I'm willing to see it through but capital hinders my quest due to investing all my capital in the D.O.G. pad system that Pineapple Tech pulled for planetary reasons! If most of the capital is raised in the UK/GB we will focus there first or anywhere else for that matter! Yet we need to open at least one center in U.S. Ohio to work out the bugs before opening centers there to ensure our process is sound and the cost is reasonable for consumers. The average car is a 2k U.S. dollar cost and pays for itself in 6 months time. I have faith that we can cut cost by 50% by mass producing the kits that will be installed by professionals. Is it a challenge? YES! Yet, I'm willing! The big question is the world willing to help! That's the biggest question!
  Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: 
PLEASE SHARE! With Environmental groups you are affiliated with! 
 Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
About us

We are a coalition of groups in Nottingham concerned about climate change. We are: Nottingham Friends of the Earth, Nottingham Greenpeace, Women's Environmental Network, Nottingham People's Assembly and others.

The demonstration on March 7th aims to put pressure on political parties before the general election, and raise the profile of climate change. It is also intended to energise and strengthen the climate movement.

We want the government to act on climate change. Not just to do something – to do enough to avoid climate chaos. This means investment not in new fossil fuels but in renewables – massive amounts. It means saving energy by insulating and converting all homes and all public and private buildings, and a shift from cars to public transport. It means a dedicated workforce to create this infrastructure – one million climate jobs. And it means the UK supporting a global agreement to cut warming emissions of all kinds, speedily, with fairness and justice.

By helping us to fundraise a coach to London, you'll help put Nottingham on the map as standing in solidarity calling for climate justice.

What We Need & What You Get

Coach hire will cost around £500. If we get the £500, we will offer people free seats on the coach - people who cannot afford to pay, but who wish to come with us.

By donating towards this campaign, you'll get satisfaction that you are helping to put Nottingham on the map, to give Nottingham a presence at the march, and to help people to get there who couldn't afford to pay.

Any profits we receive from this will go towards the Road to Paris Dec 2015 campaign in Nottingham that we will be continuing once back from the march.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, then please spread the word about our IndieGoGo page to your networks, and also share the event on Facebook so that we can ensure that we can fill the coach.

story:
Short Summary


Life Support Project is comprised of two moms, Cherri Foytlin and Karen Savage, who wish to serve and amplify the voices of environmental justice and front line communities affected by extreme extraction.  Based in Louisiana, we know first-hand the devastating effects extreme extraction industries have on the health of communities and families living in our region.  We have worked to amplify the voices of communities across the Gulf Coast - from fishermen sickened after the BP disaster to a community still suffering from a 5-year old mercaptan spill to a historic community threatened by the transport and refining of tar sands. After spending the past four years helping impacted people along the Gulf Coast to tell their stories, we are embarking on a journey to connect those voices with similar ones across North America.  We will travel to the tar sands of Northern Alberta to refinery communities in California to the coal fields of West Virginia to the uranium mines of North Dakota and New Mexico, connecting, amplifying and serving our communities and our peoples in their epic struggle for clean air, water and land. We will be servants to the causes of these communities in whatever aspect they need while providing media support and outreach through social networking, documentary film and written word.


What We Need & What You Get


Our plan for the summer of 2014 is to continue our work with, and to make connections between, communities across the Gulf Coast, and our "sister" communities in California, Utah, West Virginia, Canada and other places across Turtle Island.  We know how hard individuals and community organizations are working; as well as, how few resources they have. So while we are there, we plan to make ourselves useful - stuffing envelopes, making phone calls, manning a booth at a festival, participating in an action, whatever needs to be done - we're ready to jump in and get to really know folks and the struggle we share.


The total projected budget for the project is $15,000 which will cover travel, much-needed camera and computer equipment, and the ability to make the stories, and voices of the communities we visit, heard around the world.

-  Roughly $4,000 would go to equipment

-  Approximately $7,000 will be used for travel, food, etc.

-  About $1500 is for social media and marketing support

-  The remainder will be used for copying, promotional materials, and support to Gulf Coast and sister communities. 


Ideally, we'll get full funding, which will allow us to complete our project and to release one story every 3 to 4 weeks from July through December 2014.  Of course, however much we raise will be put to good use and we'll tell as many stories as our funding allows (hey...we're both moms, so we can guarantee you we'll be thankful for and will stretch every penny you can give!).



The Impact - Why this Project?


This year marks the 20th anniversary of the historic Environmental Justice Executive Order, which was signed by President Clinton and which directed federal agencies to “identify and address the disproportionately high and adverse human health or environmental effects of their actions on minority and low-income populations” and which required each agency to develop a plan to implement and achieve environmental justice.  


Yet communities suffering environmental injustices continue to be divided geographically, culturally, and purposefully by extreme extraction industries. They continue to suffer disproportionate impacts, often while remaining “invisible” to mainstream media. Their voices and struggles need to be heard.


•  We'll build on stories we've already produced, amplifying those Gulf Coast voices and connecting them to other communities across North America in order to further a robust and unified movement for clean air, water and soil for all and in protection of our Mother Earth.


•  Even if you don't live in a "front line" community, we all share this one planet and an environmental injustice in one community pollutes the same air, water and soil that we need for this and future generations.



Other Ways You Can Help


•  Continue to read and share stories from front line communities

•  Even if you can't contribute, maybe your friends can - be sure to share our campaign!

•  Join in the struggle for climate and environmental justice – please follow and support front line and environmental justice communities working to protect life on our planet.

story:
Short Summary

Ours is a simple solution to a complex problem.

My name is Mike Fernandes. My son Benjamin and I will go anywhere to find places of interest to photograph for our websites www.PhotoChronicles.net and www.SydneyTimeline.com.au . We've seen first hand the devastating results of careless disposal of plastic bottles in parks, historical sites, waterways and even cemeteries.  We were powerless to do anything about it until now.

Our PETLEASH is an easy to use strap to capture and control a number of bottles at one time without taking up carry space.

We are desperate to make PETLEASHES available at very little (or no cost in some cases) to as many people as we can to make a difference as quickly as we can.

With your help we can spread the word and convince authorities that something can be done to cure this plague with very little financial input or effort.

We can even design systems to implement smoother logistics.

Together, if we can achieve even a small percentage reduction in waste, that would equate to millions of plastic bottles out of the race to choke our planet. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our target is to raise $3,000 in this fundraising campaign.

A big part of the money raised we hope will be from pre-sales of our PETLEASHES which we feel is so important because we would love for them to be used as soon as they are produced.

As soon as we raise the first $1,000, that will give us the confidence that you are interested and the product is indeed viable. At this point we will commence producing enough PETLEASHES to send out to our supporters.

For anyone who supports us for amounts of $50 and above we will post out samples of our PETLEASHES to strap onto your back packs or to take to the beach or wherever and we hope for you to spread the word. We're calling these 'pre-purchases' just to sound posh!

We are doing all of this on a shoestring budget and because we're determined to do it, we WILL produce PETLEASH even if we don't reach the target.

We will be truly grateful for your help and we will commit to sending you samples even if we don't reach our goal.

The Impact

PETLEASH will assist in reducing this sickening waste.

If you can help us push a little harder, you can be assured that your help WILL save birds, animals, fish and plant life, will help to clear the cesspools that poor kids have to play in and in the end will help you rest a little easier knowing that the world is a better place for even one less stray P.E.T.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest fear is that we will take PETLEASH to the point to where pre-orders are fulfilled and we have a few stocks on hand and then we run aground when it comes to heavy promotion.

We are hoping that this Indiegogo bid will give us enough friends and contacts that we can bounce ideas off when it comes to approaching governments and authorities from a position of strength.

As an advertising person with over 40 years' experience making other people and businesses successful, I should be cocky and confident with this but I am not.

My biggest challenge is sales, a weakness that I have carried all my life, however, this time I believe with all my being that together we can make a huge difference and I am now prepared to break down any barriers.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, not to worry! Your word out there can have a massive impact. We would love you to take advantage of anything we can provide on our website to assist you with any environmental ventures.

Also, don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And just keep coming back - We've only just started!

story:
Miles of opportunity... 

Take a moment and envision streets filled with money, just laying there waiting for someone to pick it up.  It wouldn't stay there long, would it?!

Now envision streets in Haiti filled with plastic and trash.  Still a form of money just laying on the street, but no one is picking it up. 

5 Facts You Need to Know:

  • Haiti imports 40,000 lbs of plastic per day, most of which ends up on the ground
    • We anticipate being able to recycle 20,000 lbs of plastic per month, cleaning the streets and preventing flooding
  • People crave the dignity of being able to earn a living
    • This center supports 5 full time jobs and hundreds of families that collect plastic
  • Participants who collect and sell recyclable plastic most often better their lives through:
    • Paying for a child’s education
    • Supplementing their family’s diet with protein
  • Any revenue generated from this center gets funneled in to community development projects, keeping the profits locally
  • Once this center is started, it is self-perpetuating and requires no further financial inputs

 Photo source: EWB


Possibilities from Plastic...

The Community Health Initiative, Haiti, (CHI) is a 501 (c)(3) organization that is focused on improving all aspects of health in isolated rural communities in Haiti through providing ongoing healthcare. Every three months teams of medical and non medical volunteers travel to the communities in Haiti that CHI is affiliated with.  CHI coordinates extended term volunteers to oversee the ongoing health care after trips and assist with community development projects.  In addition to treating illness, we aim to address the biological, social, and environmental causes of disease.  

Toward that end, we are starting a plastic recycling center in the city of Arcahaie in 2014. (Insert self high five here!)

We are partnering with Executive without Borders (EWB) in a program that places plastic collection depots in towns around Haiti.  This will essentially turn trash into cash and create possibilities from plastic!  This program cleans up the streets, stops the widespread burning of plastic, and supplements people's income. 

Source: EWB, photo by Ken Cedeno

Haiti is an island the size of Maryland and imports over 40,000 lb of plastic each day, (yes each day) and it all gets thrown on the streets and clogs canals.  This is especially apparent during the annual hurricane season and contributes to the massive mudslides and flooding that kill hundreds nearly every year. 

   Source: EWB, photo by Ken Cedeno

Impact studies that have been conducted by EWB show that the majority of participants use the money earned through recycling plastic to send a child to school or to supplement their children’s diets.  We know that preventing malnutrition and anemia will raise a child’s IQ by 15 points, better equipping them to learn and become productive members of society.  


Turning trash into cash...

After the 2010 earthquake Executives Without Borders identified this as an opportunity to expand income generating opportunities to other locations within the country.  They created Ramase Lajan, which in Creole means ‘picking up money’.  Through this program, small collection centers are placed in communities to take in, clean, and crush the plastic that people collect.  Collectors are paid by the pound for the plastic that they bring to the collection centers.  The plastic is then transported to a central location in Port-au-Prince where it is purchased at a mark-up, chipped, and exported to be made into messenger bags, polar fleece, and a number of other products.

Source: EWB, photo by Ken Cedeno

EWB estimates that 2,000 such collection depots are needed in Haiti to deal with what is already on the ground and the unceasing stream of imported plastic.  Our depot will be number 25.

Half of EWB's existing centers recycle 20,000 lb of plastic per month or more.  By examining the business practices of these centers, they have been able to identify some best practices, such as establishing a central location near the market, encouraging community involvement, and establishing partnerships with other local institutions.  

We work with local schools every month by having our Community Health Worker's visit them to do health education.  We just finished a big soccer tournament for 250 of the local children that drew a crowd of around 2,000 people every night.  We work closely with the local hospital, who has thousands of pill bottles to recycle.  We also work closely with two local resorts that serve all of their sodas in recyclable plastic bottles.  We think that we will be able to leverage all of these connections to bring in a lot of plastic.  In short, we anticipate being able to reach the 20,000 lb per month mark in short order. 

A truck overflowing with plastic! Source: EWB

Furthermore, CHI has just leased a plot of land across the street from the new indoor market that opened in December of 2013 and attracts thousands of people twice per week.  This market brings in people from neighboring villages, who often have to walk up to 12 hours to reach the location!  Setting up shop in this location will allow people to turn in plastic for money, and then walk across the street to buy additional goods or more nutritious food for their families. 

Source: EWB, photo by Ken Cedeno

The cost of opening the recycling center and leasing the land for 2 years is $30,000.  The center is a repurposed shipping container that comes with a plastic crusher, safety gear, uniforms, business training for employees, ongoing support and education for site managers, and a mentorship program that is all included in the start up costs. CHI is leasing premium land for $2,500 per year.  Our total economic input for the program for the first 2 years will be $30,000.   We already secured half of the start up costs ($15,000) in matching funds!

This one-time investment sets a self-sustaining, job-creating, community-cleaning, capacity-building, kid-educating, family-feeding, garbage into goodness machine that will run in perpetuity with no further inputs required.

Source: EWB, photo by Ken Cedeno


Empty bottle = Full belly + Sharp Mind 

As already mentioned, impact studies previously done by EWB show that this program sends more children to school and leads to more complete and nutritious diets for families that participate.  However, we think that we can have a much wider impact.  If the center recycles 20,000 lbs. of plastic per month, if it has just an average performance, it will generate enough money to treat 10 malnourished children per month.  Alternatively, it could provide 4,000 free meals to school children.  School feeding programs improve school enrollment, decrease absenteeism and vastly improve academic performance.  This would essentially turn trash into food and education! 

We hope we can earn a bit of income through this program so that we could use it to start a malnutrition program for the children (25% of whom are underweight) that live in our area.  We also hope to institute a school feeding program that improves school enrollment, decreases absenteeism, and vastly improves academic performance.  This would essentially turn trash into food and education.

   Photo source: CHI, Liz Nerad

The cornerstone of our work is a relationship with the community.  Our clinics are literally based in villages, where people vacate their houses and donate their yards and public areas in order to run our clinics.  The community has been the driving force and a true partner in all of our other projects.  This one is no different.  The community is stoked(!) and we have the support of the mayor, the land-owners, and the judiciary for this project. 

  A welcome CHI sign the village made us on a previous trip. Photo source, CHI

This recycling collection center is a part of our core belief that health is not simply the absence of disease, but rather the ability for an individual to fulfill their innate potential.  This center will not only clean up the environment, prevent flooding from plugged canals, and improve air quality by preventing the burning of trash.  It will enable countless families with an ability to supplement their income and  provide them with the dignity of working to provide for their relatives and children.  It will send hundreds of children to school.  The profits from this program will prevent and treat malnutrition, restoring and preserving children’s intellectual and physical capacity to build a brighter future for their communities.  It will provide meals for children to encourage them to go to school and help them learn once they are there.  It will enable them to learn how to take care of themselves, their families, and their communities. 

 Photo source: CHI, Allie Adam


Trash Talking...

Having an awkward dinner conversation?  Stuck in an elevator with a stranger?  Or simply just spending time with friends or family?  Have an easy conversation starter on us!  By keeping CHI and our recycling program in the back of your mind you are able to help generate buzz about our efforts.  That one random conversation could lead to that one project starting donation that allows this vision to become a reality.

Your voice is just as important as money to us!

Got questions about our organization? We have the answers!  Learn more about who we are, where we work, and what our lives are like by visiting our website and blog at www.chihaiti.org

Facebook fanatic?  Give us the "thumbs up" by liking our Facebook page here and receive the most up to date news on CHI.

Mèsi pou sipò ou! (" Thank you for your support.")  Without supporters in our corner we are unable to make the mission of CHI a reality in our villages.  By simply starting a conversation about CHI or sending a generous donation to our cause, it all means the same and we are so very grateful!  

"There are risks and costs to a program of action... but they are far less than the long-range risks and costs of comfortable inaction."  -JFK

plastic to send a child to school or to supplement their children’s diets.  We know that preventing malnutrition and
anemia will raise a child’s IQ by 15 points, better equipping them to learn and
become productive members of society.  Turning trash into cash...After the
2010 earthquake Executives Without Borders identified this as an
opportunity to expand income generating opportunities to other locations within
the country.  They created Ramase Lajan,
which in Creole means ‘picking up money’. 
Through this program, small collection centers are placed in communities
to take in, clean, and crush the plastic that people collect.  Collectors are paid by the pound for the
plastic that they bring to the collection centers.  The plastic is then transported to a central
location in Port-au-Prince where it is purchased at a mark-up, chipped, and exported to
be made into messenger bags, polar fleece, and a number of other products.Source: EWB, photo by Ken CedenoEWB estimates that 2,000
such collection depots are needed in Haiti to deal with what is already on the
ground and the unceasing stream of imported plastic.  Our depot will be number
25.Half of EWB's existing centers recycle 20,000 lb of plastic per month
or more.  By examining the business practices of these centers, they have
been able to identify some best practices, such as establishing a central
location near the market, encouraging community involvement, and establishing
partnerships with other local institutions.  
We work with local schools every month by
having our Community Health Worker's visit them to do health education.  We just finished a big soccer tournament for
250 of the local children that drew a crowd of around 2,000 people every
night.  We work closely with the local
hospital, who has thousands of pill bottles to recycle.  We also work closely with two local resorts
that serve all of their sodas in recyclable plastic bottles.  We think that we will be able to leverage all
of these connections to bring in a lot of plastic.  In short, we anticipate being able to reach
the 20,000 lb per month mark in short order. A truck overflowing with plastic! Source: EWBFurthermore, CHI has just leased a plot of land across the street from the new indoor market that
opened in December of 2013 and attracts thousands of people twice per
week.  This market brings in people from neighboring
villages, who often have to walk up to 12 hours to reach the location!  Setting up shop in this location will allow people
to turn in plastic for money, and then walk across the street to buy additional
goods or more nutritious food for their families. Source: EWB, photo by Ken Cedeno
The
cost of opening the recycling center and leasing the land for 2 years is $30,000.  The center is a repurposed shipping container that comes with a plastic crusher, safety gear, uniforms, business training for employees, ongoing support and education for site managers, and a mentorship program that is all included in the start up costs. CHI is leasing premium land for $2,500 per year.  Our total economic input for the program for the first 2 years will be $30,000.   We already secured half of the start up costs ($15,000) in matching funds!This one-time investment sets a self-sustaining, job-creating, community-cleaning, capacity-building, kid-educating, family-feeding, garbage into goodness machine that will run in perpetuity with no further inputs required.Source: EWB, photo by Ken CedenoEmpty bottle = Full belly + Sharp Mind 
As already mentioned, impact studies previously
done by EWB show that this program sends more children to school and leads to
more complete and nutritious diets for families that participate.  However, we think that we can have a much
wider impact.  If the center recycles 20,000 lbs. of plastic per month, if it has just an average performance, it will generate enough money to treat 10 malnourished children per month. 
Alternatively, it could provide 4,000 free meals to school
children.  School feeding programs improve school enrollment, decrease absenteeism and vastly improve academic performance.  This would essentially turn trash into food and education! 
We hope we can earn a bit of income through this
program so that we could use it to start a malnutrition program for the children (25%
of whom are underweight) that live in our area.  We also hope to institute
a school feeding program that improves school enrollment, decreases
absenteeism, and vastly improves academic performance.  This would essentially turn trash into food and education.   Photo source: CHI, Liz Nerad
The cornerstone of our work is a relationship
with the community.  Our clinics are
literally based in villages, where people vacate their houses and donate their
yards and public areas in order to run our clinics.  The community has been the driving force and
a true partner in all of our other projects.  This one is no different.  The community is stoked(!) and we have the support of the mayor, the land-owners, and the judiciary for
this project.   A welcome CHI sign the village made us on a previous trip. Photo source, CHI
This recycling collection center is a part of
our core belief that health is not simply the absence of disease, but rather
the ability for an individual to fulfill their innate potential.  This center will not only clean up the
environment, prevent flooding from plugged canals, and improve air quality by
preventing the burning of trash.  It will
enable countless families with an ability to supplement their income and  provide them with the dignity of working to provide for their relatives and children.  It will send hundreds of children to
school.  The profits from this program
will prevent and treat malnutrition, restoring and preserving children’s
intellectual and physical capacity to build a brighter future for their
communities.  It will provide meals for
children to encourage them to go to school and help them learn once they are
there.  It will enable them to learn how
to take care of themselves, their families, and their communities.  Photo source: CHI, Allie Adam
Trash Talking...Having an awkward dinner conversation?  Stuck in an elevator with a stranger?  Or simply just spending time with friends or family?  Have an easy conversation starter on us!  By keeping CHI and our recycling program in the back of your mind you are able to help generate buzz about our efforts.  That one random conversation could lead to that one project starting donation that allows this vision to become a reality.Your voice is just as important as money to us!Got questions about our organization? We have the answers!  Learn more about who we are, where we work, and what our lives are like by visiting our website and blog at www.chihaiti.orgFacebook fanatic?  Give us the "thumbs up" by liking our Facebook page here and receive the most up to date news on CHI.Mèsi pou sipò ou! (" Thank you for your support.")  Without supporters in our corner we are unable to make the mission of CHI a reality in our villages.  By simply starting a conversation about CHI or sending a generous donation to our cause, it all means the same and we are so very grateful!  "There are risks and costs to a program of action... but they are far less than the long-range risks and costs of comfortable inaction."  -JFK

story:
Summary

We need your support to Save the Arctic. The Arctic is our planet’s air conditioning system and has been regulating our climate for millions of years. But the Arctic is now warming faster than anywhere else on Earth and the stability of our climate hangs in the balance. The Elysium Artists for the Arctic project began as an epic expedition to our polar north in August of 2015 to inspire change. Drawing on the experience and passion of 66 team members from 19 different countries, we’re now ready to share the sights, sounds and science captured during the expedition to inspire the conservation of life at the top of the world through art, education and outreach. We need your support in our endeavor to share the splendor and fragility of the Arctic with the general public. Be part of the climate change solution with us.

The Elysium Artists for the Arctic team included the legendary Dr. Sylvia Earle, world-renowned photographers and artists such as David Doubilet, Ernie Brooks, Jennifer Hayes, Michael Aw, Eric Bettens, Leandro Blanco and Wyland. We started this project to show how the condition of the Arctic affects us all, and our ultimate goal is to send a strong message to our policy makers that we demand immediate, tangible action on climate change. Now.

We stand at a pivotal moment in history. Scientifically measurable effects of climate change are being experienced around the world, and many of us are witnessing these changes in our own backyards. Yet rather than using its immense influence to create positive changes in this regard, the new US administration banned the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as well as the Department of Agriculture from using social media to communicate scientific research to the public. Tweets regarding the carbon cycle were deleted off the National Park Service’s Twitter account. It has been rumored that the EPA has been asked to take down its internet page titled, “Climate Change”, and the administration has already requested a list of federal employees and contractors who have worked on different climate initiatives. In a world in which science is under attack and facts may have “alternatives”, it has never been more important or more urgent to mobilize our collective voices and fight for the future of our planet and our children.

“Illustrate it, write about it, photograph it, sketch it, paint it, sculpt it, go back with this body of work and present it to change people’s minds, attitudes and maybe behaviors.” – Jennifer Hayes

What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we will now be able to expand on the success of the Elysium expedition to bring the plight of climate change in the Arctic into the wider public awareness. With the images that have been presented so far as well as the upcoming release of the book and the movie, we are making progress toward getting our message out. You have been instrumental in supporting our cause. But it is not enough. Our real goal is to make a lasting impact on policy and decision makers who can help change the trajectory of the climate disaster that we are currently on.

“What’s happening is that as polar ice is melting away, so is the stability of the planet.” – Dr. Sylvia Earle

Our goal is to raise $20,000 in order to cover the production, venue, printing and advertising costs associated with bringing this project to the attention of the world. All funds collected will be used for this purpose, regardless of whether we reach our target goal amount.

Now in this next stage of the Elysium Arctic project we are making a call for support to help us share our vision far and wide. We are putting the finishing touches on the plans for the Elysium Artists for the Arctic exhibitions that will premiere in New York and Singapore on 23 March and 5 April, 2017 respectively. Through photos, paintings, sculptures, videos and music, these exhibitions will connect with people around the globe, changing their perception of this northern polar region so that they better comprehend the importance of the Arctic and why all of us must do everything in our power to protect it. 

$20 Donation: You will receive a one-year Ocean Geographic E-edition subscription and an invitation to preview the online Exhibition gallery on 20 March.  YES – you will be the first to see the exhibition! You will also be credited as a supporter in the HONOUR ROLL of Elysium Arctic (ElysiumEpic.org).

$50 Donation: You will receive all of the above plus a limited edition pin designed exclusively for the Elysium Arctic expedition. In addition, you will receive a signed souvenir print edition of Ocean Geographic magazine featuring a gallery of work from the premiere exhibition and an in-depth interview with Dr. Sylvia Earle.

$200 Donation: You will receive all of the $50 perks as well as an author-autographed copy of the hand-sewn case-bound limited edition of the Elysium Artists for the Arctic book (valued at $150).

Patron of Exhibition $11,000: You will receive the entire $200 package, ten copies of the author-autographed, hand-sewn, case-bound limited edition Elysium Artists for the Arctic book, plus you will be credited as our patron at the entrance of the exhibition and in all promotional materials. You will also be invited to a private dinner with Dr. Sylvia Earle and will receive a choice of three limited edition prints from the exhibition. Email Elysium@OGSociety.org for more info.

As an added incentive, donate at the $50 or $200 level and you will be entered into a drawing to win a trip to Singapore (round trip airfare) to attend the official launch of the Elysium book and exhibition.

We will pay for your flights to Singapore to attend the official opening of the Elysium Artists for the Arctic exhibition at the Ion Art Gallery and view a special premiere of Elysium Artists for the Arctic at Lido Theatre on 5th April. The Elysium Artists for the Arctic evening will be comprised of screening of documentary footage from the expedition, an Arctic lecture by Michael AW, Howard Shaw and Alex Rose, and an unforgettable keynote presentation by Her Deepness, Dr. Sylvia Earle. OR if you prefer to attend the launch in the USA, we will fly you to New York to attend the Elysium Arctic launch at the Explorers Club Annual Dinner on 25 March. You will receive a special invitation to the prestigious club that has been in existence since 1904. PLUS you will be entered into a raffle to win a free week of diving and accommodations for one at YOS Dive Eco Resort in Lembeh (value at USD$1200). 

We hope you will support us in this endeavor to share the splendor and fragility of the Arctic with the general public. We were privileged to experience the Arctic firsthand during Elysium, but we need your help to show the Arctic to the rest of the world in a way that will inspire its protection and preservation.

Impact

“There is still time, to save what remains. We have an obligation to come back and say, look, this is what I have witnessed…We have to keep the rest of the world engaged, sharing what we know.” – Dr. Sylvia Earle

During our Elysium expedition fundraiser in 2015, we raffled off the last space on the expedition for $50 per ticket in order to raise enough money to make Elysium carbon neutral.  We hit our goal and the $25,000 we raised was used to offset our carbon emissions by investing that money in GreenChar, a for-profit social enterprise in Kenya working to make clean energy accessible to all. They produce and distribute high energy and nearly smokeless charcoal briquettes made from the agricultural waste of sugar cane farms.    

The Elysium project started as a dream among a small group of friends one night in Orlando, Florida. With dedication, passion, hard work and your help, it has grown powerful enough to be a platform for real action influencing policy makers in their decisions regarding the global climate crisis. We are now ready to share this definitive body of work with the world.

Challenges

Our biggest challenge is getting this unique body of work out to the public in a timely manner, where it can be seen by policy and decision makers who are in a position to make a real difference in all of our lives.

Many talented people have done amazing projects to help bring climate change to the forefront of our concerns. What sets the Elysium Epic team apart is that so many accomplished scientists and artists have come together for this one project to share their expertise.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Your voice can make an impact! Tell your friends, tell your family!
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

That's all there is to it! Thank you for your support!

story:
Conserving seeds is about more than just bringing food to the table. It’s about conserving biodiversity, conserving traditional knowledge, and conserving people’s capacity to take their future into their own hands. We call this food sovereignty and it starts with the conservation of native seeds.

In Guatemala, a very small number of giant corporations have been aggressively promoting fast-maturing hybrid seeds. Hybrid seeds are extremely vulnerable because their genetic pool is small and poor, confined to high-production genetic traits. Traditional native seeds naturally have a wide gene pool, which makes them more robust and resilient to disease and varying climactic conditions. Small farmers in Guatemala are especially vulnerable to the impacts of climate change because of their low income, their reliance on agriculture and their geographic location.


Native seed sources are urgently needed. There is no government effort and very little NGO-based efforts to promote native seeds in Guatemala. Because of modern agriculture practices, traditional knowledge regarding the use of native seeds for food production is in the process of disappearing. This has a tremendous impact on family farming communities, where there is limited capacity to seek alternative livelihoods and a high incidence of poverty – 75% in the Sololá department, with an Indigenous population of 96%[1].

The Instituto Mesoamericano de Permacultura - IMAP (Mesoamerican Permaculture Institute) is a Mayan-run, Mayan owned non-profit organization in San Lucas Tolimán, Guatemala, that has spent the last 12 years empowering Indigenous farmers to combat poverty and malnutrition through permaculture education and by offering training to small farmers on ways to produce and conserve traditional native seeds.

If you don’t know about IMAP, you can check out our website.

The Indiegogo site is linked directly to our PayPal account, and all funds will go directly to us. The goal is to reach $10,000 in order to:

1)    promote and give out native seeds
2)    offer workshops to farmers on seed conservation and
3)    build a community seed bank where farmers can receive and exchange native seeds.

Here’s where your money goes:

  • $5 will give 1 farmer a package of native seeds
  • $10 will cover a 1-day workshop for a farmer on seed conservation
  • $25 will cover a 3-day workshop for a farmer on community seed bank management
  • $100 will help establish a community seed bank

In addition to this Indiegogo fundraising effort, IMAP has launched its Seed Guardian Campaign at the local and national levels in order to encourage farmers to preserve native seeds. More details about the Seed Guardian Campaign can be found here.


[1] Panamerican Health Organization, Guatemala – Health in the Americas 2007, Volume II

story:
Adele Traditional Area - Nkwanta, Ghana  - Rural Development

Community Environmental Education & Eco farming in Ghana!

Please Join the Ghana Nkwanta Project in our Rural Development Eco-farming Community environmental Education Initiative in Ghana!

The Ghana Nkwanta Project is working towards building sustainable villages in the Nkwanta ‘Upper Volta’ region of Ghana by promoting practical activities for sustainable eco farming using best practices, knowledge sharing with a deep respect for traditional knowledge, and the environment. We will be adding a community environmental education program in partnership with the Permaculture Institute in Techiman, Ghana, which will be expanding on our existing organic home gardening project which was started in 2009.

Mission - to raise funds to strengthen existing Permaculture projects (Agroecology/Eco-farming) and development of environmental governance in Adele traditional communities in Nkwanta, Ghana 'Upper Volta' region.

Our goal is to continue to inspire project development towards environmental awareness and development by providing community environmental educational workshops in the Upper Volta Region of Ghana.

 
 
 Boost agroecological farming to feed world and save the climate - UN expert

UN News Centre

22 June 2010 – "Agroecological farming, which improves food production and farmers’ incomes while at the same time protecting the soil, water and climate, could feed an estimated world population of nine billion people by 2050 and go a long way to save the climate, if implemented now, experts at a United Nations seminar concluded today."

By contributing to the Ghana Nkwanta Project's Ecofarming project in Ghana, you will be participating in Agroecological farming, climate change,helping to preserve the environment and increasing food supply in a sustainable way.

 "In good times and bad, we know that people give because you meet needs, or because you have needs." -Kay Sprinkel Grace

Get involved in building Sustainable Agriculture in Ghana! The world is global! We must be globally involved!

 

If you are uncomfortable making payments online, you can make a payment the traditional way by mailing a check to:

Linda Fletcher

P.O.Box  6283

Bronx, NY 10451

Thanks so much.

 

Sincerely,

 

Linda Fletcher

Project Outreach Director
