story:
Ekobius International Ecovillage Crowdfunding Project Phase I

Let's celebrate Ecovillage Day in the Amazon!

Amazon, Medicinal Plants, Superfoods, Technology, Sustainability

Let's meet at the crossroads on Earth Day, to build our futures now.

Please join Ecology Crossroads for our 20th anniversary and founders reunion to begin a capital development campaign to re-establish our non-profit organization with a revised international mission and a special focus project with a new ecovillage charter we are initiating that serves as a ecological community development demonstration model (way down here) in the Northern Amazon this Earth Day, which we and the Global Ecovillage Network (GEN-International) are also calling Ecovillage Day!

The Indiegogo (Ecovillage Day) goal is to open our Amazonian ecovillage by Earth Day, April 22 to friends, ecotourists, students and volunteers who like camping and to accommodate other arriving member residents to begin our first production cooperative development of sustainable products for delivery by August to our funders and supporters here. Friends, new members and social network supporters can help too by donating as little as 3, 9 or 27€ to plant trees in our food forest development and reforestation efforts in and near the Ekobius village.

Donors also get to download great eBooks from our membership reference library to enhance their education about the environment, our ecology and sustainability.

Our ecovillage is connected through a number of Internet based network partnerships through our premier social media partner Globcal International and we can also be found also on Indiegogo, Idealist, Taking IT Global, Pando, Ecobasa.org, GreenMap, HelpX, Causes, FIC (Fellowship for Intentional Communities) and with WWOOF (World-Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms).

We are also offering our supporters our first line of cooperative products produced and harvested in our ecovillage this season. The products we are producing include indigenous art from our neighbor cooperators, herbs and medicinal plants collected locally, medicinal preparations made by shaman, superfoods, coffee, and even chocolates. Do you like chocolate? (Check the products out below)

We will add new products like herbal sacraments, aromatics, plant seeds, tree bark and some hand crafted wood products that are unique and limited during the Indiegogo campaign. To learn more check back for updates frequently and follow the social media.


You can also participate first hand by visiting us in the Amazon as a collaborating visitor, sponsor, maybe as a volunteer; you can also help us online through Facebook, Google+, LinkedIn, YouTube, Twitter and on Pinterest. Our project is just beginning and the world is changing, change with us! Join us in our real-life adventures and creative reality here at the ecovillage.

Our Indiegogo mission and goals.

Initially we considered developing many small projects on Indiegogo because of the complexity and scale of our project. Individual members wanted to create individual projects, however we tempered their enthusiasm to do the project collectively, accountably, and with public transparency. We consider our efforts a great social responsibility. Help us to create a such a village that is completely self-sufficient or what we call eco-indie'pendent.

Our project is involved in the development of special crowdfunding integrity development method called e³, its a method and formula under development by Globcal which requires our project to be executed over a 9-12 month period in three orderly phases, each phase shall realize 9 objectives. The system is highly accountable and based on the ideal model of a computer registry or Rubik's cube which is based on a 3x3x3 and has 27 elements.

Based on our success with the initial phase (Phase I) and our cooperative membership development drive, Globcal International will become involved during the second phase (Phase II) with the installation a community school and opportunity center to integrate and capacitate our village to become sustainable socioeconomically through their team of Goodwill Ambassadors.

Phase I - will make the ecovillage functional to accommodate volunteers and guests involved in the initial construction and foundation of the cooperative. Kitchen, campsites, restrooms, septic, internet, restore orange and pineapple grove, and establish initial cooperative production equipment to make our indie stuff and become self-sufficient. Our first phase will result in a completely functional (almost modern) outpost and camping facility with 12 full-time residents (or more) and accommodations for up to 24 campers.

Phase II will be focused on the continued development of our tourism plan and campground. Through the help of Globcal it will also begin the establishment of an open-community school and interactive community center for the presentation of workshops and to accommodate community interaction focusing on sustainable living and socioeconomic solvency of the extended regional community through its members.

Phase III will be the finishing phase to carry out our dream ideals where we will realize our goals and objectives in one form or another. Its here we plan to garner adequate support based on the developed contacts to take our project to its speculative development. We expect this final phase to change significantly or at least be modified based on the people dynamics of the forming community.

David, Earth Day, Ecovillage Day, and the Eco-Pioneers

I am David Wright, American expat living in Venezuela's Amazon, I am here teaching agroecology and Fair-Wild certification to the indigenous people who are my neighbors, playing a little soccer too; while they are teaching me about indigenous "tec'knowledge," I am also involved in building an ecovillage with an international cooperative I helped create, and I am here demonstrating to others online through the social media how to live sustainably and what it means to be an Indien!

I am arriving in the Amazon on March 03 with likeminded friends to meet up with the ecovillage pioneers to tackle and begin the development of great works in agroecology, permaculture and protection of the natural environment. Our goal is to sustain public-benefit ecosystem services for our own impressive local ecology, and for everyone else in the world who wants to breathe clean air and drink fresh water that we generate here in our forests.

This is not the first time I have had the opportunity to promote Earth Day, Arbor Day, work with delicate habitats and ecosystems, or organize environmental events; it is the first time though that I have been involved in building an ecovillage and it's my first time on Indiegogo.

I am very fortunate that the timing of our event came together so well this year with Earth Day, the subject of the environment, ecovillages, and coincidentally with my personal itineraries to give me the ability to personally facilitate the remarkable development we are embarking upon now. I am giving it my all, combining all my skills and sharing 40 years of experience with Earth Day and Arbor Day.

"Get involved with David, you're gonna love his Earth Day (Ecovillage Day) project on Facebook and the initial steps he is taking to begin. His organizational plan is engaged with Globcal International too and it follows the new e³ integrity method!" -Zen Benefiel, Ecology Crossroads

Worldwide this year there is a renewed interest and new focus on sustainable ecological community development, the concept of the ecovillage is now a top-priority development for organizations and governments working toward the United Nations Millennium Development Goals (MDG)s, we have all learned over the past few years that the ecovillage is the most practical solution for ecologically sustainable human settlements.

Earth Day (Ecovillage Day 2014)

According to the Global Ecovillage Network where our project is connected, and according to the Earth Day Network, the date for Ecovillage Day is now annually held on Earth Day on April 22nd, so please mark your calendar!

Show your solidarity to our cause and ideals through Earth Day here online! At our ecovillage in the Amazon we will be working for six days during our event planting trees and holding workshops; our event will run the entire week from Activist Day on Sunday, April 20th until Arbor Day on Friday, April 25th. We will pause during the week-long activity for one hour of meditation worldwide on Earth Day at 9:00 am according to the clock in Rio de Janeiro, 12 am in Dakar, 2 pm Berlin, 4 pm in Moscow, and 9 pm in Tokyo. On the 26th we are having a picnic for all the program participants and nieghbors!

Please join us for it being coordinated and promoted on Facebook and through other social media. Earth Day (Ecovillage Day) Event.

We are on Indiegogo to be Indie!

Here is the Indiegogo part! We are promoting and developing 3 projects in one (cooperative, community, commerce) and must present and develop the big project in three phases that attain 9 objectives each, relative to the development of a sustainable ecovillage. Also each phase must guarantee the commencement of the next phase. Sounds easy enough, right?

We are attempting to make the project accessible as an independent event and present opportunity publicly through Indiegogo for others to use as an example to help other communities in formation and to attract a diverse group of supporters and participants for our own project.

To be an Indie for us, means to be "independent and unique," think out of the box," or at least differently than the mainstream people. This was not easy for us because there are so many mainstreamers that have told us no, but despite the odds, we did it! We beat the odds, thought out of the box, and are becoming Indies!!!

It was not easy becoming an Indie, in many ways for others it is just a mindset but for me it has become a way of life. Different is GOOD! I have been doing things differently since I started marched on Earth Day in 1970 and it has all led me here.

Our cooperative and Indie product line.

To promote our project on Indiegogo we wanted to become real "indies" first, so we had to create something uniquely independent that could not be easily duplicated, that which makes us independent; for us independence also means self-reliance, being unique, different and even self-determinant.

Our cooperative will produce and offer special unique fair-trade products from the Amazon made by indigenous people (cooperative members) within our community. Herbs, spices, medicines, teas, chocolate, candy, fruit preserves and superfoods collected exclusively in the unexplored Guiana Highlands, Upper Orinoco and Amazon river basins. All funds go directly to the general community and the cooperative members.

First production of our community cottage-industry products.

Our Indiegogo crowdfunding project will help us (the ecovillage residents) cultivate, produce, distribute and market herbs, medicinal plants and preparations that promote well-being made by shaman and native healers from the Amazon. Their tradition combined with the modern knowledge of the natural sciences, permaculture and organic horticulture through the members of the Ekōbius International Cooperative is creating a special niche for exclusive limited high quality natural health and wellness products.

You can participate in our project through crowdfunding to support our cause and effort to build a model ecological village and cooperative socioeconomic community by purchasing our first premium homemade (artesanal) products that we are producing this Spring through the Summer at "Fundo Ekōbius" with our cooperative members.

Sustainable superfruit (food) crops like cupuazu, acai, merecure, moringa and other fantastic medicinal foods and other plants that are used locally as cures for a range of diseases and ailments, which due to lack of information about curing techniques and preservation methods few have been offered more than locally, until now through our project.

Through the introduction of new ideas, simple technology and country knowledge we are capacitating our entire village and enriching the lives of the neighbors living in our community. The products being developed based on the sustainable collection, harvest and local barter of fruits, seeds, plants, spices and herbs from all over the Amazon is going to be successful in helping to alleviate poverty.

We are building an ecovillage too!

Our project has been in the planning stage for the past five years. Now, finally in 2014, we are moving forward to put together our whole earth team together again of innovators, activists, and now indies; we began adding new members too, and its getting impressive.

We are combining eCooperators and Eco-Pioneers some of us are old heads like me, David Wright and lifetime friends like Michael Gallagher and Javier Vazquez, while others participating here are new teammates helping out (joined Ecology Crossroads or Ekobius) to fulfill the dream of a sustainable ecological planet. Our business model involves cooperation, local agribusiness, non-wood forest products, agroecology, conservation stewardship, and ecological tourism.

Now Zen Benefiel, Michael Sher, and Karen Cantrell, goodwill ambassadors who work with David through Globcal International and his fellow Kentucky Colonels have become involved in the Ecology Crossroads anniversary and the Earth Day (Ecovillage Day) event on Facebook. Davis said he was also pleased his first son Col. Nicholas Wright, an eco-nanoscience PhD candidate at Vanderbilt, his daughter Maya-Lis, also an eco-science student, and new friend Tony Ly, a fellow resident from Ekobius all taking up roles as officers and trustees at Ecology Crossroads. All of the paperwork is being prepared now to officially re-state our articles and bylaws on the week of April 22, 2014, in Frankfort, Kentucky.

If you are the rugged type and have skills to offer, or just want a vacation come join our eco-crew of green cooperators and pioneers we may change your perspective on life. Many new participants are arriving here simply seeking a natural life free of mainstream belief systems so they can return to nature; others are young folks on a journey down the path to enlightenment.

You can come in person or join us online, we are just getting started, we already have 9 residents including the dog; there are others arriving soon from Ireland, Sweden, Holland, Denmark, Colorado, and Kentucky. Now on March 03, David will be arriving with Tony Ly one of the project co-founders and they will get started with preliminary construction and foundational work.

Enjoy! Gaia, sacred shamanic journeys, extreme biodiversity, 3 day nature walks, abundant fresh water, long canoe trips, superfruits, and deep ecology as an ecoplaneteer with our indigenous neighbors and the deep nature of the moist forests of the Guiana highlands.

Come to Fundo Ekobius

Come join us at our developing ecovillage. We have plans to make our ecological village one of the best known models for self sufficiency and permaculture design in the world. Our focus is on nature itself with design and development energy being focused on the establishment of a botanical garden, an experimental ecological station, and a natural history center. Permaculture and self sufficiency are also top-priority for the community and through the botanical aspect there will also be a significant focus on the establishment of food forests (agroecological enriched forest plots).

Support the project by becoming a supporting member, becoming a consumer of our coop products, purchasing a cooperative timeshare which allows you to visit annually for 2-4 weeks, come as a volunteer, our apply to come on an independent internship, or you can move in as a full-time cooperative member and resident if you think you can get along with the rest of the crew and residents.

Phase I (March 03 - April 30, 2014)

Our 'Phase I' development will focus on improving accommodations for members, guests and volunteers that are arriving. Right now during the dry season accommodations are limited to primitive camping, a community kitchen with no stove or sink, and a main lodge that will be used for tools, office and as a social hall for meetings during the initial construction phase. Later (in May or June) once a new caney is built, the main lodge will be converted into to a bed and breakfast that accommodates 8 people.

We developed our project in such a way that it reaches completion at every level, the projects focused will each be completed objectively and methodically so projects are not left undone during development and all the residents are well accommodated.

We are raising 27,000 Euro to purchase and install a commercial stove and oven, a kitchen sink, install a VSAT for Internet access, make kitchen cabinets, build restrooms, a bath house, rebuild the big caney 40ft x 80ft, upgrade and recondition the lodge, top prune 40 giant mango trees, build a maintenance shop and storage building, purchase tools and other necessary equipment.

There will be special emphasis on the kitchen area because it will be used to process raw materials into homemade culinary and medicinal products. It is here that we will make our special chocolate, roast Amazonian wild coffee, macerate prepared elixir concoctions, and make preserves from the rare superfruits that we have around us.

Most of the work performed already is relative to grounds maintenance, surveying, clearing brush, planting trees, installing irrigation lines, and we began to design an ecological landscape. The priority now is to be sure that all our arriving guests are well accommodated, our project is rich in practical application, there is constant activity and learning opportunities, and that it is designed in a way that is totally sustainable.

We may even install a small pond for convenient water access and to satisfy our agricultural needs, its also gives birds a place to drink and toads a place to reproduce resulting in lots of little bug catchers running around in the garden.

It is a village, while 27,000 Euro is not very much during the initial phase, it is enough to make the site more habitable and hospitable for travelers and visitors, so we can have the soup on when folks arrive. The overall project with all of the fantasy and magic our members would like to implement to make the site completely self-sustaining and productive for ourselves and the greater community is currently projected at 303,489.00 € and it includes a low-voltage solar electric system, grounds lighting, extensive underground cabling and waterlines, 27 campsites, 27 cabins, a 5 acre lake, aquaponics, green houses, protected plantings, and a number of projects like plant and food dehydration building and a processing center for the small scale industrialization of our products by residents.

The ecovillage center when complete will include 50 cooperative jobs and provide for over 60 families living in and around Ekobius. We have lots of work to do!

We will be here at least once every two weeks with a good and thorough update of progress, plans, accomplishments, nuances, and modifications to or campaign followers well informed as stated below.

Phase II and Phase III

Phases 2 and 3 of our project are entirely independent crowdfunding campaigns, that must be carried out within the course of 9 months to one year after the first phase to remain qualified and enrolled in the Globcal International e³ Crowdfunding Method. Their current plans are to incorporate the development of a school for our local community to facilitate a new joint project ideal for ecovillage residents and for tourists to have a cultural exchange center at or nearby the ecovillage.

The sequential project phases and their place in the overall project are discussed in round about terms, as proposed plans and ideal initiatives that are being discussed or are under development, those speculative and dreamy ecovillage details can be found in our website and on our blog.

Additional informational will also be posted and updated to here very soon, and you may also notice updates to some of the places we are listed while we were nesting our ideals. Meanwhile you can follow the objective and current reality here on INDIEGOGO and through the social media for the most up to date information, or contact us directly!

Find our project listed (updates coming) on the following social media and Internet networks: Indiegogo, Idealist, Ecobasa.org, GreenMap, HelpX, FIC (Fellowship for Intentional Communities), WWOOF (World-Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms)

New networks we are projecting with: Causes, Sustainable Cities Collective, Pando, Taking IT Global

Find us too on the popular social media: Facebook, Google+, Pinterest, LinkedIn, YouTube, and Twitter.

Updates and contact information.

Watch our project for regular bi-weekly updates! We are 20 miles away from the internet, we visit the town of Puerto Ayacucho once a week and will focus on the responsibility of providing our project supporters and all other members regular updates in the social media, here on this campaign and by email. If you are not donating can add yourself too to our email list for updates too by sending an email to subscribe@ekobius.org

Initial Status Update Week 1: March 03, 2014 - March 10, 2014 - Juan Stirling arrived in Puerto Ayacucho and Fundo Ekobius with 3 volunteers on the 28th of February. David Wright, Hugo Sousa, Tony Ly, and the American Dingo left Caracas, Venezuela late in the afternoon of March 05 (2 days late) after initiating (launching) this crowdfunding project, David will post an update in the next 5-7 days. Check back again soon and watch our social connections for interactive members and our new developments.

ekōbius

See us on the map in the jungle on Wikimapia

Street Address: Via Gavilan Kilometro 24
Region & Postal Code: Municipio Atures 7101
Locality or State: Estado Amazonas
Country: Republica Bolivariana de Venezuela 

Tel:(+58)(212)5160361

E-mail: info(at)ekobius.org

Cooperative Members: David Wright, Tony Ly, Isaac Curtis, Hugo Sousa, Nicholas Wright, Sonia Ceballos, Maya-Lís Wright, Darwin Duarte, Pedro Camacho, Jose Calderon, Joe Saenz, Pat Craig, Juan Cruz Stirling, Milorad Stancevic, and Julio Gonzalez.

Amazon, Medicinal Plants, Superfoods, Technology, Sustainability
Let's meet at the crossroads on Earth Day, to build our futures now.

Phase I (March 03 - April 30, 2014) 
Our 'Phase I' development will focus on improving accommodations for members, guests and volunteers that are arriving. Right now during the dry season accommodations are limited to primitive camping, a community kitchen with no stove or sink, and a main lodge that will be used for tools, office and as a social hall for meetings during the initial construction phase. Later (in May or June) once a new caney is built, the main lodge will be converted into to a bed and breakfast that accommodates 8 people.
We developed our project in such a way that it reaches completion at every level, the projects focused will each be completed objectively and methodically so projects are not left undone during development and all the residents are well accommodated.
We are raising 27,000 Euro to purchase and install a commercial stove and oven, a kitchen sink, install a VSAT for Internet access, make kitchen cabinets, build restrooms, a bath house, rebuild the big caney 40ft x 80ft, upgrade and recondition the lodge, top prune 40 giant mango trees, build a maintenance shop and storage building, purchase tools and other necessary equipment. 
There will be special emphasis on the kitchen area because it will be used to process raw materials into homemade culinary and medicinal products. It is here that we will make our special chocolate, roast Amazonian wild coffee, macerate prepared elixir 
concoctions, and make preserves from the rare superfruits that we have around us.
Most of the work performed already is relative to grounds maintenance, surveying, clearing brush, planting trees, installing irrigation lines, and we began to design an ecological landscape. The priority now is to be sure that all our arriving guests are well accommodated, our project is rich in practical application, there is constant activity and learning opportunities, and that it is designed in a way that is totally sustainable.
We may even install a small pond for convenient water access and to satisfy our agricultural needs, its also gives birds a place to 
drink and toads a place to reproduce resulting in lots of little bug catchers running around in the garden.
It is a village, while 27,000 Euro is not very much during the initial phase, it is enough to make the site more habitable and hospitable for travelers and visitors, so we can have the soup on when folks arrive. The overall project with all of the fantasy and magic our members would like to implement to make the site completely self-sustaining and productive for ourselves and the greater community is currently projected at 303,489.00 € and it includes a low-voltage solar electric system, grounds lighting, extensive underground cabling and waterlines, 27 campsites, 27 cabins, a 5 acre lake, aquaponics, green houses, protected plantings, and a number of projects like plant and food dehydration building and a processing center for the small scale industrialization of our 
products by residents. 
The ecovillage center when complete will include 50 cooperative jobs and provide for over 60 families living in and around Ekobius. We have lots of work to do!
We will be here at least once every two weeks with a good and thorough update of progress, plans, accomplishments, nuances, and modifications to or campaign followers well informed as stated below.
Phase II and Phase III
Phases 2 and 3 of our project are entirely independent crowdfunding campaigns, that must be carried out within the course of 9 months to one year after the first phase to remain qualified and enrolled in the Globcal International e³ Crowdfunding Method. Their current plans are to incorporate the development of a school for our local community to facilitate a 
new joint project ideal for ecovillage residents and for tourists to have a cultural exchange center at or nearby the ecovillage.
The sequential project phases and their place in the overall project are discussed in round about terms, as proposed plans and ideal initiatives that are being discussed or are under development, those speculative and dreamy ecovillage details can be found in our website and on our blog.
Additional informational will also be posted and updated to here very soon, and you may also notice updates to some of the places we are listed while we were nesting our ideals. Meanwhile you can follow the objective and current reality here on INDIEGOGO and through the social media for the most up to date information, or contact us directly!
Find our project listed (updates coming) on the following social media and Internet networks:
Indiegogo,
Idealist,
Ecobasa.org,
GreenMap,
HelpX,
FIC (Fellowship for Intentional Communities),
WWOOF (World-Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms)


New networks we are projecting with:
Causes,
Sustainable Cities Collective,
Pando,
Taking IT Global
Find us too on the popular social media: Facebook, 
Google+,
Pinterest, 
LinkedIn,
YouTube, 
and Twitter.
Updates and contact information.
Watch our project for regular bi-weekly updates! We are 20 miles away from the internet, we visit the town of Puerto Ayacucho once a week and will focus on the responsibility of providing our project supporters and all other members regular updates in the social media, here on this campaign and by email. If you are not donating can add yourself too to our email list for updates too by sending an email to subscribe@ekobius.orgInitial Status Update Week 1: March 03, 2014 - March 10, 2014 - Juan Stirling arrived in Puerto Ayacucho and Fundo Ekobius with 3 volunteers on the 28th of February. David Wright, Hugo Sousa, Tony Ly, and the 
American Dingo left Caracas, Venezuela late in the afternoon of March 05 (2 days late) after initiating (launching) this crowdfunding project, David will post an update in the next 5-7 days. Check back again soon and watch our social connections for interactive members and our new developments.
ekōbius
See us on the map in the jungle on

story: My appeal against ParkingEye's unlawful parking charges in the Court of Appeal was dismissed. The Judges made new laws to dismiss the appeal, saying that the £85 charges are not a penalty. The House of Lords test for what is a penalty is clear; is it a deterrent? Then it's a penalty. I have been given leave to appeal to Supreme Court but need to raise funds to begin the campaign, Together we can beat these unscrupulous companies and change the private parking industry - for ever!

story:
Malta is a small island in the middle of the Mediterranean Sea. It is the natural place for birds to rest as they make their long migrations between Europe and Africa. These birds are an easy target for the 10,000 bird hunters that occupy the countryside of Malta and each year countless birds are shot out of the sky. 

Some birds are simply exhausted from their journey and they need a safe place to rest and refuel before being released. However, here at BirdLife Malta, we do receive about 100 injured birds every year, anything from swifts to flamingos. These birds suffering gunshot injuries are often found lying in agony, some unable to fly or even walk. When they are brought to us, they are taken to a veterinary surgeon who decides what should happen to them.

A number of these birds have injuries from which they can recover and could eventually be released back into the wild. However for these birds, this means a long journey to Sicily to a rehabilitation centre in the north of the island. This is a highly stressful journey for the birds, in cramped conditions, and can greatly reduce their chances of recovery.

Our Campaign

BirdLife Malta has been given the opportunity to set up a rehabilitation centre here in Malta. The government have offered a restored farmhouse in Buskett Gardens, a protected area of woodland in the south of Malta. One of the greenest areas on the islands, the gardens provide a quiet and peaceful setting for the birds to recover in. 

The Maltese government will be covering the costs of running the centre, which will include the water and electricity to supply the farmhouse. But BirdLife Malta will have to cover all other costs. This includes funding equipment, food and medicine to treat the birds.

Contributions to this campaign will ensure we can get this centre up and running before the next migration season.

What We Need & What You Get:

We need to raise 28,000 euros. This is the total we estimate it will cost us to cover all the set-up and running costs for the first year.

€1,000 would pay for one injured Marsh Harrier’s stay at the centre

€400 would buy a bird house for an injured Black-winged Stilt

€100 would buy a heating unit to keep a Honey Buzzard warm

€25 would pay for perches for a Scops Owl.

€10 would feed a recovering Swift for one month

Even just getting part way to reaching our target will make a huge difference to our ability to help rehabilitate injured birds. The more money we raise, the more birds we’ll be able to put back in the sky.

FAQs

What are the chances of birds being rehabilitated and released in Malta surviving?

Currently BirdLife Malta transports birds for rehabilitation to a centre in Sicily.  This is very stressful for the birds and reduces their chances of survival.  It is therefore better to rehabilitate birds in Malta to increase their chances of survival.  Birds will be released outside of the hunting season in a safe area, including on the island of Comino which is a bird sanctuary where hunting is not permitted.

How is the government involved in bird rehabilitation?

The government is working with BirdLife Malta to improve bird rehabilitation facilities in Malta.  The government vet responsible for bird rehabilitation is likely to be based at the rehabilitation centre and the centre will specialise in treating and preparing those birds that can be released back in to the wild. We are also working with the government to improve how birds are transported and treated when they are first found to increase the number that can be rehabilitated.

How many more injured birds will be released compared to those that are released at present?

BirdLife Malta and the government regularly release birds with minor injuries once they have had time to recover.  However, many birds of prey and other species have such serious injuries that they cannot be released and have to be euphanised.  A fully functional rehabilitation centre will ensure that many more of these birds can receive longer term treatment so that they can recover and also be released back in to the wild.

The Impact

There is a great need for a well-equipped rehabilitation centre in Malta, to allow these birds rest and recovery in the hands of professionals. This rehabilitation centre has the potential to ensure rare birds such as the Montagu’s Harrier, can make it back to the UK countryside. By giving a bird back its ability to fly, we will be able to give them back their life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation, please help spread the word about our campaign. Share this page and our video through Facebook and Twitter, and please ask your friends and family to share and donate to our campaign if they can. #SecondChance

story:
Environmental and Social Justice On Wheels

This May I will embark on a 1500 km bicycle alongside 12 other volunteers over two months to inspire youth to become involved in environmental and social justice issues.  I am offered the invaluable opportunity by Otesha, a non-profit organization (http://www.otesha.ca), to go on my first bike tour along BC's West Coast. On the tour, my team will visit numerous schools and communities and spark dialogue among students about sustainable living and creating positive social and environmental change in the world.

This trip will also widen my perspective on the meaning of sustainable living. I hope that after the trip, I can take away values and ideas that I can apply to my own community.

Watch this inspirational video to get a better sense of how the Otesha Project works. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cEjGz-Rr-_o&feature=youtu.be

And here is the page with details on the tour that I will be attending this summer.

http://reasonstodream.otesha.ca/british-columbia-cycling-tour-2015/ 


What We Need & What You Get

As my contribution to the project as a volunteer, my goal is to raise is $2500 by the end of this month. Since Otesha is a non-profit organization, donations are crucial to the success of the program. The money will go towards paying for food, shelter, and other travel expenses of 13 nomadic cycling super-sustainable performers on their 2 month long trek.

In return I will send you:

a) thank-you emails expressing my gratitude and updates on the project's progress

b) postcards, videos, the Otesha Book, and photos from milestones along my trip


The Impact

The Performing and Cycling Tour will visit 25 communities and influence at least 3500 students through performances and workshops. Although our trip lasts only 2 month, the messages we send out to students will inspire the next generation to make sustainable choices in the long-run.  

I would greatly appreciate it if you could share this campaign! For any further questions, please contact me by commenting below or by email.

Thank you!

Daphne

story:
Hudson Rising: Stories of Revival from the Hudson Valley

We're trying to complete our movie about the Hudson Valley - and we need your help to do it! 

After three years, production of Hudson Rising is nearly complete and the premiere is scheduled for October 26th 2013! Hudson Rising is a collection of stories celebrating citizens who are making a difference in the Valley: kids rebuilding downtowns, farmers reinventing farming, the scientist who dreamed that the Hudson Valley could become the next Silicon Valley, and many more.

When the movie's complete, it will be screened on WMHT and other PBS stations and at over 50 venues up and down the Hudson Valley. We believe seeing these stories in the movie will change the way citizens see the future of the Hudson Valley – inspiring them to join the very real revival that is already underway and make it stick.

But we need your help. Despite all the enormous support we have from our partner groups in the Valley, this is a low-budget project that has gotten this far through some modest grants and the generosity of a few donors. We still need to raise $20,000 to pay for the final post-production costs, including licensing archival footage and sound editing and mixing. Please help us get to the finish line and make a difference in the Hudson Valley!

All contributions towards the movie  are tax-deductible donations to the Hudson River Foundation.

Background

In 2009, New York celebrated the four hundredth anniversary of Henry Hudson’s voyage up the Hudson River. There were parades, fireworks, historic boats and much more. But mostly people didn’t want to focus on the Hudson Valley’s past. They wanted to talk about its future.

The citizens of the Hudson Valley feel a renaissance is under way in the valley – but it is incomplete. Hudson and Beacon are reviving, but other urban areas have been left behind, and too many kids are stuck in neighborhoods without access to Valley's nature or prospects for a good job. A new food movement is sweeping the region – but we’re losing farms every day. Appreciation for the Valley’s landscape and River is growing – but the Valley is threatened by suburban sprawl and the river’s shad and sturgeon have been in decline. How can we address these challenges and make the Valley’s renaissance complete?

A group of activists led by Chair of the Hudson Quadricentenial Commission Joan Davidson came together to establish a new coalition, OurHudson, to keep the conversation going. OurHudson convened task forces of experts to come up with recommendations. Then we restored a historic barge and towed it from city to city, where citizens came aboard and discussed reviving farms and bringing back the Valley’s urban areas. It was clear that the conversation needed to be expanded further.

So we decided to commission a film. Hudson Rising is nearly complete, the premiere is scheduled, over 50 venues and WMHT have agreed to screen the movie - but we need your help!

Who we are

OurHudson was organized by former Chair of the Hudson Fulton Champlain Quadricentenial Commission  Joan Davidson, assisted by former Municipal Art Society president Kent Barwick, former NYS Deputy Secretary of State Bob Elliott and Hudson River Foundation Executive Director Clay Hiles. OurHudson would like to thank the Hudson River Foundation for its guidance, support and administration.

Hudson Rising: Stories of Revival from the Hudson Valley  is being directed and produced by Jasper Goldman and Liz McEnaney, edited by Cameron Clendaniel and has been photographed by Jon Miller.

OurHudson is grateful to our partners in the Hudson Valley whose collaboration has made this project possible. Special thanks to Scenic Hudson, Clearwater, Riverkeeper, Glynwood, the Hudson River Watershed Alliance and the Hudson River Valley Greenway.

The perks!

OurHudson and our partnering organizations are able to offer the following wonderful perks to thank those who can help us! 

$25 – A DVD of the completed movie and a thank you on the OurHudson.org webpage.

$100 – An invite to our premiere at the wonderful Basilica in Hudson on October 26!

$250 – Visit the front lines of Hudson Valley advocacy! Select one of the unique tours generously our partners on the vanguard of the battle to revive the Valley and keep it unique:

-  Take a tour with leading land preservation group Scenic Hudson!  Learn about the initiatives past and present to preserve the Valley's landscape by hiking up iconic Storm King Mountain, visiting the wonderful new West Point Foundry Preserve park (set to open this October!) or visiting Falling Waters Preserve with its outstanding views of the Catskills. 

- Take a backstage, VIP tour of the magnificent 250 acre estate Olana, with a Persian-inspired house at its summit, all designed by Frederic Church, one of America’s most important artists, and learn how the artistic legacy of the Hudson Valley continues to thrive! For more information, click here.

-  Take a ride on the legendary Riverkeeper boat. Learn about the epic struggle to force companies to stop polluting the Hudson and clear PCBs from the River - and the challenge now to keep out sewage and other contaminants. And experience the Hudson Valley from the River!

- Take a tour of the farm of agricultural non-profit group Glynwood! Learn about the initiatives underway to save the Valley's farmland and ensure it thrives. Leave with some of their delicious farm-produced eggs as a take-home gift!

$500 – Taste the Hudson Valley! Choose from one of the following fabulous Valley foodie experiences:

-  A voucher to collect a basket of Hudson Valley produce from Adams Fairacre Farm in Poughkeepsie

-  An invitation to the Rogowski Farm Supper Club with MacArthur Prize-winner and star of Hudson Rising Cheryl Rogowski

-  A $100 voucher towards a meal at acclaimed Hudson restaurant Swoon Kitchenbar

-  A $100 voucher towards a meal at acclaimed NYC restaurant – to be announced shortly - that uses Hudson Valley produce!

$1000 – Get a personal screening of Hudson Rising! The director and producer of Hudson Rising will bring a projector and sound equipment to screen the movie at your business or neighborhood. We’ll stick around to answer questions about the movie…

$1500 – Take home a legendary print of the Hudson Valley from acclaimed landscape photographer Larry Lederman. Only two available!

$2500 – Become an associate producer of Hudson Rising. Receive a credit in the end-titles and join the executive producers and directors at an afternoon tea-party to celebrate the launch of the movie.

All contributions towards the movie  are tax-deductible donations to the Hudson River Foundation.

Contact info@ourhudson.org if you have any questions or comments about this campaign!

Contact info@ourhudson.org if you have any
questions or comments about this campaign!

story:
I am a 22 year old woman who is passionate about mantaining our forests and connection with nature. This May I will embark on a journey into a tree-planting career which I am nervous yet excited about. 

As a first time planter there are many initial costs that I am struggling with. I plan to do this annually and once I get all the nessasary equipment I will be ready and on my way to success for years to come.

The funds will be used for travel expensies and equiment such as: tent, rain gear, wrist/back/knee brace, boots, shovel, tree bag holder, sleeping equiment, warm clothing, helmet, etc. 

This is an experience that will change my life and my positive energy and love will only reach further after doing so. This is also job that will help me finantially once I get started and I plan to give back to others who need a little push in the future.

Thank you endlessly for your help.

Love Michelle.

story:
We all want to be a part of the solution, not the problem…and here’s a perfect opportunity to do just that.

 

Sustainable Silicon Valley, in partnership with NASA Ames Research Center, is hosting its fourth annual WEST Summit. These Summits have been extremely popular in the past. The 2013 Showcase of Solutions and WEST Summit will be a gathering of change agents to deepen our understanding, engage our thinking, bring together a diversity of elements and people to create a resilient civilization. We are going beyond talk to analysis, action and implementation, bringing the ingenuity of Silicon Valley to tackle the world's greatest challenges through technology, policy and social change.

We all need to all work together to bring these solutions to life. We primed the pump by selecting 90 of the best solutions we could find. And now, we need your help in connecting the dots -- creating ecosystems of solutions, make connections between various solutions, funding sources and other resources that can work together to transform our shared future, to benefit our community, region and planet.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for at least $7,500 to fund student, government staff and entrepreneurs with limited funding to be able to attend this event and have their solutions acknowledged. You can be a part of this exciting project by supporting innovative minds in their pursuit of a more sustainable future.

Perks of supporting this project include the knowledge that you have helped a sustainability solution to get a spotlight at this event. Additionally, you can get a thank you message posted on our Social Media sites, a free reusable grocery bag, and an opportunity to get a mention on the Sustainable Silicon Valley website and in the event program.

If we do not reach our goal, we will use the funds to give scholarships to as many solution submitters and students as we can. If we exceed our goal, we will help underwrite transportation and other expenses of our outstanding speakers.

The Impact

The WEST Summit is Sustainable Silicon Valley’s largest annual event, furthering the organization’s mission to lead the Silicon Valley community to a more sustainable future. WEST stands for Water, Energy, and Smart Technology, all critical elements necessary to drive sustainability in our region and globally.

This is SSV’s 4th annual WEST Summit. Previous WEST Summits brought together great minds and unique perspectives that helped bring together Silicon Valley, and the region on a mission towards sustainability.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you make a financial donation, please help us spread the word about the fantastic solutions and the Showcase Event on May 23rd.

VOTE for your favorite solution. Read the INSTRUCTIONS and visit EcoCloud to vote.

FOLLOW US on Facebook or Twitter.

VISIT the WEST Summit/Showcase website for all the information.

Or REGISTER yourself at WEST2013.eventbrite.com!

story:
Aquasension is a Tribal Gathering and Prayer, celebrating and calling attention to the Sacred waters of Alaska & the world in honor of our Beloved Angel, Mario Julian Benassi. 
 

Mario passed in the river on June 26 2018, taken by the element of Water he had such strong affiliation and love for. Mario was known to be an advocate of upholding the sacredness of waters of this planet, a talented dancer, singer and storyteller. He touched the hearts of many beings with his wisdom beyond years, especially in community spaces.  ​One of the ways he shared this was through teaching the grand invocation of the Water Blessing Song by Nalini Blossom .

 

Mario and his beautiful blood family hail from Alaska.
His family has put together this potent offering and gathering in honor of their son.

 

Please Help Support this beautiful Family in Memorializing their Son and Friend with the beginnings of an Annual Sacred Pilgrimage to Alaska where the Tribes of the World will gather to Bless the Waters, For Us All.


'AQUACENSION' takes place June 25-27 . It is to be a prayerful educating celebration with local and other indigenous world family uniting as Water Protectors and Earth Guardians on the sacred lands Mario called home.

We will gather in The Valley of the Eagles, on the edge of the Chilkat River, for three-days of heart centered ceremonies led by indigenous elders, water protection, medicine music, native dance & presentations on the latest water science and our human connection to water. 

This is an event run completely from donation. The family did not have the means to put on this gathering alone. They have called together Mario's friends to join together and offer our skills to lift this powerful vision up.  All of us producing this are Volunteering because we Believe in This Sacred Offering and Blessing of our Waters.   

We need to raise funds for: 

The Venue Space Cost
Flights for all the Native American Elders, Some Artists and Presenters

Ferry Costs and Hotels 
Materials Needed On Site: PA, Transportation, Food

Extra Costs Associated with Organizing

 

We Believe we can cover all these costs and have more for next years event with this Fundraiser!

We are doing this at cost with no profit gain or payment to any of the producers or volunteers. This is all being offered by donation from all of us . 

We hope that if you can't be present that you'll do the next best thing and offer a donation to make this possible.

 

It is hoped that with Your Help this can become a yearly event, inspired by all that Mario loved so very much and bringing awareness to creating unity across all lands and cultures and especially the healing and protection of the bodies of water of our great Planet Earth.  

 

Why This is Important: 

There is a urgent need to bring prayerful action to supporting ALL of earths population to have access to clean water. Regardless if you view Water is a gift from the Creator or not, no one can argue that it is the planets very lifeblood.  

 

Alaska represents one of the last places on Earth where acting quickly and making a stand can preserve an intact, untouched and pristine natural environment. Aquasension aims to make a strong and loving cry of support for Mother Nature/Gaia/Pacha Mama and Her gifts of pure flowing waters, clean air and healthy lands.

 

We stand side-by-side with our native indigenous Alaskan brothers and sisters to celebrate these gifts and act and pray in the ways that are asked of us to raise awareness and prevent further industrialization of the Alaskan wilderness!

Today the land of the Chilkat Tlingit people is at risk of high sulfide ore mining. The mining industry aims to dig a mile long tunnel for underground exploration of sulfide ore without Tlingit approval or consent.

 

They intend to mine just six miles up stream of the ancient village of Klukwan.

 

The indigenous people as well as environmentally-minded locals have been defending this land for nearly ten years.... now it’s our turn to join in the cause!

 

The Tlingit people are the Salmon people. Their entire way of life is completely interwoven with the continuation of a healthy river and its fish. The Chilkat River and its salmon friends are sacred to them, as are all the plants and animals.

 

In turn we gather to bring awareness to this matter and honor our heart’s deep knowing that we can make a difference when we stand together as one connected tribe of the Earth.

 

The Tribes Coming: 


The Tlingit, Nez Perce, Lakota and Kogi are coming together to Bless the Water and stand in solidarity for the water in honor of an Angel, Mario Julian Benassi who passed in the Yuba River last year.

 

"Water is our first medicine, it is our sacred source of life. I am very honored to be invited to this."- Dan Nanamkin: Nex Perce Tribe Seattle

 

May we lift our hearts and hands together. May we unite in prayerful action towards supporting the return of health to all waters, to the Earth and the humans that live upon her. 
 

We can feel the heart and soul of Mario surrounding us and cheering this on, showering what this will be in Miracles. 

I encourage you, no matter where you are on the planet to offer a moment to support the Water in this way, big or small, Thank you.

 

Mni Wiconi- Water is Life!

 

 Aquacension details are here: https://www.facebook.com/events/112092876141206...

story:
Short Summary

SeaChar was founded in Seattle Washington in 2008. Our mission is to promote the understanding and use of biochar, a highly durable form of charcoal, as a wedge strategy to combat climate change, while it builds the health and productivity of our soils.   Biochar is the high carbon by-product of biomass energy production. Across the world traditional farmers have used charcoal to build more productive soils that store carbon drawn down by plants from the atmosphere. Science shows us that this form of carbon is stable for 1000's of years. Each pound of biochar produced removes three pounds of CO2 from the carbon cycle. That makes the biochar technology cluster a truly carbon negative form of energy production and a potentially significant wedge strategy for mitigating climate change. In 2009 we developed our Estufa Finca (Farm Stove) biochar producing cook-stove as a tool that could put this powerful idea into the hands of farmers and gardeners around the world. The stoves are micro-gasification devices that burn clean and can use a wide range of waste biomass as fuel.
SeaChar now has 5-years of experience introducing this concept in North and Central America. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rowc0Y-1plY&amp...

We have seen and measured the impact this tool can have on people's lives and on the food they are producing. The idea works. With almost 3 billion people still relying on biomass for cooking and heating our little stoves have the potential to have a huge positive impact on the lives of people, forests and the climate. We are putting that experience into developing a second generation biochar producing stove that is more durable and easier to use. We are calling it the "Estufa Bella" (the Beautiful Stove) https://plus.google.com/photos/1142611701735619...

What We Need & What You Get

In order to complete our prototyping and have the Estufa Bella 3rd Party tested for emissions and certified as a improved cook-stove we need to raise $5000.
$3000 of these funds will be paid to the Aprovecho Research Center http://aprovecho.org/ for the testing and certification. $2000.00 will be used for the construction of the first ten of these stoves and the kit of custom tools it takes to produce more of them in field situations. If we can reach this goal by the beginning of 2015 SeaChar has secured a commitment from a generous donor of a $3000 grant to support a small demonstration project with these new stoves in Central America in 2015. SeaChar has already placed twelve of the 1st version of the Estufa Bella model for 6-months of field testing in Costa Rica and has performed preliminary testing at A.R.C. With this input we are ready for the final push. We want to be undergoing certification testing by April 2015 and ready to go back into the field with our new stove by soon after.

What we get: A stove which will last for at least 3-years and can be manufactured anywhere in the world to the same high performance standards.
What you get: We are offering a range of unique thank you gifts from our on-line store http://seachar.org/#shopify-store and beyond:
  • Give $25- receive a 1 lb. sample bag of our biochar soil amendment.
  • Give $50- receive a bar of biochar enhanced face and body soap.
  • Give $100- receive a SeaChar logo t-shirt.
  • Give $500- receive a Deluxe Estufa Finca biochar stove and one to one instructions, via SKYPE, from designer Art Donnelly.
  • Give $1,000-receive one, of the first ten, of the new certified Estufa Bella biochar stoves and one to one instructions, via SKYPE, from designer Art Donnelly.

The Impact

The use of open fires to meet the need for cooking, heating and crop processing continues to grow. There is also growing proof of the impact this practice has on human health, our forests and the climate. The World Health Organization estimates 3.8 million premature deaths annually from noncommunicable diseases including stroke, ischaemic heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and lung cancer can be attributed to exposure to household air pollution.
Recent landmark studies have shown that black carbon, like that emitted by traditional cook-stoves ranks “as the second most important individual climate-warming agent after carbon dioxide”.
The laboratory testing of our Estufa Finca cook-stove showed that it produced 92% less particulate matter and 87% less CO than an traditional open fire cook-stove. Field testing indicated that our stoves use 40% less fuel to cook the same meal. That difference is huge in terms of the health and climate impacts of our stove. However we will only see these benefits if people use these stoves. Our experience tells us that people will only use and replace these stoves on an ongoing basis if they are a good value, consistent quality and are convenient to use.
The Estufa Bella will give the cooks a long lasting (3+ year ) stove, made from high tolerance stainless steel kit parts, that has a greater range of temperature control.  That's the kind of product you can build sustainable businesses with and that is what it will take to mainstream this concept.

 

    Risks & Challenges


    We are aware of the fact that we are working on the "bleeding edge" of development work with concepts that most people have never heard of.  The risk of failure in this situation is always high. We have experienced failure, you have to accept that risk if you are going to learn and move forward. We have 5-years of that kind of hard-won experience. This is why we feel confident that we can produce and test the device the people we have been working with have been asking for. Our greatest challenge is to give donors and investors confidence in our ability to contribute to real and lasting positive change. A tested and certified biochar producing stove, based on our years of field experience is the foundation we can build that confidence on. That is what it will take to get these stoves into the hands of farmers and gardeners from Seattle, Washington to Bri Bri ,Costa Rica. You are going to help us lay that foundation.

    • Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can not give at this time, then please help support this campaign and our valuable work by sharing our story with your family and friends.

    Also please consider volunteering. SeaChar is and always has been an organization powered by committed volunteers. No matter what your skills, we can find a way for you to help grow this grass roots effort.

    Please contact us at : info@seachar.org

story:
Since my father has received his sentence, many people have been reaching out and wondering how they can help the man who stood up for Mother Earth, Muskrat Falls (Labrador), us and our rights. People are wondering where they can email money and are wanting to plan fundraisers, I thought that setting up a page like this would make it easy for people to contribute funds. 

If anyone is interested in having a fundraiser please email me at regan.burden@hotmail.com, you can deposit the funds from the fundraiser here but we'd like to keep track of everything that is going on. This way we can also recognize contributions.

My family and I are so grateful to each and everyone of you for your kind words and your tremendous support, your generosity will not be forgotten. Your actions are sending a loud message to those who stand to destroy Labrador and our planet as a whole. In our own ways, we are all standing up to say enough of being silenced while the lands, waters, and way of life we hold dear are threatened. As my father would say, "There is no Planet B".

As a thank-you to each of you for donating, we will be having a draw with everyone's name and the person picked will receive two free nights at the Alexis Hotel in Port Hope Simpson with complimentary breakfasts. The first morning will be spent dogsledding near Port Hope Simpson and on the second morning you'll be treated to a Labrador Boil-up. 

I'd like to thank everyone in advance, you're all truly amazing.

Regan Burden - January 10, 2014

HOW TO CONTRIBUTE:

1) You can make payment from your credit card directly to this website

OR

2) You can make payments to the EAGLE RIVER CREDIT UNION in the "Dennis Burden Land Protector Fund" (be sure to reference account # 92359206) by either of the following methods:

a) IN PERSON at any of the branches in NL (see https://www.eaglerivercu.com/Home/ToolsAndCalculators/FindBranchATM/?branch=show  for locations)

b) MAIL to Eagle River Credit Union, 328 Hamilton River Rd, PO Box 57 Stn C
Happy Valley-Goose Bay NL A0P 1C0

c) ONLINE (if you are a Eagle River Credit Union member) to deposit in the account # 92359206

 

Here are some words from my father, Dennis Burden, on the day he went to receive sentencing in provincial court (Happy Valley-Goose Bay) on January 8, 2014:

"Right from the start I knew there was something really really wrong with this Muskrat Falls (Labrador) project.

I have spent hundreds of hours searching the better way. I have watched them spend a fortune on an unsanctioned project. I have heard the NL Premier lie about how green and needed this hydro dam is. Our experts, our experts, our experts! So I check to find SNC Lavalin (banned from any World Bank project for 10 years and also from bidding on Canadian international development agency contracts among other things) then there is Manitoba Hydro (MHI) who was 85 % over on their last project.

I have seen the "power is in our hands" advertising (remember that old guy and his grandkid looking out over our perfect green future) I have read about methyl mercury and its dangers, Agent White, and that some dams are worse than plants the same size running on fossil fuels ( methane gas ).

So I begin to wonder what’s wrong for the people to stand by and watch this terrible assault on our habitat and democracy. They don`t know or they believe our government? I ask myself "How to spread the message? What to do? How to kill the monster?" Discouraging much? Yup! So I figured if we, the ones who have studied this project, could just inform the folks about what’s going on here they would stand and say no.

Every little protest, picture, and post would tweek someone’s interest. The media has been silenced. The Public Utilities Board (PUB) perhaps (oh no they were kicked outta the equation months ago). Environmental laws (nope, they got the boots too). Then there is Newfoundland & Labrador’s (NL) Bills 60 & 61 and changes to Bill 29 that drops NL below some third world countries in its laws of disclosure. I felt, and still do, that I owe it to my kids’ future to try and stop the Muskrat Fall project. In hind sight maybe attacking the corrupt pole was not such a great idea (I remember my girlfriend walking in the room with tears saying I wish you never had to do this) but that was it, I had no choice. I had to.

Did it have the desired effects? No. Am I sorry? Only that it didn`t work. Would I do it again? If I thought it would stop the project - Yes.

I see all you proudly waving the Labrador flag and singing songs about "We, her strong sons and daughters". Next time you wave it ask yourself "How much would you sell it for?"

You see it has to come down to the common folks. Not our Native groups. Not the Combined Councils of Labrador. Not any of our elected officials has the balls to speak out! Maybe the ole attitude of "You’re only Labradorian and deserve no better" has stuck on us.

"It takes years to learn how to look at the destruction of beautiful things; to learn how to leave the place of oppression; and how to make your own regeneration out of nothing." G Stern

So I stood there with every intention of committing this offence in hopes of exposing a far greater crime. Hopefully someday soon the other criminals involved in this slaughter will get justice delivered to them also!" - DB

January 8, 2014 - Dennis Woodrow Burden was convicted and found guilty of "mischief over $5000" in NL Provincial Court and has been fined $8000, ordered on probation for 12 months, and not allowed to visit any active Nalcor Muskrat Falls active work sites for 12 months.

Media:

Dec 19, 2012 - http://www.cbc.ca/labradormorning/episodes/2012/12/19/port-hope-simpsons-dennis-burden---protesting-muskrat-falls/

Jan 8, 2014 - http://www.thelabradorian.ca/News/Local/2014-01-08/article-3568681/No-regrets/1

Rethink Muskrat Falls article by Dennis Burden (Dec 2012) - http://rethinkmuskratfalls.wordpress.com/2012/12/18/why_am_i_here/
story_txt:
Since my father has received his sentence, many people have been reaching out and wondering how they can help the man who stood up for Mother Earth, Muskrat Falls (Labrador), us and our rights. People are wondering where they can email money and are wanting to plan fundraisers, I thought that setting up a page like this would make it easy for people to contribute funds. If anyone is interested in having a fundraiser please email me at regan.burden@hotmail.com, you can deposit the funds from the fundraiser here but we'd like to keep track of everything that is going on. This way we can also recognize contributions.My family and I are so grateful to each and everyone of you for your kind words and your tremendous support, your generosity will not be forgotten. Your actions are sending a loud message to those who stand to destroy Labrador and our planet as a whole. In our own ways, we are all standing up to say enough of being silenced while the lands, waters, and way of life we hold dear are threatened. As my father would say, "There is no Planet B".As a thank-you to each of you for donating, we will be having a draw with everyone's name and the person picked will receive two free nights at the Alexis Hotel in Port Hope Simpson with complimentary breakfasts. The first morning will be spent dogsledding near Port Hope Simpson and on the second morning you'll be treated to a Labrador Boil-up. I'd like to thank everyone in advance, you're all truly amazing.Regan Burden - January 10, 2014HOW TO CONTRIBUTE:1) You can make payment from your credit card directly to this websiteOR2) You can make payments to the EAGLE RIVER CREDIT UNION in the "Dennis Burden Land Protector Fund" (be sure to reference account # 92359206) by either of the following methods:a) IN PERSON at any of the branches in NL (see https://www.eaglerivercu.com/Home/ToolsAndCalculators/FindBranchATM/?branch=show  for locations)b) MAIL to Eagle River Credit Union, 328 Hamilton River Rd, PO Box 57 Stn CHappy Valley-Goose Bay		 NL		 A0P 1C0c) ONLINE (if you are a Eagle River Credit Union member) to deposit in the account # 92359206 Here are some words from my father, Dennis Burden, on the day he went to receive sentencing in provincial court (Happy Valley-Goose Bay) on January 8, 2014:"Right from the start I knew there was something really really wrong with this Muskrat Falls (Labrador) project.I have spent hundreds of hours searching the better way. I have watched them spend a fortune on an unsanctioned project. I have heard the NL Premier lie about how green and needed this hydro dam is. Our experts, our experts, our experts! So I check to find SNC Lavalin (banned from any World Bank project for 10 years and also from bidding on Canadian international development agency contracts among other things) then there is Manitoba Hydro (MHI) who was 85 % over on their last project.I have seen the "power is in our hands" advertising (remember that old guy and his grandkid looking out over our perfect green future) I have read about methyl mercury and its dangers, Agent White, and that some dams are worse than plants the same size running on fossil fuels ( methane gas ).So I begin to wonder what’s wrong for the people to stand by and watch this terrible assault on our habitat and democracy. They don`t know or they believe our government? I ask myself "How to spread the message? What to do? How to kill the monster?" Discouraging much? Yup! So I figured if we, the ones who have studied this project, could just inform the folks about what’s going on here they would stand and say no.Every little protest, picture, and post would tweek someone’s interest. The media has been silenced. The Public Utilities Board (PUB) perhaps (oh no they were kicked outta the equation months ago). Environmental laws (nope, they got the boots too). Then there is Newfoundland & Labrador’s (NL) Bills 60 & 61 and changes to Bill 29 that drops NL below some third world countries in its laws of disclosure. I felt, and still do, that I owe it to my kids’ future to try and stop the Muskrat Fall project. In hind sight maybe attacking the corrupt pole was not such a great idea (I remember my girlfriend walking in the room with tears saying I wish you never had to do this) but that was it, I had no choice. I had to.Did it have the desired effects? No. Am I sorry? Only that it didn`t work. Would I do it again? If I thought it would stop the project - Yes.I see all you proudly waving the Labrador flag and singing songs about "We, her strong sons and daughters". Next time you wave it ask yourself "How much would you sell it for?"You see it has to come down to the common folks. Not our Native groups. Not the Combined Councils of Labrador. Not any of our elected officials has the balls to speak out! Maybe the ole attitude of "You’re only Labradorian and deserve no better" has stuck on us."It takes years to learn how to look at the destruction of beautiful things; to learn how to leave the place of oppression; and how to make your own regeneration out of nothing." G SternSo I stood there with every intention of committing this offence in hopes of exposing a far greater crime. Hopefully someday soon the other criminals involved in this slaughter will get justice delivered to them also!" - DBJanuary 8, 2014 - Dennis Woodrow Burden was convicted and found guilty of "mischief over $5000" in NL Provincial Court and has been fined $8000, ordered on probation for 12 months, and not allowed to visit any active Nalcor Muskrat Falls active work sites for 12 months.

story:
Nature Connected Living 

Can Be Rapid, Widespread and Grassroots

Help kids make it happen!

The Basic Idea

I've been teaching kids sustainable living skills and have discovered that they become powerful change-makers, inspiring change in their homes right away.  Kids lead their families to change the way they live despite perceived inabilities or failing wills. Teachers and schools are requesting my curriculum, and I'm writing a book.  It could take years writing it part time, or it could be finished this spring with your help.  Considering the state of the planet, I'm in a bit of a hurry.  


Finished this spring, it would be ready for teachers to use this coming fall, and it could be used for my upcoming: 


• educator workshops this summer in New Mexico and Oregon

• environmental educator conference presentations, and

        • a globally available and locally relevant online course being organized for Fall 2011 to Spring 2102.  





Learn More

What if you’d grown up with the chance to learn how to live in a nature connected way?  You would have learned to:


      • grow your own food and healing herbs, 
      • collect and recycle your own water, 
      • build your own structures with local natural materials, and 
      • generate your own renewable energy.

You could also have learned how to create a living interconnected system of these elements that would do much of the work for you.  Starting young, it would all be second nature to you. 


What if your family and neighbors had all grown up with the same opportunity?  

What would your neighborhood and local businesses be like? 

What if nature connected living was part of education in general?  

How could that affect your world?


My Story

I’d like to find the answers to these questions.  I’ve been working for ten years to help answer them, teaching nature based sustainable living skills to kids.  They really love it and so do their parents, who tell me how great it is to have their kids respond to their question “So what did you learn in school today?” with enthusiastic details of their experience.  Almost all parents tell me with pride about the family-connecting and earth-caring activities their child learned and insisted on starting at home.  Kids inspire and activate change now!


I’ve begun to work with classroom teachers to help incorporate sustainable living skills into their science, math, language arts and social studies, and it’s been a big hit with the teachers, who also enjoy learning.  Incorporating art, music and drama makes it even more engaging and effective.  


I'm working on a model that involves 

• student taught workshops for their families and community,

• local sustainability entrepreneurs and practitioners working with students and school curriculum committees, 

• basing kids' grades on being creative, cooperative, responsible, and other such things of value to a community striving to be more self reliant.  

These are all part of a concept for an evolving process for toddlers through university level.   


The requests for my curriculum are starting to come in from near and far, even internationally.



Widespread change can happen soon, and YOU can help lay the groundwork!  


What I Need & What You Get 

Covering the $1000 a month I'd earn from substitute teaching (on the days I don't teach sustainable living skills), would make it possible to support my family and write the book this semester.  The fund will also pay for printing costs, and other professional fees.  Reaching the $6,000 goal allows the book to be published in time for the summer workshops.  If the $6,000 goal is not reached, all money received will go towards days off from substitute teaching to help get the book written faster than it would otherwise.  Any money raised above the goal will go towards scholarships for attendees that would be otherwise unable to come to the educator's courses.  

For your kind, generous and immensely appreciated contributions you will receive the knowledge that you are: 

• contributing to catalyze change in the way we live, which brings joy to children and their families 

• bringing profound relevance to education, and a sense of purpose to children and youth 

• supporting the creation of jobs for sustainable living practitioners, helping to define tomorrow's jobs 

• tying communities together around sustainable living practices.  


Additionally, with deep appreciation for your contributions I will present you with:

$1 - A great sense of contributing to sustainability  

$5 - A recipe for a home made herbal decongestant that my family has used for years

$10 - A recipe for a home made ointment for preventing infection in scrapes or scratches that my family has used for years

$25 - A home made organic bandana 

$50 - An autographed copy of the book for your own use or to donate to the school of your choice

$100 - An autographed photograph of a class of engaged students and acknowledgment in the book if you'd like 

$250 - A vegetable/herb/flower garden design full of companion plantings and acknowledged in book, if you’d like

$500 - Instructions to build a device to recycle laundry greywater (without having to punch a hole through your wall) and acknowledgment in the book, if you’d like

$1000 - Two hours of personal phone or skype consultation on sustainable living for your home and acknowledgment in the book, if you’d like

$5000 - Your choice of a full day of instruction on principles of sustainable design for your home or a hike in the New Mexico mountains with an introduction to edible and medicinal wild plants, or attend a day of one of the educator courses this summer (travel expenses not included) and acknowledgment in the book, if you’d like


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with everyone you feel might be interested in children and the future through e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, MySpace or any other social networking sites you know of!  


Thank you very much,

Patty Parks-Wasserman
