story:
J’ai 55 ans, marie ,3 enfants, mécanicien de formation, mais un touche a tout perpétuel, brevet et bac pro en poche et je suis l’inventeur d’un projet dont le  brevet a été déposé.

 

J’ai retourné sur les bancs de l’école pour suivre des cours d’ingénieur et mettre au point ce projet, mes calculs ont été validés par une école d’ingénierie Suisse.

 

Ce projet  a pour but de prendre la place des éoliennes ou des panneaux photovoltaïques dans des endroits où cela n’est pas possible.

Cette machine je l’ai  baptisé « CENTRALE HYDROSOL une centrale électrique dans son jardin » » sont principe est basé sur la poussée l’hydro mécanique et le pompage-turbinage.

 

Ce projet a vu le jour il y a 40 ans date de mes premiers essais, mais vient seulement de voir le jour grâce a de  nouvelles technologies  développé  depuis peu, pour exemple : ce même projet il y a une dizaine d’année aurai la taille d’un camion semi remorque et un poids de 5 tonnes, mais surtout il aurait fallut un petit fleuve pour l’entrainer

 

A l’instar des éoliennes et autre panneaux photovoltaïque ayant besoin des éléments climatiques pour fonctionner, mon projet lui n’a besoin que de quelques mètre cube d’eau stoker dans un réservoir pour fonctionné  et ceux  sans aucunes restrictions ,24h/24h et 365 jour par ans.

 

Ses atouts sur les autres systèmes  est sa simplicité de mise en place, vu sa taille au maximum 27 m2 au sol et 2.5m de hauteur, mais aussi très écologique, pas de pollution sonores, visuelle, pas de destruction de milieux naturels pour sa mise en place, pas non plus d’utilisation d’énergie fossile, elle utilise que de l’eau, 6 a 18 m3 et en plus réutilisable a volontés

 

Tous les matériaux utilisés sont recyclable et déplaçable sans très grosses contraintes

 

Mon projet pourra être utilisé par des particuliers,  des entreprises ou des collectivités locales qui sont isolé ou très difficile d’accès pour le gestionnaire du réseau publique, pouvant alimenter une maison, une usine ou même un gros village

 

Mais sa vocation première est la vente de la production aux fournisseurs d’énergie, pour amortir l’achat, tous en gardant sa consommation personnelle.

Car le système Français prévoit que des producteurs privé peuvent vendre leur production (sous certaines conditions réglementaires) aux distributeurs d’énergie (EDF, POWEO etc.…) pour une durée de 20 ans

En fonction du modèle choisi les revenus financiers seront de 1 800 a 5 000€

 

 

Mon projet, une fois financer, servira de base a la création d’une entreprise et comptera au début 4 salariers, voir plus

 

5 modèles seront développés  allant de 52, 70,100, 140 et 780 kw j’ai déjà  plus de 15  promesses d’achat

 

Très simple pour sa  fabrication mais très chère a fabriqué car la génératrice de base choisie est la seul à pouvoir produire de l’électricité et de l’injecter directement dans le réseau de distribution

 

J’ai besoin de vous car le système bancaire Français ne laisse aucune place pour des petits inventeurs comme moi «trop visionnaire qu’ils disent) mais surtout fera de l’ombre aux industrielles déjà en place

 

Mon projet a besoin  de 60 000€  maximum pour acheter les matériaux, le matériel de production, le matériel de raccordement au réseau électrique  et sa mise point  du 1er prototype, il faudra aussi payer les sous traitant, les démarches administrative lier a la mise sur le marcher des centrales, il me faut 5 mois de fonctionnement pour tout cela.

 

Je propose pour ceux qui le souhaitent un rendement financier sur 2 ans

 - de 15 % pour les sommes allant  de   100 €   à  1 000 €

 - de 12% pour les sommes allant  de  1001 €  à  10 000 €

 - de 8 % pour les sommes allant  de 10 001 € et +

 

Si je n’arrive pas a financer la totalité de mon  projet les fonds récolté serviront quand même au projet par l’achat du matériels de base

 

 

 

Si certain d’entre vous ne peuvent pas m’aider directement ils peuvent partager au tour d’eux grâce au réseau  d’INDIEGOGO

story:
Stingless HoneyBee Project in Malaysia

                                   

                                         The Malaysian Kelulut (Beehive)

Summary

My name is Dr. Joseph A. Resnick.  To most people I am known as, "Dr. Joe".  I'm from Lenoir, NC and a member of the Caldwell County Beekeepers Association and the North Carolina Beekeepers Association.  In 2013, I was invited to join the Faculty at the University of Malaysia, Institute of Marine Biotechnology, where I am presently a Professor and Lecturer. There, I am part of a research team studying the stingless bee, or 'Melipona', with my Esteemed Colleagues, Assoc. Prof. Dr. Shamsul ("Sam") Razak, Assoc. Prof. Abdullah ("Haji") Zain, Ms. Joyce ("Joy") Mann, Mr. Ramlee Rhamat, and UMT Student RA, Zuliana Noor.

                               

         Trigona miniata (Stingless Bee) at UMT's Bukit Kor Research Station

Our project is a very important one, directed to creating an entirely new business infrastructure here in S.E. Asia called, Meliponiculture (propogation and culturing of the Stingless Honeybee).   Our research is designed to lead toward creation of new new jobs, help people find new sources of sustainable income through cultivation of 'green products' <Stingless Honeybees are considered a 'green product' and are a 'sustainable resource'>, and improve the economic condition of all peoples living in S.E. Asia .  Initially, our focus centers on activities that will be carried out in the Setui Wetlands Region near Jebi, and the Bukit Kor Research Station at UMT's second campus in Marang, both locations on Malaysia's beautiful N.E. seacoast adjoining the South China Sea.

                           

                          Melipona Trigona The 'Stingless' Honeybee


What We Need and What You Get

The Project
Our research project calls for purchase of twenty (20) Kelulut bee hives, one for each program participant.   The Kelulut hives cost $400 UDS's each and are purchased complete with bees (and a viable Queen).  The total cost for hives will be $8000 USD's.  We plan to engage twenty people here in Terengganu state to be involved in our research project.  Each participant will be provided with a Kelulut and will receive training in proper Bee Management Practices through attendance at several Workshops provided by members of the research team, all Professors at UMT.  The goal is to spark interest among the native population regarding the potential benefits of small-scale bee farming related to this species of stingless bee and to help provide new jobs and revenue access at the 'grass-roots level'.

                                

                       Egg Cells of the Trigona itama (Stingless Honeybee)

No special equipment is required, but participants will be provided with books and appropriate garments (hat, safety glasses, gloves and paper-coveralls) that will be used when tending the bee colony.  We estimate cost for clothing, books and safety equipment to be about $2000 USD's.  So the total cost for this project will be Ten Thousand Dollars ($10,000 USD's).

          The Malaysian Kelulut (Beehive) Experimental Station at Bukit Kor

We have very exciting Perks for our contributors, ranging from some of the exotic products that our Melipona will produce over the term of the project, to Hats, Tee's and even an 'Exotic Tropical Vacation' at one of Terengganu's finest, 5-Star, seaside resorts.

All funds raised will be used to purchase equipment and supplies for the project regardless of whether or not we reach the goal of $10,000 Dollars.  If we raise more than needed we will use the excess funds to purchase more Kelulut's and get more people involved: That would please the Team very much and help more people discover a potential new source of income.

The Impact

The Kelulut is the term used by native Malays to refer to this kind of beehive, native to the tropical forests and jungles of Malaysia.  There are (presently) 30 known species of the stingless bees in Malaysia, called, 'Melipona'.  Our team is studying Trigona itama and Trigona minima.  T. itama is the largest of the species, and T. minima is the smallest.

The team's research will lead to establishment of better bee management practices and a more comprehensive body of knowledge the stingless honeybee.  The stingless honeybee is  that, prior to our research project,  were not known nor found anywhere in any scientific literature.  So, this work is very important and will help Man discover new findings about this pollinator and about its environment, the Eco-systems in which it thrives and the weather patterns that help this species produce maximum amounts of honey and byproducts (propolis, bee bread, etc.).

You can see some videos that will give you a snapshot into some of the team's preliminary efforts by clicking the following links:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dYbfQ2wCH9U 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yMV_pspxqjw
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z-AIdTMyb8M
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aeT8oAaiReI
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K9cSmwz8Nw8&feature=youtu.be

Risks and Challenges

One risk we are confident that will not be encountered is the prospect of participants and researcher being stung by the Melipona.  The Melipona species does not have a lancet, or stinger, and cannot inflict a sting.  However, the Melipona is capable of biting with its tiny jaws or Mandibles.  The width that the mandible is capable of being spread is very, very small.  Thus one can barely feel the bite, if one occurs at all. The Melipona is, generally, very shy and not aggressive and not prone to swarming.   In order to lessen the possibility of any injuries to either bee or project participants a number of workshops related to proper hive management and proper beekeeping techniques will be held.  During the workshops participants will receive one-on-one training with regard to proper bee management and bee hive maintenance practices for the Melipona species.

                                              

           Dr. Resnick samples fresh honey from honey pot in Kelulut at Gong Bris

Collectively, team members possess an aggregate number of over 90 years of experience as Beekeepers and with bee management practices.  Thus, the team believes that it possesses requisite experience and resources to handle any problems that may arise.  If some problem does arise the cannot be resolved by the team, the Project Leader can rely upon the full support of the university to find resolution.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to make a donation, you can help us in other ways.  For example, you can help spread the word about our project.  You can discuss the project at work, with friends and you can post our photo's on your Facebook wall, or tweet our messages or tell people about the 'stingless bee'.  Most people don't know there there is a stingless bee and even more, a stingless Honeybee!  People who can't donate can also use the 'share tools' portal on Indiegogo's web page.

Stingless HoneyBee Project in Malaysia

                                                                             The Malaysian Kelulut (Beehive)Summary My name is Dr. Joseph A. Resnick.  To most people I am known as, "Dr. Joe".  I'm from Lenoir, NC and a member of the Caldwell County Beekeepers Association and the North Carolina Beekeepers Association.  In 2013, I was invited to 
join the Faculty at the University of Malaysia, Institute of Marine 
Biotechnology, where I am presently a Professor and Lecturer. There, I am part 
of a research team studying the stingless bee, or 'Melipona', with my Esteemed 
Colleagues, Assoc. Prof. Dr. Shamsul ("Sam") Razak, Assoc. Prof. Abdullah ("Haji") Zain, Ms. Joyce ("Joy") Mann, Mr. Ramlee Rhamat, and UMT Student RA, Zuliana Noor.


                                         Trigona miniata (Stingless Bee) at UMT's Bukit Kor Research StationOur project is a very important one, directed to creating an entirely new business infrastructure here in S.E. Asia called, Meliponiculture (propogation and culturing of the Stingless Honeybee).   Our research is designed to lead toward creation of new new jobs, help people find new sources of sustainable income through cultivation of 'green products' <Stingless Honeybees are considered a 'green product' and are a 'sustainable resource'>, and improve the economic condition of all peoples living in S.E. Asia .  Initially, our focus centers on activities that will be carried out in the Setui Wetlands Region near Jebi, and the Bukit Kor Research Station at UMT's second campus in Marang, both locations on Malaysia's beautiful N.E. seacoast adjoining the South China Sea.

story:
In the Beginning...

Eighteen years ago SolarFest was created from a dream (yes, literally!).  Today that dream would be fairly easy to accomplish, but eighteen years ago this dream was truly revolutionary. This was the birth of solar education on a new unchartered scale in Vermont and across New England. And indeed our founders were more than up to the challenge, they forged the way for what is now a thriving industry not only here in the beautiful hills of Vermont, but throughout the northeast. They proved it could be done, one festival at a time.

The concept has always been clear – provide education and hands-on experience with renewable energy sources and sustainable practices in an atmosphere of art and music. Bringing industry leaders, innovators, highly experienced users of renewable technologies and newcomers together in a family-friendly environment.  SolarFest demonstrates the possibility of a brighter planet in the bright, shiny package of great music, food, theater and family fun. This allows folks a weekend to relax, recharge and re-invent the way they look at energy, community, and their impact on the world.  Our goal is to encourage attendees and enthusiasts to become a part of the movement and embrace ideas and inspiration by spending a day, or all weekend in a fully renewable energy powered community seeing renewable solutions in use everywhere.

As we grew...

Over the years, we have become masters at combining superb family entertainment along with presentations by some of the region's most knowledgeable Renewable Energy and Sustainable Living experts.  We offer a special children's activity area (Kids Corner), and a wide variety of food, craft, renewable energy and sustainable living vendors. Our featured performers represent a far-ranging spectrum of styles and traditions from around the world. We provide plenty of space throughout the weekend for serendipitous encounters, conversation, dancing, hiking, camping, relaxation, and an overall celebration of our planet's beauty.

The premise is that real, concrete learning can only happen when all senses are stimulated and the creative side of people is allowed to come to the surface. Our event strives to provide the creative stimulation, a really great environment for learning, and countless things to learn, one weekend a year.  SolarFest has become a destination for information and inspiration by presenting our multiple messages basked in the glow of artful and creative experience. We strongly believe that this is the best vehicle for change in the world.

Ushering in the Next Generation...

Today one of our biggest challenges is not just trying to keep up with new technologies, but to bring them to our festival so that people can see them in action. Eighteen years ago it was almost impossible to find any solar electric or solar thermal installations, but today solar has become mainstream, Solar electric and solar thermal is in use in almost every community.  Even national retail stores are getting into the game, putting large-scale solar electric installations on their rooftops. Today energy efficiency is a hot topic. Hybrid and electric cars are no longer viewed as only for environmentalist hippies; it’s just plain practical, saving energy saves money and everyone wants to do it.

But how?

Which technologies are best for each individual and how do you get the best deal, or find the best source of information or learn what is the most appropriate technology for you?  That’s where SolarFest continues to fill the need. We give people the chance to learn and explore the latest technologies, to re-learn old traditions (re-skilling), to get their feet wet, and to gather with others who are interested in learning the same things. Everything we do at the festival is an educational opportunity. A three-day sustainability conference, with extensive hands-on, in-depth, beginner and advanced workshops, displays of new and innovative technologies, opportunities to sit and talk at length with experts in the field and see world-class performances, all powered by renewable energy.

The need for good information is as great as ever, and we are committed to redoubling our efforts to building our programming, to embrace and include all new technologies, to show the world that alternatives exist and they are affordable and practical, even in today’s busy world. But we need your help. With your backing and a successful Indiegogo campaign we will be able to reach more people and continue to do important work and maintain our affordable ticket prices. Our list for expansion includes:

  • Expand our reach and attract more and different people. We have made a strong commitment to keeping our ticket prices low so that we remain accessible to as many people as possible.
  • Keep our music top notch and world class. Many people come to the festival for the music, but when they look around and see a sustainable community and renewable energy technology in use they are inspired to live their lives in a more sustainable manner.
  • Expand our arts, theater and innovative technology opportunities both at our event and as an ongoing regional outreach program
  • Expand our conference workshop topics to include the newest technologies, more DIY options, more opportunities for industry trainings, and an expanded focus on climate change issues both at our event and through ongoing community outreach programs.
  • Make our workshops and educational content available year-round online, and on community public access television channels. 
  • Develop an online community resource for consumers to ask questions about renewable technologies and products and get honest, unbiased answers from industry experts and other members of the community.

This list is long, but we are confident that with your help, each item is within our reach. We have an unbelievable group of dedicated volunteers and staff, a completely committed board of trustees, and the work ethic to see this through. What we are lacking is the financial capacity to expand our vision. We hope you will share our enthusiasm and pledge your support.

We’ve come a long way in our eighteen years, but there is much more we can accomplish. There are so many people to reach and so much potential. Please help us continue to bring our unique and important brand of sustainability to the northeast and support SolarFest - The Next Generation.

Be sure to share our campaign through your social media connections to ensure that we can continue to share our important work with people throughout the Northeast.

Thank you for your support!

story:
A movement founded by an elementary school teacher –

Raging heat, dying crops, election year...time to act!

We start on August 27th at the Republican Convention in Tampa with our "Going Away Party for FLORIDA!"; then August 30th we launch our eight-day Hunger Strike: "A Taste of Things to Come! Global Warming Famine Practice".  We'll tour colleges in Florida, Georgia, and North and South Carolina, before heading to the Democratic Convention in Charlotte.  It all culminates after the President's speech on September 6th.  Join us if you can! 

Every dollar raised is going to provide basic needs of the demonstrators from 8/26-9/7/12 (except FOOD)!

Thank you for contributing and sharing this on FaceBook and Twitter.  Soon, you can join “Pissed-off Polar Bears” on Meetup.com to have a way to take bold action in your community every single day!

:D

story:
Youthaiti - Building a Healthier Future in Rural Haiti

Youthaiti is a 501 (c) (3) non-profit organization, now in its sixth year of helping people in rural Haiti develop sustainable sanitation and hygiene, and encouraging the recycling of human byproducts to enhance sustainable agriculture.

We need your help to complete the next phase of building our Center For Sustainable Development in the village of Duchity, in the southwestern Haitian province of Grand'Anse.

The Youthaiti Center for Sustainable Development will spread our reach in the rural communities of southwest Haiti – far from the aid efforts centered in large cities – and will help more people develop practical, sustainable ways to break the cycles of poverty and disease that destroy far too many lives each year.

THE PROBLEM

When Gigi Pomerantz first visited Haiti in 2006 as a visiting health-care provider, she quickly learned that 85 percent of rural Haitians practice “open defecation” – in other words, they have no toilets at all, and feces and urine end up anywhere and everywhere. This often leads to the rapid spread of pathogens and parasites. More than 10 percent of Haitian children under the age of 5 die each year because inadequate sanitation is so pervasive in rural areas. Adults and children alike in many communities are infected with worms, chronic diarrhea and dangerous diseases, including  cholera, which can kill a person in hours without diagnosis and proper treatment.

Pomerantz founded Youthaiti in the town of Duchity, in the southwest Haitian province of Grand'Anse -- home to the the country's last indigenous forest land -- to help young people overcome these often devastating problems.

WHAT WE'VE DONE SO FAR

Youthaiti provides sanitation facilities and community education in hygiene and sustainable agriculture methods in Grand'Anse. So far: 

  • We've trained more than 120 community-based health workers in principles of ecological sanitation, improved hygiene, and the prevention, identification and treatment of diseases spread by inadequate disposal of human feces and urine.

  • We've funded and built more than 15 “dry toilets” in rural community centers, which safely collect feces and urine so they can be treated and used as safe and effective agricultural fertilizer.





  • We've installed more than 120 “Arborloo” latrines that trap feces and urine below ground and beneath a concrete cap, where it can biodegrade safely. In time the waste turns into fertilizer, and the former arborloo site becomes home to a fruit tree or other beneficial planting.

WHERE WE GO FROM HERE

Youthaiti is building a permanent home in Duchity to continue providing sanitation, education and agriculture assistance in the community, and to extend our work to other communites in the region.

The Youthaiti Center for Sustainable Development will serve as our base of operations, an education center, as a community gathering place, and as accommodations for people who travel from other communities for a day or a week of training programs.

The Center will provide many young Haitians with their first "hands on" experience with ecological technologies including rainwater harvesting, ecological toilets, permaculture gardening and using earthworms to improve composting.

Phase One of the project is complete. Thanks to support from donors in the United States and the work of our staff and volunteers in Grand'Anse, we've acquired land and built the concrete foundation for our future home.

(See for yourself at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_tDU64Fqi4I)

We need your help to complete Phase Two: erecting the first section of the structure including kitchen and dining facilities, temporary sleeping space, equipment for composting, seed beds for future gardens and -- you guessed it -- an arborloo with handwashing facilities. 

The cost of this phase is $10,000.

Future phases will include:

Phase Three: Adding a large meeting room, a resource room and an indoor composting toilet, as well as starting a demonstration "permaculture" site using recycled human byproducts as fertilizer.

Phase Four: Building dormitory facilities for guests and a second indoor toilet.

Phase Five: Adding office space, additional sleeping quarters and a conference room, installing a third compostiung toilet and creating a rooftop solar array.

For more information visit us at:

www.youthaiti.org

story:
Our first campaign is finished and has been so successful thanks to all who have shared our vision and donated generously!

The campaign has attracted private donors and investors and WE HAVE BEEN ABLE TO MEET OUR GOAL to plant the first batch of 1000 trees!

 

THANK YOU ARGAN CO-CREATORS!!!!

 


Update, Spring 2014:

Interested in becoming part of our project for the next round, our planting of 750 argan trees in April 2014? 

The pioneering nature of our work has been recognised as research and we are now working with a recognised non-profit organisation to further research argan varieties suitable for our region. Donations are eligible for tax-deductions.

You can contact us at: arganhanegev@gmail.com for instructions as to how to donate and receive a tax deduction or donate directly on our web site without a deduction: www.arganofthenegev.com


 

 

 

 

The Argan tree

is a very special tree- it has roots that can reach 70 meters (about 210 feet!) into the earth. One of the oldest trees on this planet, it is called "the tree of life" in its native Morocco. It has very specific cultivation needs that are identical with our conditions here in the town of Mitzpe Ramon in the Negev desert. 

Besides being a great ecological boon, this tree has been only recently discovered by the West and the market prices reflect the value of its product: precious argan oil.

For those who dont know about argan oil yet, take a look at this video about one product made from argan oil from Morocco. Although the product is produced in Israel all of their oil is being imported, it is not from Israel (yet). 

We look forward with great joy to not only plant this tree here in the Negev desert but also be part of the unfolding of this tree's potential as we discover more uses for the healthful oil and other parts of the tree.



Argan of the Negev

is a pilot project. We have received a parcel of land in the Negev desert outside of the town of Mitzpe Ramon in Israel. This land was used for military training but is being converted to agriculture. A real example of turning swords into plowshares!

Many other families will also be receiving plots to farm here. We hope to prove to both these families and to the government that the best possible use of the land in terms of water usage, ecology and income is argan. We hope to spark an argan industry here that will completely turn around our local economy and make it possible for more and more people to move away from Israel's overpopulated center to the Negev. This is the dream of the prophets, the Vilna Gaon, Ben Gurion and ourselves. It is time!

Argan has been grown as a research crop for over 25 years in Israel successfully but now it is time to test it in our particular climate and soil as a cash crop- only then will it be listed on the government approved list of crops and other families who come after us will receive partial funding aid from the government. This will open the door to a boost here that will lead to opportunity for many.

 

Sponsor a tree!

When we green the desert we are bringing the Spirit of God to rest on the wasteland. Any person who supports this work shares in the Mitzvah and in the blessing. May we all be blessed!

Participate in the Mitzvah according to your means. You and only you know what your means are. But do participate, as much as you are able! 

 

Please note!!!

You can give any particular amount that you would like by clicking the category that is lower than that amount and then manually writing in the amount that you would like to give, so it is possible to give, say, $25 or $273. The $18 category actually means "$18 and above", etc.

You can pay with credit card or Paypal.

 

Pass this on!

with a personal recommendation to others.

 


Our web site has much more interesting things about our project, take a look!!

arganofthenegev.com

 

Questions?

contact us at: arganhanegev@gmail.com
story_txt:
Our first campaign is finished and has been so successful thanks to all who have shared our vision and donated generously!
The campaign has attracted private donors and investors and WE HAVE BEEN ABLE TO MEET OUR GOAL to plant the first batch of 1000 trees!
 
THANK YOU ARGAN CO-CREATORS!!!!

story:
The Project

In 2010 we bought an 8 acre plot of land next to a small town called Lucio V. López near Rosario City. Through our project, Suelo Común, we hope to create a place where multiple food crops coexist -from groundcovers to edible trees, everything in between- by exploring different natural organic farming techniques such as crop rotation and high diversity plantation, which will not only promote healthier plants, but also enrich the soil.

The Suelo Común Project is a place where we will put into practice all aspects of ecological living. This includes green construction, rain water collection and grey water recycling, reforestation, an arboretum of native trees, a place to promote sustainable farming, a horticulture book library, and a seed bank; all of which will be available to the local community for free. This project has short and long term goals. The most immediate need is to buy tools, build and irrigation system and a greenhouse where we can start a plant nursery. This nursery will help finance our long-term goals. Later on we will need to finish the shelter where the library will be housed and a space where we can stay to work on the land for longer periods of time.



The money will specifically be used to purchase tools, material and equipment to build the structure of the greenhouse and the irrigation system. In the event that we raise over the $7,000 goal, the extra money will be used to start buying fruit trees for the edible forest and to complete the shelter. You can stay tuned to the project’s developments through our blog and Facebook page.

suelocomun.blogspot.com.ar

www.facebook.com/suelocomun

Adrián has also kept a Facebook page with lots of pictures with all we were able to accomplish so far...

www.facebook.com/AmadoBuenaPlanta

With your donations, we can make this project come to life. When you support Suelo Común, you will be supporting the promotion of natural farming practices, small family businesses, community building, and an invaluable resource, which will make an impact on the local community. Thank you for joining us in our effort to contribute to bring back old natural farming practices, something our grandparents knew well how to do…

story:
In 2012/13 hundreds of Wolves lost their lives to Bow hunters, Shooters, Hunters, trappers and hounds. Not to mention the Wolves killed by cars and those not accounted for by greedy killers.
 The Hunt Saboteurs have been active for years in the States and for over 50 years in the UK, defending wildlife, standing between hunter and hunted.
  This year Wisconsin has opened hunting Wolves with hounds, already hounds are being trained. Many Dogs, Wolves and Wolf pups will lose their lives in this barbaric act of so called "hunting"!
  This year we need your help with donations (monetary and supplies) so we can remain active in the field.

  The Funding we need go's directly towards monitoring Hunting areas, fuel, vehicle maintenance, none perishable food, basic supplies, two way radios, camping gear and warm clothing.
We'd also be quite happy to receive any of these items as gifts towards the campaign and future campaigns, below is a list of items we need.
 Non perishable Vegan food.
Gentle used or new, warm clothing and Camping gear (meant for colder weather).
2 way radios (so we can communicate with each other while in the field).
Gas cards.
Food cards.
4x4 vehicle/s.
Vehicle maintenance.
Cookware (meant for outdoors cooking).
Night vision goggles.
Telescope.
GPS device.
Binoculars .


   With your help we hope to have a stronger presence in the field and no Wolves will be killed.
  We also realize not everyone is able to make a donation, so we ask that you use your Facebook pages and any online social media to make aware of the needless Wolf slaughter, We ask that you share our request for donations, take the time to write emails and make phone calls sharing your disappointment in this senseless and unnecessary killing.
  Wolves are essential!

story:
Our parks, open spaces and recreational facilities are critical public resources that enhance urban life. They are essential to sustain our health and well-being. SFPA envisions a park system in San Francisco that supports this critical environmental function. Street Parks -- city-owned spaces that are adopted, beautified and activated by community volunteers -- are a crucial part of San Francisco’s park system.  

What We Need & What You Get

The San Francisco Parks Alliance (SFPA) needs you!

$4,000 will help the Parks Alliance fund the Street Parks Program; a program that enables and assists community groups in transforming neglected city owned parcels into verdant gardens, community gathering spaces, and habitat.

The Street Parks Program is a partnership between SFPA and the Department of Public Works (DPW) which supports the development and maintenance of  community-managed open spaces on DPW owned land.

Funds raised from this campaign will go towards general support for the Street Parks program. Your donation will provide crucial support to neighborhood groups doing greening, including needed tools and native plants. Funds will also support gardening education workshops as well as the dispatch of the Clean & Green Crew to assist in maintaining these community spaces.

With your donation, you are eligible for either a tote bag, an SFPA hat or a Limited Edition SFPA Parke Diem t-shirt.

    The Impact

    San Francisco residents are incredibly lucky to have access to more than 300 parks within our 49 square miles, but some neighborhoods have less access to parks and greenery than others. The San Francisco Parks Alliance mission is to inspire and promote civic engagement and philanthropy to protect, sustain and enrich San Francisco parks, recreation and green open spaces.  With your help, SFPA will be able to enrich existing parks and also create new patches of green within our concrete jungle.

    Since the Street Parks program's inception in 2004, 125 community green spaces have been developed.  There are Street Park sites in every district of San Francisco. Each Street Park is created to meet the needs of the community that develops it. Street Parks function as ornamental gardens, agricultural sites, places of recreation, community meeting spaces and wildlife habitat -- maintaining public access and meeting community needs are the only major requirements.  

    SFPA and DPW staff celebrating the 10th Anniversary of the Street Parks Program. 

    Street Park Program benefits:

    • Beautifies neighborhoods and improves quality of life.

    • Activates under-utilized spaces and created opportunities for recreation

    • Provides an opportunity for community groups to envision and create a customized park that addresses their specific neighborhood needs

    • Increases biodiversity and enhances habitat

    • Builds community and healthy residents

    • Decreases incidences of blight and unwanted behaviors such as illegal dumping, and increases safety in neighborhoods

    • Enhances the value of adjacent properties

    To learn more about the Street Parks Program, visit our website:  http://sfparksalliance.org/our-work/stewardship...

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Volunteer! Email us at volunteer@sfparksalliance.org for more info about volunteer opportunities.

      Help us enrich our parks by sharing our Giving Tuesday campaign with your friends on Facebook and Twitter!

story:
*Click the Updates tab to see how the programme is developing!*


In a Nutshell.

A one year research programme carried out at University College London, to explore new and more efficient ways of harnessing the chemical energy in algae and plants and coverting it into electrical energy. The intention is to understand whether bioelectricity can compete with electricity currently produced through coal, oil and gas. The research would look into how to extract more electrons, more efficiently in algae by designing and producing a series of catalytic cells. From there, the potential of plants for bioelectrical production will be explored, by comparing with algae and seeing whether a series of apparatuses can be produced to extract starch to use in fuel cells. The research would concern the economic viability of bioelectricity as well as its capacity to produce a viable volume against current electrical production. A final study would be carried out to see how bioelectricity can be efficiently utilised in a city, through smart technology and urban design. 

Why Your Help is Needed.

This is a huge opportunity for you to be part of an exciting and important cause. As you can imagine the programme will come across huge challenges to tackle due to its highly ambitious goals. The goals are achievable. The programme will be worked on for over 12 hours a day by committed people, who are passionate and experts in their fields. But your help is needed to meet the financial demands of the programme. 

Currently, the programme is hugely underfunded, with the University unable to financially support it. Basic equipments are required such as a computer that is powerful enough to process huge amounts of data and support 3d modelling and analytical software. Other equipments required are recording equipment, both for photographic and data recording. The need to prototype several apparatuses will require the purchase of materials and specialist robotics components. The travel costs are huge as some biomass samples are very difficult to get obtain through the usual means, so collection will be required in person by travelling abroad. Everything mentioned so far is the tip of the iceberg. As with all research programmes, new paths will be explored as the programme matures and so new hurdles will spring up that will require a certain response. Every penny donated to this programme, will ensure the challenges are overcome quickly and effectively in order to resume the quest to achieving a viable option for bioelectricity. 

A series of perks have been set for this campaign to allow you have an immersive experience and be part of the team. Not only will you be mentioned on the website and end of year report, but you will receive your very own catalytic cell which you can use to obtain electrical energy from algae! The more you contribute the more you will get! The highest contributors will even get their own sample of algae! 

Contribute to be part of an exciting cause and learn about the thrilling science behind bioelectricity. This programme is exploring new and dramatic ideas and has the potential to provide fruitful solutions to many of our modern day issues. Be part of that team.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Everyone is invited to be part of the team. Both financial contributors and non-financial contributors. Spreading the word about this campaign is as important as donating the much needed cash. Be active. Tell your friends, family and colleagues, in person, through social media and even mention it over the phone. The quicker we can get the funding in place, the quicker we can sink our teeth into the research and fully grasp the challenges. 

    Lets save our planet. Together.

story:
Mon rêve de petite fille...

Je me prénomme Kathleen Goulet, j'ai 21 ans (et trop bientôt 22), je suis étudiante en dernière année à l'Université d'Ottawa en Géographie. Une chose à dire: J'ADORE ÇA. La géographie m'a fait grandir, découvrir le monde, et m'a fait voir et comprendre l'Homme d'un autre oeil. 

Depuis que je suis toute jeune, mon rêve était d'aller à l'Université. Lorsqu'à la petite école on nous a demandé d'économiser, alors que mes collègues ramassaient leurs petits changes pour s'acheter le nouveau Nintendo, moi, du haut de mes 10 ans, je gardais mon argent pour un jour étudier à l'Université. Ce fut mon premier rêve, écrit en gros dans mon tout premier carnet de compte Desjardins. 

Aujourd'hui, je ne suis peut-être plus la petite fille de 10 ans qui rêvait de devenir avocate, mais je suis toujours aussi passionnée. Apprendre m'apporte tellement, j'en savoure encore toutes les couleurs. Dans moins d'un an, je vais pouvoir cocher « check » à mon rêve de petite fille et tenir fièrement mon diplôme entre mes mains. 

À l'aube de mes 22 ans (3 mars prochain oh la la), j'ai entrepris un projet qui me tient beaucoup à coeur, un autre rêve de petite fille, mais un peu plus refoulé. Curieuse et passionnée de nature, le monde m'a toujours intéressé. Les gens dans le bus à coté de moi, comme ceux de l'autre coté de l'océan, j'aime les gens d'amour <3. J'ai toujours voulu sortir de ma zone de confort pour aller apprendre de l'autre, partager une culture, des savoirs et des regards. 

De la géographie à l'environnement en passant par la solidarité internationale

Mon BACC en géographie me permet aujourd'hui de réaliser cela. À travers ces nouvelles connaissances géographiques sur l'Homme, j'en suis arrivée à aimer la terre d'amour aussi. L'environnement qui nous entoure est précieux et mes études m'ont permis de vraiment le comprendre. Il était important que mon dernier stage soit en lien avec l'environnement. 

Grâce au programme Québec Sans Frontière (http://www.mrifce.gouv.qc.ca/qsf/) et le Comité Régional d'Éducation pour le Développement International de Lanaudière (http://www.credil.qc.ca/), j'ai donc la chance de partir cet été avec 8 autres jeunes (tous aussi passionnés), dans la région d'Ayacucho au Pérou pour réaliser un stage de solidarité internationale en lien avec l’environnement, la santé et l'énergie thermique.

Nous allons concevoir et installer, en partenariat avec la population locale, des chauffe-eaux solaires. Ces chauffe-eaux, fait à partir de matériaux recyclés, auront pour but de réduire l’exposition aux matières toxiques issues de la combustion liée au réchauffement de l’eau destinée à la consommation familiale. La pollution de l’air intérieur due à la combustion a des effets nocifs sur la santé des gens. Ce projet contribuera aussi à l'assainissement de l'environnement local dans cette communauté puisque nous participerons à mettre sur pieds des collectes de déchets organiques et inorganiques, et nous offrirons des ateliers de sensibilisation en matière de santé et d'environnement. 

Pour mener à terme ce projet, chaque stagiaire s'engage à amasser une somme de 2000$, en date d'aujourd'hui, il me reste environ 1000$ à amasser. Cet argent servira strictement à porter à terme notre super projet, ce montant ne couvre que les frais relatifs au séjour à l'étranger. 

Comprendre ailleurs pour agir ici

Ce projet me tiens à coeur et je tiens à le partager avec vous. Votre appuie et vos dons me permettraient, oui de réaliser un rêve, mais aussi de créer un projet innovateur avec la communauté de San Melchor et mon équipe du tonnerre. 

Ce projet en lien avec la santé, l'environnement et l'énergie thermique est oui certainement une occasion de partager et d'échanger nos connaissances scientifiques avec les gens du Pérou, mais c'est aussi l'occasion de s'immerger dans une autre culture, de la vivre et de la comprendre. Le changement il ne se fera pas au Pérou, on ne part pas pour changer les autres, on part pour revenir et changer ici dans notre communauté. Comme le dis si bien le slogan du CRÉDIL, il faut comprendre ailleurs pour agir ici. 

Participez vous aussi à ce projet

Ce projet vous tient aussi à coeur? Participez y en m'aidant dans mes levées de fonds. Vos dons seront appréciés, mais votre soutien encore plus. N'hésitez pas à partager mon projet avec vos amis, collègues et connaissances. 

De plus, suiviez nous durant tout notre séjour en pays péruvien en vous rendant sur notre page facebook. 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Projet-P%C3%A9rou-2014-San-Melchor/694074343947980
story_txt:
Mon rêve de petite fille...
Je me prénomme Kathleen Goulet, j'ai 21
ans (et trop bientôt 22), je suis étudiante en dernière année à l'Université
d'Ottawa en Géographie. Une chose à dire: J'ADORE ÇA. La géographie m'a fait
grandir, découvrir le monde, et m'a fait voir et comprendre l'Homme d'un autre oeil. 
Depuis que je suis toute jeune, mon rêve
était d'aller à l'Université. Lorsqu'à la petite école on nous a demandé
d'économiser, alors que mes collègues ramassaient leurs petits changes pour
s'acheter le nouveau Nintendo, moi, du haut de mes 10 ans, je gardais mon
argent pour un jour étudier à l'Université. Ce fut mon premier rêve, écrit en
gros dans mon tout premier carnet de compte Desjardins. 
Aujourd'hui, je ne suis peut-être plus
la petite fille de 10 ans qui rêvait de devenir avocate, mais je suis toujours
aussi passionnée. Apprendre m'apporte tellement, j'en savoure encore toutes les
couleurs. Dans moins d'un an, je vais pouvoir cocher « check » à mon
rêve de petite fille et tenir fièrement mon diplôme entre mes mains. 

À l'aube de mes 22
ans (3 mars prochain oh la la), j'ai entrepris un projet qui me tient beaucoup
à coeur, un autre rêve de petite fille, mais un peu plus refoulé. Curieuse et
passionnée de nature, le monde m'a toujours intéressé. Les gens dans le bus à
coté de moi, comme ceux de l'autre coté de l'océan, j'aime les gens d'amour
<3. J'ai toujours voulu sortir de ma zone de confort pour aller apprendre de l'autre, partager une culture, des savoirs et des
regards. De la géographie à l'environnement en passant par la solidarité internationale
Mon BACC en géographie me permet
aujourd'hui de réaliser cela. À travers ces nouvelles connaissances
géographiques sur l'Homme, j'en suis arrivée à aimer la terre d'amour aussi.
L'environnement qui nous entoure est précieux et mes études m'ont permis de
vraiment le comprendre. Il était important que mon dernier stage soit en
lien avec l'environnement. 
Grâce au programme Québec Sans Frontière
(http://www.mrifce.gouv.qc.ca/qsf/) et le Comité Régional d'Éducation pour le Développement
International de Lanaudière (http://www.credil.qc.ca/), j'ai donc la
chance de partir cet été avec 8 autres jeunes (tous aussi passionnés), dans la
région d'Ayacucho au Pérou pour réaliser un stage de solidarité internationale
en lien avec l’environnement, la santé et l'énergie thermique.
Nous allons concevoir et installer, en
partenariat avec la population locale, des chauffe-eaux solaires. Ces
chauffe-eaux, fait à partir de matériaux recyclés, auront pour but de réduire
l’exposition aux matières toxiques issues de la combustion liée au
réchauffement de l’eau destinée à la consommation familiale. La pollution de
l’air intérieur due à la combustion a des effets nocifs sur la santé des gens.
Ce projet contribuera aussi à l'assainissement de l'environnement local dans
cette communauté puisque nous participerons à mettre sur pieds des collectes de
déchets organiques et inorganiques, et nous offrirons des ateliers de
sensibilisation en matière de santé et d'environnement. 
Pour mener à terme ce projet, chaque stagiaire
s'engage à amasser une somme de 2000$, en date d'aujourd'hui, il me reste
environ 1000$ à amasser. Cet argent servira strictement à porter à terme notre
super projet, ce montant ne couvre que les frais relatifs au séjour à
l'étranger. 
Comprendre ailleurs pour agir ici
Ce projet me tiens à coeur et je tiens à
le partager avec vous. Votre appuie et vos dons me permettraient, oui de
réaliser un rêve, mais aussi de créer un projet innovateur avec la communauté
de San Melchor et mon équipe du tonnerre. 
Ce projet en lien avec la santé,
l'environnement et l'énergie thermique est oui certainement une occasion de
partager et d'échanger nos connaissances scientifiques avec les gens du Pérou,
mais c'est aussi l'occasion de s'immerger dans une autre culture, de la vivre
et de la comprendre. Le changement il ne se fera pas au Pérou, on ne part pas
pour changer les autres, on part pour revenir et changer ici dans notre
communauté. Comme le dis si bien le slogan du CRÉDIL, il faut comprendre
ailleurs pour agir ici. 
Participez vous aussi à ce projet
Ce projet vous tient aussi à coeur?
Participez y en m'aidant dans mes levées de fonds. Vos dons seront appréciés,
mais votre soutien encore plus. N'hésitez pas à partager mon projet avec vos
amis, collègues et connaissances. 
De plus, suiviez nous durant tout notre séjour en pays péruvien en vous rendant
sur notre page facebook. 
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Projet-P%C3%A9rou-2014-San-Melchor/694074343947980

story:
Mining for Hope*


My Story

I am from Newton, Massachusetts—a sub-city of Boston. It is fairly urban and one has to go out of their way to be immersed in a wilderness setting, but this slight disconnect heightened my curiosity for it and strengthened the inert magnetism my soul felt towards nature. 

At a young age I realized that there was so much more to life than the prescribed steps many tended to follow. I saw unhappy people spending their time on this magnificent planet doing things they didn’t care about—constantly on the move from one passionless commitment to the next. I decided to never settle for a life like that and gained a drive to spend my time on earth being happy and helping make others happy. 

I looked up to change-makers and influential members in social movements like Martin Luther King, Mohandas Gandhi, and Steve Irwin. Their resilience and fiery passion inspired me. I knew that if I wanted to make positive changes in the world, I had to get out in the world to make it happen. 

In mid-May 2014 I graduated from the University of New Hampshire with a bachelor’s in English. Throughout my four years at the university, I was heavily involved in environmental and social activism, and during my senior year I was the Tar Sands Campaign Coordinator for the UNH Student Environmental Action Coalition. 

When I first learned about tar sands two years ago, I immediately became an avid opponent. I have always loved and respected the environment, so after seeing photographs of the strip-mining in Alberta destroying an area the size of Florida, I couldn't stand idle and passively let this occur. So in spring 2013, I attended the Forward on Climate rally in D.C. and then in spring 2014, I attended the XL Dissent rally in D.C. In the fall of 2013 I organized a stop at UNH for the Tar Sands Exposed: Speakers Tour created by 350 Maine.


My Project

The tragic and dire conditions directly caused by the tar sands industry have fueled my passion to act against it, so I decided to take to the road. Since Monday, June 16th, 2014, I have been traveling through the United States and Canada. I have been stopping at frontline communities affected by different aspects of the tar sands industry, such as Chicago, IL where communities are living near petroleum coke

, which is one of the by-products of the tar sands refining process, and Wisconsin where people are living near the mining sites for frac-sand

—silica sand is used in hydraulic-fracturing for tar sands, as well as, conventional oil. 

I traveled to Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada to attend the fifth and final Athabasca Healing Walk to get a first person view of tar sands excavation and how it has deeply affected First Nations communities. After spending two weeks in Canada, I will be traveling to PR Springs in Eastern Utah to join the activists who set up a permanent camp at the proposed tar sands excavation site--the first in the United States. From July 15-22, I will attend the Summer for Climate Justice project at the Utah excavation site, where students and other young people will learn about organizing, relationship building, direct action, and the cultivation of a climate justice analysis.  

My goal is to shed light on this devastating issue by emphasizing the personal stories of the human beings who are directly affected. My hope is that these stories, along with pictures and videos, will tug at the heartstrings of every person who takes the time to engage with them.


*MINING. Verb.: Delve into (an abundant source) to extract something of value, especially information or skill. 

HOPE. Noun.: A feeling of trust.

In this world there is a lot to question and speculate, and a lot to mistrust. Bigwig corporations and governments heavily influence and force ways of life onto us, such as to create and elevate our consumerist and materialist habits and high-energy needs. Society constructs what "success" is and it involves owning all types of stuff. All of this stuff comes with consequences, many of which some people are unaware. To produce all of the stuff we are told we need, a lot of energy and resources are necessary. Because our main source of energy is from fossil fuels, a finite resource, there is no practical hope in continuing to depend on them. 

The most direct and efficient way of extracting fossil fuels has reached its demise because of the lack of easily-accessible free-flowing oil. Today oil companies use toxic and deadly methods of strip-mining and in-situ hydraulic fracturing (fracking) to excavate tar sands and oil deep in the ground. These processes use fresh water and chemicals, which take drinking water away from frontline communities and pollutes what little water they have left. 

While oil companies are getting rich and some people are able to power their unnecessary products, other people are dying and the environment is depleting. 


Let's make it right. Will you join me in mining for hope, not oil?  


For a better understanding of tar sands and why I'm campaigning against it, here is a short compilation video of three animated shorts from the documentary H2Oil: 

What I Need & What You Get

From the generous donations I receive for my project, I will be able to travel to Illinois, Canada, Utah, and other places where front line communities are. I will also be able to acquire necessary supplies and equipment in order to successfully document the communities' stories--audio recorder and video camera. The funds will also help with any publication or printing costs needed to spread the stories far and wide. You may notice that my fundraising goal is a tad low, but that is because it is the bare-bone amount needed, however I would like to receive more than my fundraising goal in order to more seamlessly achieve my goals. 

Because I am fundraising for this project, I don't have much, as far as material items, to give back to people who donate, however you will have helped me illuminate the stories of victims pushed into the shadows by Big Oil, and hopefully that will suffice. (But even I like to get some type of physical gratitude once in a while, so there are some goodies for those who donate.)  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate money, don't worry! All I ask is that you help spread the word! Share my fundraising page and story to colleagues, friends, and family! 

Please follow my blog by clicking here!

You can also follow my project on twitter @Mining4Hope and 'LIKE' my facebook page here! 

#mine4hope #tarsandsfree

story:
A Green Roof for the Educational & Research Center for Permaculture in Sermenin

 

Who we are?

Hi. We're The Green Ark. We are a grass-root organization from Skopje, Macedonia. We are about 15 people all joined together with a single goal: to protect, preserve and improve upon our surrounding environment. Starting from 2007 we are actively working in accordance with the principles of Permaculture to make a difference in peoples everyday lives by giving workshops on making organic soap, building herb spirals, building with straw bales, methods of composting, filtration of water, making seed balls, guerrilla gardening... 

Our current project is to establish the first Educational & Research Center for Permaculture in our country. We have already jump-started the project by organizing a fundraising concert asking for local support, but as you are well aware, a project of this size and the reconstruction itself can be quite expensive. That is why we turn to you, all the environmentally aware eco-logicians and naturally generous people out there to join us and help us raise the much needed funds. We simply need your help.

 

What is the project about?

After two years of negotiations, the local authorities have granted us the use of a former school building over the next 20 years for the purpose of establishing the Educational & Research Center for Permaculture. The agreement is that we take care of the reconstruction of the object dating from the 1930s, and it is completely up to us to make it operational again. We are now taking step one, and that is to reconstruct the roof and convert it into a green roof.

Our plan is to initiate parts of the educational program that can be applied through hands-on experience during the reconstruction of the object itself by organizing workshops for restoration and refurbishment with minimal impact to the environment. We will explore the posibilities to engage people who want to learn and practice these building techniques and appropriate technologies, and will seize each opportunity to turn every single step of the process of establishing the Educational & Research Center for Permaculture into a learning experience open for all who want to do it.

 

The Impact 

The work done in the Center will incite significant positive changes, over the years to come, in the community of the village Sermenin and the region by empowering people to make their first steps in the transition towards self-sustainability within healthy ecosystems. We will be inviting people all over the world to learn and exchange knowledge & experience with us and the local population. The Educational & Research Center for Permaculture in Sermenin will grow to be the hub of numerous environmental, social, cultural and economic initiatives in the region, supporting diverse innovative collaborations. You could take part in the growth as well! 

 

What we are asking for?

- We are looking for help & funds to reconstruct the roof of the school building

- Fixing the roof will really help get the ball rolling for the whole project

- A fixed roof allows the rest of the building to get refurbished on time 

- An operational building will provide working space and shelter to students, as well as, storage for material & equipment

So we're turning to you to support our efforts by asking for your kind and generous contributions. In exchange, we're offering you the opportunity to learn and practice Permaculture with us, adopt a beehive, get hands-on experience and hand made soap to wash it down, taste berries, fruits, honey... Your contribution will help us to reconstruct the roof in a sustainable manner using appropriate technologies, not harming the environment extensively during the process, and further, it will help us to continue with the work on establishing the first Educational & Research Center for Permaculture in Macedonia. 

As a kind thank you for your help and support we will give our best to make you a part of this rewarding and beneficial project.

 

Cost breakdown:

This is the estimation of the cost, and how we plan to implement the funds for the reconstruction:

Type of roof

or

Material

Roof surface

or

Cubic meters

Price per m2

or

per m3

Total per item

Green roof

225 m2

 

50 €

or

63 $

11250 €

or

14,185 $

Timber for beams & posts

17 m3

 

200 €

or

252 $

3400 €

or

4,285 $

Total cost of the green roof & timber  

 

 

14650 €

or

18,470 $

 

Transport

~ 1000 €

or

~ 1,260 $

Expert supervisor

~ 2000 €

or

~ 2,518 $

 

As you can see from the table above, we need to raise over 20000 dollars, if we take into acount the additional costs for the transport and the expert supervisor, to cover the cost of reconstructing the roof of the almost ruined building of the future Educational & Research Center for Permaculture. Otherwise the structure might not remain standing over the next winter.

We are firmly determined to establish the Educational & Research Center for Permaculture in Sermenin. In case we do not reach the final amount we asked for, any amount raised will still be used to buy the materials needed for the reconstruction. The same applies if we are fortunate to receive a greater amount than we asked for, it will all be invested in the following stages of reconstruction on the other parts of the building.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools, so more people get involved!

What are you waiting for?

Hop into our Green Ark and let’s sail together towards the first Educational & Research Center for Permaculture in Macedonia!

Thank you for the support!

story:
From Kevin Douglas, Stanford University Law student

The majority of students at Stanford University are oblivious to the subtle yet critical role that fossil fuels play in their lives.  Until recently, I was personally unaware of the central role that fossil fuels play in, for example, the production of the abundant food that we enjoy, and unaware of the direct role that fossil fuels have historically played in improving the human environment.  I was made aware of these facts thanks to the work of Alex Epstein, founder and president of the Center for Industrial Progress.  I am working to bring Alex to Stanford University to help inform my fellow students--by setting up a debate between him and Sierra Club Senior Director Bruce Nilles.  I hope to increase the number of smart, ambitious young people who support the idea of a free market in energy.

This fund raiser will help me pay for the speakers, realize the highest potential turnout, record the event for future distribution, and organize the most informative debate possible. 

The Highest Potential Turnout

The event will be open to the public, and a portion of the funds will be used to market the event to individuals in and around Stanford using social media.  Additionally, your contributions will allow us to fund a direct marketing campaign to maximize our turnout.

Recording the Event for Future Distribution

Your contributions will allow us to produce a high quality video recording of the debate for future distribution, and will allow us to live stream the event.

Do you want to see Alex Epstein debate the Sierra Club, one of the two leading environmentalist organizations in the world? Do you want to make sure that some of America's top students see it, as well? Then please support this debate.

--Kevin Douglas

PS on Perks

Since I am a full-time student I don't have the resources to offer the usual assortment of perks that come with crowd-funding.

But I hope you agree with me that the excitement of this debate, and the low cost at which we are able to put it together, are by themselves great reasons to contribute.

One exception: Alex has offered to invite any donors at $250 or above to join us for a post-debate celebratory dinner.

This fund raiser will help me pay for the speakers, realize the highest potential turnout, record the event for future distribution, and organize the most informative debate possible. 
The Highest Potential Turnout
The event will be open to the public, and a portion of the funds will be used to market the event to individuals in and around Stanford using social media.  Additionally, your contributions will allow us to fund a direct marketing campaign to maximize our turnout.
Recording the Event for Future Distribution
Your contributions will allow us to produce a high quality video recording of the debate for future distribution, and will allow us to live stream the event.
Do you want to see Alex Epstein debate the Sierra Club, one of the two leading environmentalist organizations in the world? Do you want to make sure that some of America's top students see it, as well? Then please support this debate.
--Kevin Douglas
PS on Perks
Since I am a full-time student I don't have the resources to offer the usual assortment of perks that come with crowd-funding.
But I hope you agree with me that the excitement of this debate, and the low cost at which we are able to put it together, are by themselves great reasons to contribute.
One exception: Alex has offered to invite any donors at $250 or above to join us for a post-debate celebratory dinner.

story:
Swing City GROW 2.0

Many, many miles from the ocean front sands of Santa Monica Muscle Beach, Swing City creates a home away from home, in the sands of the Nevada desert.

We bring “The Traveling Rings” to Burning Man. It encourages us to evolve as a collective on an annual basis. The travails we experience bring about a drive to persevere & transition into a creative process that is much more than just a “holiday”; it is art in motion.


On our third year of bringing “The Rings” to Black Rock City, we seek to generate a legacy of sustainability that will reduce our carbon footprint for many years to come.  We will be a strong example of the “leave no trace” environmental motto that has been a consistent challenge in the Burning Man community. This is our highest priority.

We are going solar and marking 2012 as the year we create our own sustainable power structure. Through the good will of the BMORG, we have obtained a much more prominent placement on The Playa. As such, light and power needs for our fair city have increased substantially, to maintain the safety of the entire community.

 

The Impact of your contribution; Solar Energy harnessed for years to come! 

We can’t do this alone, so we seek the help of our friends, family and enthusiasts of the gymnastic / aerial arts community who understand the relevance of what we seek to manifest.

Below is a list of the items we will be purchasing with the funds we raise on this campaign;
Our Solar Power System requires up to 500 watts, 8 hours per night

- Solar Panels (500 watts)
- Power Inverter (800 - 1000 watts)
- Batteries (Four Deep Cycle Marine 12V Batts)
- Charge Controller
- Parts for wiring and racks  
- Solar stands

Any size of contribution is greatly appreciated. With that said, we have created a raffle giveaway to offer as reciprocation for your generous donations as a way of expressing our thanks!

story:
Saving the Rhino and Why YOU should get involved:

"Each and every one of us are supposed to be stewards of this planet and all it’s inhabitants. We are all they have got and they are depending on us to help them. Survival of many other species depend on us successfully fighting for the rhino’s survival. If the iconic rhino can’t be saved, what chance do the lesser known endangered species have? Please, talk to yourself about getting involved! We need you to!"

 

NEWSFLASH!!

"Lions are dying off rapidly across Africa. These cats once ranged across the continent and into Syria, Israel, Iraq, Pakistan, Iran, and even northwest India; 2,000 years ago more than a million lions roamed the Earth. Since the 1940s, when lions numbered an estimated 450,000, lion populations have blinked out across the continent. Now they may total as few as 20,000 animals."

"Rhinos have been slaughtered to near extinction to fuel the insatiable demand for rhino horn products in China - and more recently Vietnam - all based on myths about the alleged medicinal properties of rhino horn."

"Elephants Dying in Epic Frenzy as Ivory Fuels Wars and Profits"

"Lion bones have become a hot commodity for their use in Asian traditional medicine, driving up exports from South Africa to the East and creating new fears of the survival of the species."

"Previously de-horned Rhino cow shot, front nose part hacked off, found saturday near Cullinan, carcus approx 3 days old... National total now 374"

"A renowned rhino activists has issued an estimate that, at current rates, the rhinoceros will be extinct in South Africa by 2015. Karen Trendler, a veterinary nurse who has been working with rhinos for nearly 20 years, believes the sharp increase in poaching activity is unsustainable."

"In 2011, almost 40 tons of illegal ivory was seized worldwide—the equivalent of 4,000 dead elephants.

These are real quotes of things happening right now as we all go about our daily lives, and many of us are completely unaware of the real tragedy that awaits. For the sake of your children and future generations we must act now! It's now time to educate at least 5,000,000 by publishing these horrors in booklet form. 1,000,000 booklets read by 5 people wil help spread the word and put a stop to the demand.


Before reading any further, first take a look in our gallery to see the reality of the problems we are facing!

 

What Do We Need To Do - WE NEED TO ACT AND ACT NOW!!!

Many feel that the solution to these problems is the intoduction of Anti Poaching Units and although effective on the "front line" they do nothing but inflate the value of  animal horns, tusks and bones. A parallel can quite easily be drawn with the illegal drug traficking problems of the world - the more difficult it is to get the higher the price people will pay.

A more effective approach is to educate those who believe in the myths surrounding traditional mediines and so called "magic" potions and to show them through education that what they believe is not true at all. We plan on doing this through the publication of 1,000,000 booklets to be distributed throughout China, Vietnam and Laos (the main importers and users of Rhino Horn, Tiger & Lion bones). The booklets, translated into local languages and will display graphic pictures of slaughtered Rhino, Lions & Tigers and will include scientific evidence proving that using such potions has no medicinal value whatsoever. We will distribute these booklets through Animal Rights in China (ARC), Chinese Animal Protection Network (CAPN), Chinese Companion Animal Protection Network (CCAPN), The Philippine Animal Welfare Society, Education For Nature Vietnam (ENV). www.savingrhinos.org & www.rhinorage.org are also assisiting with and will benefit from this campaign.These organisations will carry the message through to city dwellers and those living in city and rural communities. Funds will be used to produce the full colour booklets, aid in the distribution of them, with at least $50,000 being split among these organisation to make sure they are able to get our inmportant messages out there into the communities and carry on their good work.

The Impact

Combined efforts of education by use of easy to read and understand but graphic booklets, plus local community work will eventually have a huge impact on demand for these so called aphrodisiacs, sex potions and ornamental objects. 1,000,000 booklets, each read by 5 people will help us achieve our goal of educating at least 5,000,000 people. Most people in the East have no idea of what these animals have to go through for them to wear or consume such unecessary objects. Lowering demand has to be our number one priority if we are to save our Lions, Tigers, Elephants and Rhino's for our future generations to enjoy. Please, let's all come together and act now before it's too late!

How The Funds Will Be Used

Most of the funding will be used for the production of the booklets with an estimnated cost of 20c per booklet (includes distribution costs). This means that at least $200,000 (1,000,000 x .20c) of funding is needed to cover this. We are also hoping to raise an additional $50,000 to be divided among the various groups taking part in this well needed excercise. Of course - perks need to be paid for from this too. 

 Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount from $1 upwards will all add up and help us to achieve what we really must do. If you for any reason cannot help with as little as a $1 then please share this campaign with those you think can.

http://mobile.nytimes.com/2012/09/04/world/africa/africas-elephants-are-being-slaughtered-in-poaching-frenzy.xml

http://www.treehugger.com/endangered-species/rhinos-may-be-extinct-south-africa-2015.html

http://thecitizen.co.tz/news/4-national-news/24980-lion-bones-trade-flourishes-in-asia.html

http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/big-cats/lion-decline-map/

http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/endangered_species/elephants/african_elephants/#distribution

story:
Imagine walking through the park and looking up at a canopy of fruit and nut trees. Around and below you, there are shrubs and many other types of plants, bearing fruits, vegetables and herbs free for the taking. These are the basics of a food forest. 

A Food Forest is an age-old agricultural strategy where people plant diverse types of edible, climate appropriate plants that form strong, mutually supportive relationships, creating a system that sustains itself over time.  Food forests produce abundant food, with minimal maintenance – humans design with nature to let nature work on her own.

East Austin's rich soil and dedicated neighbors have cared for pecan, plum, loquat and citrus trees for generations. Food forestry is a strategy that can help protect this natural tranquility and neighborhood heritage even as we face increasing water scarcity.

Who we are

East Feast is a coalition of diverse community members dedicated to cultivating food and community together in East Austin, Texas. We are a subsidiary of Urban Patchwork Neighborhood Farms (UP).

East Feast is currently working to establish the first food forest in a public park in Austin, Texas!  The Festival Beach Food Forest will be a place for visitors to connect, grow, and celebrate.

Since its inception in 2012, we have grown from an idea to a grassroots movement for local, healthy, affordable food, with an ordinance to prove it!   Neighbors of the site have rallied to support the Festival Beach Food Forest, including the RBJ Residential Center (a mixed income community and independent living center for seniors and people with disabilities), the Festival Beach Community Garden, nearby neighborhood associations, and public schools.  East Feast partners also include like-minded organizations such as PODER (People Organized in Defense of Earth and Her Resources), the Sustainable Food Center, Austin EcoNetwork, Austin Permaculture Guild, and Food is Free, just to name a few.  Through this network of diverse partners, we are working to ensure that many generations of Austinites learn how fun, easy, and essential good food is.

We invite you to learn more about the Festival Beach Food Forest at www.festivalbeach.org.

Food Forest Layers

What We Need

Right now, we are looking for $25,000 to start the first phase of the Festival Beach Food Forest.  This funding will pay for the initial earthworks, tools, permitting fees, and the initial planting.  These fund will also make sure that we can maintain the Festival Beach Food Forest and prove it is a viable use of public lands. 

We are currently exploring other sources of funding but your contribution will help us get shovels in the ground during the spring planting season. 

As a special thank you for contributing to this amazing project, we have several perks available for contributors.  Below is a list of some of the available perks.

  • Access to newsletter
  • Personal thank you from FBFF
  • FBFF logo Sticker
  • FBFF Logo T-shirt
  • Choice of edible plant or small art piece
  • Choice of fruit tree or large art piece
  • Your name or company name Listed on plant sign as donated by ……
  • Your name or company name Listed on Park bench sign as donated by ……

The Impact

East Feast is proud to announce that on August 28th, 2014, the city council unanimously approved the creation of The Festival Beach Food Forest (FBFF). This ordinance was a milestone for us, and represents an important step forward in the future of food security (and food fun) for our city! The unanimously approved ordinance allows for the creation of a fence-free edible Eden on 2/3 acres of park land. There all citizens are welcomed to learn about food forestry and experience the beauty of an edible oasis in the heart of Austin!

Festival Beach Food Forest plan

The Festival Beach Food Forest will provide the first edible forest garden in a public park in the City of Austin.  The goal of the food forest is to remind people where their food comes from and to provide organic sustainably grown food to the local community. 

Another key goal is to demonstrate how we can design low-water, low-maintenance edible landscapes throughout the city by designing with nature. Just like a natural forest ecosystem, a healthy food forest has multiple levels that support one another. Fruit and nut trees are the upper level, while below are berry shrubs, as well as a mix of other edible plants that benefit from the shade of the canopy trees.  Some supporting plants are strategically included to attract beneficial insects for natural pest management.  Other plants are included to make the soil healthier by providing nitrogen and mulch. By working with nature, we work less. In a food forest, humans help set the conditions where they, the plants, and local animals can keep the system going over time.

We hope that by providing a successful model the city will expand the food forest project and will be more receptive to future food forests throughout the city. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Although we are currently in need of funds to start implementation, we understand that contributing financially is not always possible.  If you are interested in helping with this project but cannot contribute financially there are several ways you can insure the success of the food forest.  Here are some ways you can contribute.

  • Share this campaign with your network
  • Sign up to volunteer during implementation
  • Share your talents 

Thank you for your time.  We Hope to Hear from you!!! 

To stay and in touch and sign up for our newsletter, sign up here:
http://festivalbeachfoodforest.weebly.com/contact.html

Coverage in the media:
http://www.kvue.com/videos/news/local/community/2014/09/19/14953828/

http://www.takepart.com/article/2014/03/07/austin-hotbed-music-technology-andforaging?cmpid=foodinc-fb

http://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2014-02-14/the-way-of-the-food-forest/

http://www.myfoxaustin.com/story/23106947/food-forest-planned-for-east-austin

http://www.austinchronicle.com/food/2015-01-02/the-year-in-food-top-10-food-nonprofits/

East Feast Coalition, is a coalition of diverse community members in Austin Texas, and a subsidiary of Urban Patchwork Neighborhood Farms (UP),  Urban Patchwork’s mission is to educate and mentor our neighbors across the region to become good stewards of our land, our health, and our communities.

story:
As we all know Austin is going through some rough times. I talked to Aunt Marilyn about starting this fundrasier and she mentioned that it would mean the world to her and Uncle Rob to have Austin home.  With family and friends banding together I know we can meet this goal!

 

"Families are the compass that guides us. They are the inspiration to reach great heights, and our comfort when we occasionally falter."

-- Brad Henry
