story:
Hola,

Somos comjeruma, una cooperativa multisectorial de jóvenes émprendedores productores y este es nuestra campaña de crowdfunding

Comjeruma quiere expandirse territorialmente para brindar oportunidades principalmente a jóvenes originarios de comunidades que están siendo afectadas por problemas sociales como violencia familiar, trata de personas, grupos juveniles (pandillas) los cuales han afectado seriamente a la juventud.

 

Desde el punto de vista social, a través de la implementación de los fondos recaudados dará la oportunidad que más jóvenes puedan tener acceso a la generación de divisas para mejorar sus condiciones de vida, considerando que los apicultores con los que trabajamos son jóvenes y están ubicados en comunidades muy vulnerables, en las que la apicultura se ha convertido una manera oportuna para generar recursos para su familia, y al mismo tiempo, gracias a la estrategia de responsabilidad ambiental de COMJERUMA, cada uno de los apicultores atendidos tiene la tarea y compromiso de realizar actividades ambientales en pro de la apicultura y de mejoramiento del medio ambiente, como es el establecimiento de viveros y reforestación con especies nectarpoliníferas, jornadas de limpieza, utilización de productos naturales para la producción, protección de fuentes de agua, uso racional de los recursos naturales y sensibilización a sus familias sobre las prácticas amigables para el medio ambiente, de manera que este tipo de acciones darán una mayor resiliencia a estas familias a los efectos del cambio climático en nuestro país.

 

También es importante sensibilizar a las comunidades sobre el uso racional de los recursos naturales, ya que es la población humana la principal responsable del deterioro de los recursos naturales, por lo que se llevan a cabo sensibilización con las familias sobre la NO quema, la reforestación, la no utilización de productos químicos y la de cuidar a las abejas, de manera que si existen enjambres silvestres que se consideren como un riesgo para las comunidades se pueda solicitar gratuitamente a la Cooperativa para extraer las abejas y orientar su ubicación hacia lugares donde cumplen con las normas de seguridad para la población.

 

COMJERUMA tiene como tarea y compromiso social con la comunidad, por lo que se tiene proyectado trabajar con un grupo de productores del Municipio de San José de Cusmapa, organizados en una pequeña Cooperativa llamada “Cataluña”, los cuales todos sus miembros son padres de niños con capacidades diferentes, y tienen como propósito implementar acciones productivas en sus comunidades para disponer de mayor cantidad de recursos y mejorarle las condiciones de vida a sus hijos con capacidades diferente, lo que COMJERUMA, ya ha iniciado a trabajar con este grupo y tiene como objetivo seguir trabajando fuerte para que este grupo de productores pueda salir adelante y probar que todo es posible con emprendimiento y persistencia.

 

COMJERUMA ha realizado actividades socialmente responsables en la comunidad como es: acudir a los llamados de la población en general de las comunidades y de la ciudad de Somoto que se hacen directamente a la Cooperativa o a través de los Bomberos para extraer enjambres de abejas africanizadas en lugares donde representan peligro para niños, adultos y ancianos; la Cooperativa envía a personal calificado para la extracción de los enjambres gratuitamente. También hemos contribuido con recaudación de fondos para ayudar al asilo de ancianos, también para el equipamiento de la Cruz Roja Nicaraguense.

 

En resumen, los impactos ambientales y sociales son positivos y queremos seguir brindando mas cambios positivos a estas coomunidades rurales en Nicaragua. Por eso, necesitamos tu ayuda para seguir creciendo y por eso estamos pidiendo recaudar $15,000 con su ayuda para seguir adelante.

Hey,

We are Comjeruma, a multisectorial cooperative of young entrepreneurs in rural Nicaragua and this is our crowfunding campaign

Comjeruma wants to expand its territory in order to bring more opportunities to young people in communities which are being affected by social problems such as family violence, human trafficking and groups of young people whose cchildhood has been seriously affected.

From the social point of view and considering the fact that most beekeepers that we work with are from vulnerable communities, with the help of the funds raised, more young people will have access to more ways to make their lives better. Beekeeping has become a great way to generate resources for families and at the same time, thanks to COMJERUMA´s environmental responsibility policy, every beekeeper has the task and commitment of carrying out environmentally responsable activitities such as reforestation, regular rubbish clean-ups, usage of natural products in their production processes, protecting water sources, rational use of resources and raising awareness amongst their families about environmentally friendly practices which will, in the long run, make these families more resilient to the climate change present in our country.

In addition to the families being aware of the responsible use of resources, it i also very important that the wider communities are also aware, due to the fact that it is us humans who are responsible for the deterioration of the world´s natural resources. Therefore our beekeepers carry out awareness campaigns about not burning rubbish, reforestation, utilizing non-chemical products and how to take care of bees and beehives that may be dangerous – in which case the cooperative offers a free service to extract the bees and change their location to  a place where all health and safety regulations are properly followed.

In summary, the environmental and social impacts of COMJERUMA are positive. For that reason, we would like to keep growing and expanding so that we can keep on making positive changes within vulnerable rural communities in Nicaragua and to do that we need your help! We are looking to raise $15,000 to help obtain our own land and continue to grow as a cooperative.
story_txt:
Hola,
Somos comjeruma, una cooperativa multisectorial de jóvenes émprendedores productores y este es nuestra campaña de crowdfunding
Comjeruma quiere expandirse territorialmente para brindar oportunidades principalmente a jóvenes originarios de comunidades que están siendo afectadas por problemas sociales como violencia familiar, trata de personas, grupos juveniles (pandillas) los cuales han afectado seriamente a la juventud.
 
Desde el punto de vista social, a través de la implementación de los fondos recaudados dará la oportunidad que más jóvenes puedan tener acceso a la generación de divisas para mejorar sus condiciones de vida, considerando que los apicultores con los que trabajamos son jóvenes y están ubicados en comunidades muy vulnerables, en las que la apicultura se ha convertido una manera oportuna para generar recursos para su familia, y al mismo tiempo, gracias a la estrategia de responsabilidad ambiental de COMJERUMA, cada uno de los apicultores atendidos tiene la tarea y compromiso de realizar actividades ambientales en pro de la apicultura y de mejoramiento del medio ambiente, como es el establecimiento de viveros y reforestación con especies nectarpoliníferas, jornadas de limpieza, utilización de productos naturales para la producción, protección de fuentes de agua, uso racional de los recursos naturales y sensibilización a sus familias sobre las prácticas amigables para el medio ambiente, de manera que este tipo de acciones darán una mayor resiliencia a estas familias a los efectos del cambio climático en nuestro país.
 
También es importante sensibilizar a las comunidades sobre el uso racional de los recursos naturales, ya que es la población humana la principal responsable del deterioro de los recursos naturales, por lo que se llevan a cabo sensibilización con las familias sobre la NO quema, la reforestación, la no utilización de productos químicos y la de cuidar a las abejas, de manera que si existen enjambres silvestres que se consideren como un riesgo para las comunidades se pueda solicitar gratuitamente a la Cooperativa para extraer las abejas y orientar su ubicación hacia lugares donde cumplen con las normas de seguridad para la población.
 
COMJERUMA tiene como tarea y compromiso social con la comunidad, por lo que se tiene proyectado trabajar con un grupo de productores del Municipio de San José de Cusmapa, organizados en una pequeña Cooperativa llamada “Cataluña”, los cuales todos sus miembros son padres de niños con capacidades diferentes, y tienen como propósito implementar acciones productivas en sus comunidades para disponer de mayor cantidad de recursos y mejorarle las condiciones de vida a sus hijos con capacidades diferente, lo que COMJERUMA, ya ha iniciado a trabajar con este grupo y tiene como objetivo seguir trabajando fuerte para que este grupo de productores pueda salir adelante y probar que todo es posible con emprendimiento y persistencia.
 
COMJERUMA ha realizado actividades socialmente responsables en la comunidad como es: acudir a los llamados de la población en general de las comunidades y de la ciudad de Somoto que se hacen directamente a la Cooperativa o a través de los Bomberos para extraer enjambres de abejas africanizadas en lugares donde representan peligro para niños, adultos y ancianos; la Cooperativa envía a personal calificado para la extracción de los enjambres gratuitamente. También hemos contribuido con recaudación de fondos para ayudar al asilo de ancianos, también para el equipamiento de la Cruz Roja Nicaraguense.
 
En resumen, los impactos ambientales y sociales son positivos y queremos seguir brindando mas cambios positivos a estas coomunidades rurales en Nicaragua. Por eso, necesitamos tu ayuda para seguir creciendo y por eso estamos pidiendo recaudar $15,000 con su ayuda para seguir adelante.
Hey,
We are Comjeruma, a multisectorial cooperative of young entrepreneurs in rural Nicaragua and this is our crowfunding campaign
Comjeruma wants to expand its territory in order to bring more opportunities to young people in communities which are being affected by social problems such as family violence, human trafficking and groups of young people whose cchildhood has been seriously affected.
From the social point of view and considering the fact that most beekeepers that we work with are from vulnerable communities, with the help of the funds raised, more young people will have access to more ways to make their lives better. Beekeeping has become a great way to generate resources for families and at the same time, thanks to COMJERUMA´s environmental responsibility policy, every beekeeper has the task and commitment of carrying out environmentally responsable activitities such as reforestation, regular rubbish clean-ups, usage of natural products in their production processes, protecting water sources, rational use of resources and raising awareness amongst their families about environmentally friendly practices which will, in the long run, make these families more resilient to the climate change present in our country.
In addition to the families being aware of the responsible use of resources, it i also very important that the wider communities are also aware, due to the fact that it is us humans who are responsible for the deterioration of the world´s natural resources. Therefore our beekeepers carry out awareness campaigns about not burning rubbish, reforestation, utilizing non-chemical products and how to take care of bees and beehives that may be dangerous – in which case the cooperative offers a free service to extract the bees and change their location to  a place where all health and safety regulations are properly followed.
In summary, the environmental and social impacts of COMJERUMA are positive. For that reason, we would like to keep growing and expanding so that we can keep on making positive changes within vulnerable rural communities in Nicaragua and to do that we need your help! We are looking to raise $15,000 to help obtain our own land and continue to grow as a cooperative.

story:
Activate the Wheatbelt  is an annual tree planting music festival run by a community of volunteers, that unites the love of music, with the love of land and community

We plants trees to help revegetate and repair degraded agricultural lands around the WA Wheatbelt region. We dance while we do it.

Due to government regulations of the early colonial era, the Wheatbelt region experienced the clearing of critical bush land for farming practices. This mass destruction of the regions natural habitat has caused many serious environmental issues including salinity and erosion. 

Activate the Wheatbelt hosts 2-3 tree planting events in these rural areas, planting over 30,000 trees each winter, showcasing local musical talents and building strong community.  These events are family friendly and encourage people to get back in touch with nature, form life long friendships, have a good dance, and most importantly help our planet by getting trees in the ground.

For ten years we have been revegetating the wheatbelt with a team of hard working volunteers from diverse backgrounds, our mobile DJ truck, and the help of local farmers, grants and sponsorships. All fuelled by nourishing organic wholefood from our volunteers in the kitchen.

‘Activate the Wheatbelt’ gets back in touch with Mother Nature through the spirit of celebration and the physical planting of trees. . We repair our environment whilst meeting new friends and experiencing one of the rawest, connected and meaningful West Australian Bush festivals.

As a volunteer led group, fundraising is vitally important to help us cover trees, food, accommodation, transport and equipment. 

We need your help to make these events a success. So we are reaching out to the community and asking for your support. Your contribution is greatly appreciated and will make a real difference, to all!

Thank you!

story:
Bees are truly fascinating beings. These little creatures are extremely important for the wellbeing of humans. Roughly a third of the foods that are consumed by us humans only grow because these insects pollinate them.

Unfortunately, bees aren’t doing very well nowadays. Places that used to be full of various blossoming meadows, have now become large grain fields. Bees often come in contact with pesticides and other poisons when they are on their foraging flight. And as if that wasn’t enough, their deadly enemy is lurking in their home: the Varroa mite.

Over the last decades, this parasite has spread over the majority of the world, making it extremely hard for the bees. Despite beekeepers treating their bees with different remedies to reduce losses, millions (!) of bee colonies die each year.

Even though I treated my bee colonies too, I still lost many. But I just didn’t want to accept that. I knew that another chemical treatment wouldn’t be the solution. I was looking for alternatives and came across a British inventor, who, after long-term experiments, achieved promising results.

The VARROA BUSTER is a further developed version of that product and is used in addition to regular treatments. The hexagonal gadget comes with a clip and can easily be attached to any kind of hive without any additional tools and doesn't prevent the beekeeper from doing his job the way he's used to.


How the VARROA BUSTER works


Under magnification the gadgets backside shows thousands upon thousands of tiny, razor sharp shards covering its surface, which, when viewed under the microscope, looks like a field of broken glass bottles firmly cemented into the disc.

The coating consists of specially composed biolites. These are sedimentary rocks that were formed by living organisms thousands of years ago.

As you can see here, Varroa mites are covered with bristles which make it really hard for the bees to get rid of their enemies.

But now bees can easily rub themselves against the surface of the VARROA BUSTER by crawling behind the disc to get rid of the mites from both, the front and the back of their bodies, equally as good. This results in the shards  snagging the hooks covering the mites. At the same time the Varroa mites wax coat is cut open and their soft internal tissue is exposed.

This quickly kills the mites through dehydration. Dehydration is a safe and simple killer; the parasite loses its strength and relaxes its grip. It then falls off and dies. For tiny creatures such as mites, the surface is a deadly trap. However, it's no problem for the much larger bees. It's recommended to use two of the VARROA BUSTER gadgets for each hive. They work for one year before they need replacement.

It doesn't require electricity either and works mechanically. Therefore, there is no risk of the mites becoming resistant to the product.


What We Need & What You Get


We are going to use the money to buy the materials needed as well as buy machines to make it easier for us to produce VARROA BUSTER.
We are also planning on creating a nice website for our product.
We are looking to use the collected money for marketing purposes too.

Perks

  • Pledge $29 - get a VARROA BUSTER T-shirt (in different sizes)
  • Pledge $30 - get 1 pair of VARROA BUSTER
  • Pledge $100 - get 4 pairs of VARROA BUSTER
  • Pledge $200 - get 10 pairs of VARROA BUSTER
  • Pledge $800 - get 50 pairs of VARROA BUSTER
  • Pledge $1200 - get 100 pairs of VARROA BUSTER
    

The Impact

Our goal is to reduce bee losses by giving bees the opportunity to rid themselves of varroa mites and therefore help them lead a healthier life. Another important aspect is the fact that you will increase the profitability of your apiary. That way beekeeping will be even more fun and enjoyable again. 
 

Risks & Challenges

 

As with any new product, there may be some unexpected hurdles. Depending on the amount of orders, there may be a shipping delay of a few weeks, although it is not expected. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you aren't able to help finacially, you can still help us out by telling fellow beekeepers about the VARROA BUSTER campaign and website www.varroabuster.com

  • Please help us by sharing this campaign on all of your social media pages. Please use the Indiegogo sharing tools!
  • Help the bees by planting bee-friendly plants.

Thank you for your support!

story:
My name is Simona Rodano and I am the author, producer and one of the performers of "EVERGREEN". I created the musical in 2013 collaborating with a group of amazing artists ( Johna Mancini, Punto Rec Studios) with the mission of making people aware of two of the most important subjects that affect humanity: the environment and recycling. Encouraging people to recycle and care about the Earth through the arts and languages  is very important to us. Multilingual shows enrich and give meaning to people's lives, help them to feel part of society, and celebrate cultural diversity. Songs are in four languages: English, Italian, French and Spanish!

Since 1999 I have been working as a professional singer, actress, songwriter and educator. 

I founded Incanto Productions  in 2008 with the dream of write multilingual, multicultural and educational musicals. Thanks to all our supporters  and the success of the show, we are coming back this year for a new journey:

a cast of 12 talented performers will work together to open "EVERGREEN"  at the Queens Theatre in The Park, New York and also in Washington D.C. 

I believe it is worth it to ask for support for projects that have an impact on future generations. If you wish, I would love to have you as one of our supporters in this special endeavors and follow our growth in the year to come! 

What would your contribution go towards in this campaign? 

Ticket prices cover only part of the production costs. The funding from this campaign will be used by Incanto Productions to pay the amazing performers and the production team, the offset productions costs including the rental of the theatres, costumes and props. But it can also help those schools that don't have the funding to attend our show. Take a look at our perks!!

NOTE 1: you can send your contribution using:

a) Credit Card

b) Paypal

NOTE 2 : For tax-deductible purposes, "EVERGREEN"'s campaign is also fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a 501c(3) nonprofit organization. You can call us at 1-888-300-3357 and we'll assist you!

I thank you on behalf of the whole cast of " EVERGREEN" for helping us achieve our goal. We could not have come this far without support from people like you!

story:
• Hello, we are Jon Todd and Sam Mitchell, two students of Prairie Crossing Charter School (PCCS). As part of 8th grade graduation requirements, we have to complete a Culminating Project (CP) which has to help the environment in our area.  Monitoring air quality and protecting the well-being of Grayslake and surrounding communities is the focus of our CP.

    • We are asking for your help to raise $1,000 to cover the cost of a portable air monitor that checks SO2 and H2S levels.  For sustainable and ongoing monitoring, we are working with IFLC, a local non-profit.  We will post results on their website, and IFLC will take over monitoring after completion of the CP.  To go to the IFLC website click HERE.

    • By donating you will help the Grayslake and Waukegan areas monitor the air quality, especially important due to proximity of a solid waste facility or coal fired power plant.  All readings will be available via website to the community and used as a tool by IFLC as a means to provide advocacy on behalf of the community.  

    What We Need

    • The manufacturer of the air monitors have generously granted us 60% of the cost of the monitor.  We need to raise the remaining $1,000 in order to purchase one air monitor. This monitor will benefit the community because these chemicals harmful to our health and in some cases cause cancer.

    • If we do not reach our goal, we are going to try and get a grant from Pollination Project and if that doesn’t get us all the way there we will ask for donations at the train station located nearest to the Countryside landfill the people who visit this train station.  The faster we complete funding, the sooner we can monitor the air.  If we exceed our goal, any extra funds will go toward maintenance and calibration of the monitor.  Our stretch goal is to provide two monitors to the community if at all possible.

    The Impact

    • Our CP is valuable to our community because it not only helps us learn about the chemicals we are researching, it gives peace of mind to the community. Peace of mind is huge when a landfill or coal fired power plant are in your backyard.  

    • At PCCS, we have 2 teacher mentors for the CP; they guide us on this complex project and keep us on track.

story:
UPDATE, Sept 23: Lizzie, Ben and Julie plead guilty to disorderly conduct (class C misdemeanor) in exchange for dropping all class B misdemeanor criminal trespassing charges filed that day. More info here. Each paid $480 in fees and court costs. Thanks so much for helping us raise enough for their fees! 

SPECIAL OFFER: Tar Sands Blockade activists still face several pending charges for this and other protests; additional funds will go to support those cases. If you donate $30, we'll send you a sweet Fearless Summer bandana (until we run out)!

On November 19 2012 in East Texas, Lizzie Alvarado, Ben Reynoso and Julie Henry climbed up sixty feet into trees to stop construction of the Keystone XL pipeline and prevent the destruction of a swath of forest. The lifelines supporting their platforms were tied to construction equipment, preventing any work from being done.

After a nine hour stand-off with police and workers, a cherry picker arrived. A crowd of local supporters surged into the road to block the truck but were dispersed when a sheriff emptied an entire can of police-grade pepper spray into the crowd. Check out the video of that incident:


Police used the cherry picker to take all three tree-sitters into custody. Ben, Lizzy and Julie were each charged with misdemeanor criminal trespass, felony mischief, and felony use of a criminal instrument. Altogether, these charges could lead to imprisonment for several years and fines of tens of thousands of dollars.

UPDATE: The case has been postponed until September 23rd, when the defendants will face the judge for the first time for their misdemeanor trespassing charges. Please show your support for these activists by donating to their legal fund. Read more about their action here.

What we need and what we’ll do with it:
We can't know for sure how the judge will rule, but we hope $2500 will cover fines and fees for the three tree-sitters. Activists can expect to spend a day in jail for every $100 unpaid.

Please give even if we've already reached our goal; If we have any money left over, we’ll use it for the legal funds of other blockaders. Four others were arrested the same day with the same charges but haven’t been given a court date yet. Overall, other pending cases against nonviolent Tar Sands Blockade activists include over 19 felonies and 8 misdemeanors.

Who we are:
Tar Sands Blockade is a coalition of activists and affected community members using nonviolent direct action to directly oppose the Keystone XL pipeline and other forms of tar sands infrastructure. Click here for a list of our actions.

Ben Reynoso

Ben is a 30 year old rabble-rouser and ruckus-maker from San Luis Obispo, California. He came to the blockade in September after spending a year in New York organizing with Occupy Wall St. Currently, he is doing forest defense work in Oregon. He enjoys climbing all sorts of things, getting dirty in the woods, digging latrines, and standing up to the police.

Lizzy Alvarado

Lizzy is a 21 year old filmmaker and student. She's from Austin, Texas, and is currently entering her fourth year at Stephen F. Austin State University in Nacogodoches. Since moving here in 2010, she has become part of the town's small but close-knit community. 

Lizzy gives back to that community by teaching yoga classes for the university and heading a cycling club which she founded. After learning about the negative effects of KXL and seeing the destruction and disruption of her fellow East Texans' land and lives, she joined with the Tar Sands Blockade in their journey to stop the Keystone XL pipeline.

Julie Henry 


Julie is a biologist and animal rights activist originally from Nashville, TN, but her projects have taken her all over the world. She traveled throughout Southeast Asia to study the environmental impacts of the black market wildlife trade, widespread habitat destruction, and pollution. She spent 2009 - 2010 moving between Thailand and Burma, documenting the smuggling of wild elephants destined to be enslaved in the booming Thai animal entertainment industry. Julie motorbiked her way across the continent through Laos, Vietnam, and Indonesia to document habitat destruction. 

Julie moved to Texas to join the Tar Sands Blockade after seeing photos from the 90 day Winnsboro tree sit. She's been with the campaign ever since. Julie is a rock-climber, caver and all around animal lover. Back home in Nashville she has 3 dogs and 9 cats. "All rescues," she says.

Why we take action:

Tar sands mining is one of the most ecologically destructive projects in human history.

-If pipelines like KXL are constructed and the tar sands deposits in Alberta are fully exploited, an area of pristine boreal forest – one of the largest forests in the world and one of the most important terrestrial carbon sinks – equal to the size of New York State will be destroyed. For more on tar sands, see Rainforest Action Network's info page.

-Indigenous communities near the tar sands mines are already suffering from massively inflated rates of rare cancers and other diseases. 

-Tar sands pipelines are more dangerous than crude oil pipelines – more likely to burst and more deadly when they do – as evidenced from major spills in Kalamazoo, Michigan in 2010 and in Mayflower, Arkansas in 2013.

-Refining the tar sands produces an even higher load of toxins than normal crude; communities along the gulf coast will be forced to breathe these toxins

-Tar sands produce more carbon than regular oil. James Hansen, former head of NASA’s Goddard Institute and one of the world’s leading climate scientists, said that fully exploiting the tar sands would be “game over for the climate”.

For more information about tar sands and about our organization, visit our website.
story_txt:
UPDATE, Sept 23: Lizzie, Ben and Julie plead guilty to disorderly conduct (class C misdemeanor) in exchange for dropping all class B misdemeanor criminal trespassing charges filed that day. More info here. Each paid $480 in fees and court costs. Thanks so much for helping us raise enough for their fees! 
SPECIAL OFFER: Tar Sands Blockade activists still face several pending charges for this and other protests; additional funds will go to support those cases. If you donate $30, we'll send you a sweet Fearless Summer bandana (until we run out)!
On November 19 2012 in East Texas,
Lizzie Alvarado, Ben Reynoso and Julie Henry climbed up sixty feet into trees to stop construction
of the Keystone XL pipeline and prevent the destruction of a swath of forest. The lifelines supporting their
platforms were tied to construction equipment, preventing any work from being
done.
After a nine hour
stand-off with police and workers, a cherry picker arrived. A crowd of local
supporters surged into the road to block the truck but were dispersed when a
sheriff emptied an entire can of police-grade pepper spray into the crowd.
Check out the video of that incident:

Police used the cherry
picker to take all three tree-sitters into custody. Ben, Lizzy and Julie were
each charged with misdemeanor criminal trespass, felony mischief, and felony use of a
criminal instrument. Altogether, these charges could lead to imprisonment for several years and fines of tens of
thousands of dollars.
UPDATE: The case has been postponed until September 23rd, when the defendants will face the judge for the first time for their
misdemeanor trespassing charges. Please show your support for these activists by
donating to their legal fund. Read more about their action here.
What we need and what we’ll do with it:We can't know for sure how the judge will rule, but we hope $2500 will cover fines and fees for the three tree-sitters. Activists can expect to spend a day in jail for every $100 unpaid.
Please give even if we've already reached our goal; If we have any money left over, we’ll use it for the legal funds of other
blockaders. Four others were arrested the same day with the same charges but
haven’t been given a court date yet. Overall, other pending cases against nonviolent Tar Sands Blockade activists include over 19 felonies and 8 misdemeanors.
Who we are:Tar Sands Blockade is a
coalition of activists and affected community members using nonviolent direct
action to directly oppose the Keystone XL pipeline and other forms of tar sands
infrastructure. Click here for a list of our actions.

story:
Power Shift 2013: 


We are the generation that occupied Wall Street, Sandy, and Tahrir Square. We dyed Facebook red in support of marriage equality. We’ve turned out in record numbers to every election we’ve been allowed to vote in, and elected President Barack Obama – twice.

We are leading the fight to solve the climate crisis and build a clean, just and thriving economy by standing up on our campuses and in our communities to demand real solutions that work for workers and Millennials. We have put our fists in the air and our bodies on the line to fight Keystone XL, fracking, and mountaintop removal — and we’re willing to do it again.

We are not afraid to speak truth to power, to sacrifice and to demonstrate our commitment to changes that seemed impossible to previous generations. We are the most diverse generation in history, united with one voice, demanding justice for all.

This October, 15,000 young people from across the country will converge in Pittsburgh, PA for Power Shift 2013 and the University of Illinois wants to be there. We’re coming together to reclaim our democracy and drive forward progress for a clean energy economy. At Power Shift we’ll spend the weekend training on effective strategies, sharing solutions, networking, and taking action to make sure our voices are heard. 

We, the University of Illinois, are writing to ask for your help in sponsoring us to be a part of this life changing experience. We don’t ask for money often and only do it when we feel that something is as important as Power Shift. To attend the conference we need to raise funds to help cover registration, travel, and housing for the weekend. Our current goal is to raise $15,000 (we are trying to raise $500 here). Please help support us by making  a donation between $5-$25. 

 We will be using the bare minimum amount of money to get to Power Shift. We are renting 15 passenger vans and will be staying in the cheapest motels we can find! Not ideal, but this cause means so much to us that we don't care how we get there or where we stay, as long as we are there! 

If you cant donate, no worries! Spread the word to people you know who might be interested. You can also help by spreading the word about the climate movement and support our generation as we fight for clean energy, social justice, a green economy, marriage equality, woman's rights, and much more! 

Check out the video from Power Shift 2011 to get a better understanding of what Power Shift really is!

story:
Short Summary

Salam (Peace) from Palestine! 

The Marda Permaculture Farm is a working farm and a demonstration site for permaculture principles, techniques and strategies in Palestine. Based in the picturesque ancient village of Marda, the project promotes food sovereignty, health, self-reliance and empowerment.  This is accomplished through modeling water harvesting, recycling, energy conservation and home-scale garden production with readily available and locally-appropriate materials.

The Farm is a model of sustainable development and self-sufficiency for the whole of Palestine and to build connections with permaculture projects regionally and internationally. It is the vision of the farm to provide Palestinians with a demonstration site to revive traditional knowledge and practices in farming, sustainable living and community building.  

Palestine has been undergoing a vicious alienation and dispossession of its people from their land, resources and traditional livelihoods by the Israeli occupation and its practices. Today, we are working on building a strong local movement to strengthen local economy, enhance resilience of our farming communities and reach self sufficiency and dependency to achieve sovereignty and sustainability of our communities. 

One of our main outreach activities is conducting the international Permaculture Design Course (PDC), accomplished through a 2-weeks permaculture theoretical and practical training for Palestinian women, men, and farmers—as well as international students, interns and apprentices. The upcoming course will take place from the 25th of September to the 9th of October 2013.  

The funding will go to cover the expenses of 7 Palestinian studentsn, who cannot cover the course expenses but are very enthusiastic and committed to building resilience in Palestine. Our farm and vision is strengthened by local students attending and continuing their work in the field of farming and sustainable agriculture. We are building a pool of local expertise and knowledge to enhance our cause for a just and sustainable world for all. 

We are grateful for you contribution and our farm has bounties to offer to send a warm thank you for believing in our cause. Olive oil, organic soap and honey from Palestine is our small thank you for your generous support, with an open invitation to visit us in the Marda Permaculture Farm and Palestine anytime. Even if we don't reach our goal of funding for 7 students, we will use what you offer to engage as many students as possible in the course. 

Please specify "Marda PDC" in comments sections when submitting the donation. 

Please share widely with friends and colleagues who are passionate about environment, farming, sustainable agriculture and Palestine. Just spreading the word about the work we do will be very much appreciated. 

Shukran (Thank you) from the Marda Permaculture Team!

story:
What The Heck Is This?

I'm sure you must be wondering what this is all about; a map of North America with some animals strategically placed on it.  Wonder no longer!  These fine-looking creatures are a small sampling of the endangered species of the North American continent. 
 
The idea came to me simply enough.  I was in the process of researching a fun all-ages geography text which will be published professionally late in 2013 and upon coming to the biogeography section I was startled to discover how many species we are in danger of losing.  I actually completed my geography degree at UCLA with concentrations in biogeography and climatology so I am no stranger to the concept of extinction.  The rate of loss is really quite astounding.  Some strides have been made to revive near-extinct species, but there is still much that needs to be done.  I decided to take a step towards that goal.  
 
The goal of my project is two-pronged.  I will be publishing an AD-FREE website with lots of original photos and videos so people can see what we're in danger of losing.  The website will contain links to specific organizations people can contribute to or volunteer with to help save the critter in question.  What makes this website different is the sheer number of photos and other media it will contain.  All media will be made available as public domain, as well.  The more exposure, the greater the chance of survival.  I also will be publishing an e-book with different photos.  It can be enjoyed by both children and adults.  All proceeds (100%) from the sale of the book will go towards organizations dedicated to saving endangered species.  When you donate to this project, your funds will go farther than you can imagine!  I will update the website frequently with information about where everything is going.
 
 

What Will You Do With My Pledge?

That is an excellent question!  I'm glad you asked.  I am requesting funding for the upkeep of the website.  A dedicated server, domain name, extra bandwidth (if needed) and the cost of publicity are requirements for a successful website.  In addition, I am also seeking the funds for the required travel and entrance fees associated with photographing and videotaping some of the most elusive animals on our planet.  In many cases, I will need a guide of some sort.  I have already contacted a few professionals and, if I get the required funding (please pledge!), I can meet with them.  

I am requesting $5500 in support of this goal.  A portion of this goes towards indiegogo and paypal.  The rest will be used for the above objective.  Please remember that the more funding I receive, the more comprehensive the book and website will be.

I have some great rewards for you guys.  All you need to do is pledge $10 to get a digital copy of the book.  That's all it takes!  $50 gets your name and photo (if desired) on the "Acknowledgements" page of the website as well as the e-book.  $75 is the best!  You get all of the above, plus your name listed in the acknowledgements in the ebook and any future physical copy of the book.  Wow!  Those are some cool rewards.

If I do not achieve my goal of $5500 I will be required to pay indiegogo almost $550, so please help me out.  I am a strong believer in crowdfunding and have personally pledged to more than 20 projects.  Many of them have been successful.  I hope this project will be among the success stories.  Our wildlife is counting on us.

 

Are You Qualified To Do This?

Before pledging your hard-earned money to this project, it's natural to ask this question.  In addition to earning a degree in a field associated with this endeavor, I also have actual field research experience.  I spent some time in Florida tracking armadillos with a terrific team of academics and amateurs and I have also taken several courses with associated field sections.  I have had some of my photographs published professionally, as well.  Please check out the link to my Fotki website to see some of my work.
 
 

What Else Can I Do?

Another good question!  If you are unable to contribute monetarily, you can still help by spreading the word about this project.  There are all manner of "share" tools you can use to spread the word through facebook,  e-mail, your website, etc.  Word of mouth is pretty awesome, too.  Thank you for your support.

story:
2000 Miles. 80 Days. 

Dozens of State & National Parks. 3 Cameras. 2 Wheels. 

1 Bicycling Photographer with Beautiful Pixels to Share.

As a photographer, the word "envisioning" is very powerful and dear to me, and I often envision a world in balance and with equality, where humans and other inhabitants live in conscious harmony. A world filled with openness, acceptance, creative art, and joy, where deeds are done out of kindness for others and respect for nature, instead of profits, and we no longer "fight" towards peace, but simply live in peace.

These are ideals far greater than myself, or any one individual, for that matter. It is very easy to become overwhelmed with all these tremendous global issues, and simply throw in the towel. The way I see it though, is that we ought to discover and work towards that particular thing we are most passionate about, and have faith that others will (if not already) fill the rest of the niches in a connected movement.

I do believe that global movement is underway; some of that magic has been seen by my own eyes, as well as captured with my cameras.


Skookumchuck Narrows, British Columbia. A force of nature, a scared ground for First Nations people, and an absolute sight to behold.

This is precisely the basis in which I have been transforming my own life in the past couple years. Since April this year, I left home in Los Angeles on a one-way flight with my bicycle, and have been traveling throughout the Pacific Northwest as I work from one organic farm to another and connecting with many incredible individuals along the way.

I had set out with the intentions of having low-carbon adventures, 
endless photographic opportunities,
full immersement in sustainable food production, and
living a minimalistic but socially and environmentally-sound lifestyle
in the company of friendly strangers and old friends.

So far, so very good.

Why by Bicycle?

It is a no emissions, low maintenance, and highly rewarding mode of transport. In addition these already amazing perks, traveling by bicycle also brings the pace down to be able to soak in more of the details and beauty along the way. This choice is also a personal challenge to live only with belongings I need and am able to carry - trim the fat, with nothing superfluous. The physical work comes with yet another perk, and that is the fitness and high quantity of quality food I can ingest to sustain the energy output - everyone's dream, right?

Why Organic Farms?

It was through my humbling past work in environmental development work with indigenous villages in rural Panama where I became in-tune with the utmost importance of wholesome, local food production. The paradigm shift continued from taking an introduction course on the U.S. food system through the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, reading enlightening books and credible publications such as Michael Pollan's The Omnivore's Dilemma, as well as being more in-tune with world happenings. 


Late Summer Harvest at Rolling Earth Farm and Retreat, British Columbia

I came to the realization that food is in a multitude of ways the very social and environmental essence which binds and separates us from one another as well as the physical world, and found a burning desire to dive into the realms of sustainable agriculture and food systems to not only in obtaining a fuller understanding of the complexity of getting food from farm to table, but also in promoting awareness in shifting towards a system that accounts for the long-term social, public health, economical, and environmental factors over the conventional, quantity-driven, fossil fuel-based system. 

I decided one of the best ways to go about this is to get my hands dirty with the very stewards of land and farmers who have been doing it for years, and have some fun while at it!


Day-to-day operations, Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) box, and shenanigans at 8th Street Greens CSA and Farm, Okanogan, Washington

I wish to take all that I am able to absorb, and in turn, convey the significance and share such experiences through my photographs and videos I have been and will continue to post. I have also conversed with many individuals, friends and strangers alike, about the elephant in the room:

How are we going to continue to sustainably feed 7+ billion people without significantly degrading our most valuable resources of land and water?

The answer is wildly complex, hugely interdisciplinary, but certainly not without solutions with our existing knowledge and ability, as well as continued evolution.


Happy cows on a green pasture, near Cowichan Bay, British Columbia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Journey

In the past 5 months, I have spent superbly quality time on 3 farms and intentional communities in British Columbia and Washington (Rolling Earth Farm & Retreat, Chuckleberry Community, and 8th Street Greens), met characters I will never forget, and gathered stories and experiences I would not have gained anywhere else. Some personal notes about this transformative journey can be read on my blog. Note: not a writer by any means, simply a reflective verbal spillage of thoughts ;)


Some of my many inspirational teachers

As autumn is beginning to set in, the big plan now is to take the ride of my life down the majestic west coast - from the coast of mainland British Columbia, down to Vancouver Island and towards the lush Olympic Peninsula, through the entirety of the Oregon coastline while visiting Alpha Farm, nestled in the coastal mountain ranges, for a week, then crossing the awe-inspiring Redwoods of northern California, down the Pacific Coast Highway 1 to San Francisco, followed by one more farm stop at Pasture 42 with the family which had hosted me on my very first WWOOF (Worldwide Opportunities on Organic Farms) experience. After that, I will return to the bay area to reconnect with friends, ride through the famous central and southern California coast to the San Diego/Mexico border, and finally return to where my family resides in Los Angeles. 

I foresee spending almost 7 million seconds, or 80 days, for this physical and mental trek of a lifetime. Below is the (tentative, and already revised) route:

Why Should I Contribute?

This journey has thus far been entirely self-funded, but in order to sustain this long solo trek, I need your financial and mental support! 

Your contributions will keep my stomach and body filled with wholesome calories and energy needed to sustain the 2000+ miles (3300+ km) venture across some of the most gorgeous coastline and temperature forests on our home planet.

And I will be capturing as much of that natural beauty on my cameras. So is there another incentive? You betcha! Read on...

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Photogenic Perks

In return for your contributions, a wide range of photographic/canvas prints and services are offered. The full list can be seen on the right column. A link to the full gallery of photographs to choose from will be accessible and continuously be added to soon! For now, please check out the 'Gallery' tab for just a sampler of the sceneries and moments I have captured.


Mount Rainier, Washington.

With the exception of "The Hat Tip," all perks come with an invitation to a Google Hangout-style session, where I will be presenting a number of favorite photographs, moments, personal commentaries, as well as a chance to AMA - Ask Me Anything - regarding the bicycle journey, the farming experience, and of course, about photography! I plan to host several of these hangouts at the end of the year to early next year, and have several sessions to mesh well with everyone's time zones and life schedules. Details to come.

Upon arriving home to southern California, I shall call upon a trusted professional printer who uses the highest quality photo papers and canvas to materialize your beautiful print(s). 

As for the photographic services, let's work out a date in the following year, and you can expect personalized attention in making that picture-perfect portrait session happen, or wedding that you (or family/friends) have been envisioning for months, if not years. Same goes with the workshops - we will no doubt have a great time and learn much about this art that I am absolutely passionate about, wherever the location may be! 

I greatly look forward to connecting with you, and your support for my art and multitude of motivations are so, so appreciated. 

But wait, there is more!

For a number of years, I have been a huge fan of 350.org, a grassroots movement empowering people worldwide for collective global climate action and environmental awareness, and Conservacion Patagonica, which is creating the future Patagonia National Park in the incredible Andes Mountains of Chile. These good folks have been at the forefront of environmental action and stewardship for years, and your contributions to this fundraiser will also support their momentous causes. I had the great opportunity to take part in a climate action rally in Los Angeles in earlier this year, and I can tell you, the empowering feeling and great sense of community 350.org and many other organizations brought forth are the driving force we as better stewards of this planet can have more of.

As part of my belief that we are collectively doing our part in the world to make this planet a better place for all inhabitants, it is therefore my pleasure to pitch in 20% (10% each) of the net proceeds to these momentous environmental organizations. 

Check out the awesome work they are doing on their websites:

  • 350.org: http://www.350.org
  • Conservacion Patagonica: http://www.conservacionpatagonica.org


Climate Rally in Los Angeles, California, in calling our congressmen and leaders for clear and urgent climate change action

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

My Work

As a photographer, my own viewpoint of a particular subject matter or scenery is embedded into every image. Besides the thrill of capturing the sheer beauty of our earthly landscape at its finest moment, I am captivated by the genuine expressions in people and the human element of a scene. 

My work has been shown or utilized on various outlets and publications, such as National Geographic's Go Blue Central America, Global Brigades, Earth Train, UC San Diego, WilderUtopia, Escape Artist Panama, La Prensa Panama, Maptia, Visit Oceanside, and more. About a year ago, I hosted a personal photo exhibit in the historic quarters of Panama City and attracted hundreds of Panamanians and travelers on an evening where I was able to share my adventures and human experiences throughout the country. 

Past portrait sessions and weddings have taken me to an island in tropical Panama, parks throughout Los Angeles, and beaches of sunny San Diego. My cameras and I have matched alongside indigenous leaders for environmental action, witnessed the healing process at a drum circle and the traditional dances for celebration, battled water in its 3 forms from windy coasts to blizzard-raged mountain peaks, and frozen the unique times of the most rewarding baby smiles for his/her parents. I have a humble but steadily growing fan base through my social media networks, and aspire to inspire others to respect as well as admire the places, cultures, and beauty our world unrelentingly offers.

Beyond the photography realm, I have backpacked on multi-day journeys in the snow-peaked Sierra Nevadas, through mesmerizing sandstone canyons of Arizona and Utah, and deep into the tropical jungles of Panama. My bicycle has already racked up 1000+ miles since April, and although the road ahead will undoubtedly be filled with challenges in all scenarios and shapes, I am confident my strong motivations and the omnipresent kindness in people will prevail and allow me to see this to completion. 

Your contributions will be so valuable in perpetuating all that makes my work possible on my Facebook Photography Page, 500px profile, and blog. If you haven't already, watch the video at the top of this page to give you an essence of what this journey has been about. Check back on this fundraising page in the coming weeks to see updates!

Photo Credits (Top Left to Bottom Right): Audrey, Katrina, Aurelio, Laura!

Other Ways To Contribute

I 100% understand if you are unable to monetarily contribute. It would be absolutely appreciated in getting the word out through your networks. If you have a Facebook, Twitter, Google+, Tumblr, Pinterest, or any social media profiles, resharing this fundraiser to your circles, or better yet, sending a personal message to any potential supporters would be simply divine.

I am absolutely excited for the future pages to unfold! Thank you so much.

Onwards!

A 3-story high waterfall at the Day Road Forest in Roberts Creek, British Columbia


Crescent moon just after sun down, with Vancouver's Lions Gate Bridge lit next to Stanley Park

story_txt:
2000 Miles. 80 Days. 


Dozens of State & National Parks. 3 Cameras. 2 Wheels. 
1 Bicycling Photographer with Beautiful Pixels to Share.
As a photographer, the word "envisioning" is very powerful and dear to me, and I often envision a world in balance and with equality, where humans and other inhabitants live in conscious harmony. A world filled with openness, acceptance, creative art, and joy, where deeds are done out of kindness for others and respect for nature, instead of profits, and we no longer "fight" towards peace, but simply live in peace.
These are ideals far greater than myself, or any one individual, for that matter. It is very easy to become overwhelmed with all these tremendous global issues, and simply throw in the towel. The way I see it though, is that we ought to discover and work towards that particular thing we are most passionate about, and have faith that others will (if not already) fill the rest of the niches in a connected movement.
I do believe that global movement is underway; some of that magic has been seen by my own eyes, as well as captured with my cameras.

Skookumchuck Narrows, British Columbia. A force of nature, a scared ground for First Nations people, and an absolute sight to behold.
This is precisely the basis in which I have been transforming my own life in the past couple years. Since April this year, I left home in Los Angeles on a one-way flight with my bicycle, and have been traveling throughout the Pacific Northwest as I work from one organic farm to another and connecting with many incredible individuals along the way.

I had set out with the intentions of having low-carbon adventures, endless photographic opportunities, full immersement in sustainable food production, and 
living a minimalistic but socially and environmentally-sound lifestyle in the company of friendly strangers and old friends.
So far, so very good.




Why by Bicycle?It is a no emissions, low maintenance, and highly rewarding mode of transport. In addition these already amazing perks, traveling by bicycle also brings the pace down to be able to soak in more of the details and beauty along the way. This choice is also a personal challenge to live only with belongings I need and am able to carry - trim the fat, with nothing superfluous. The physical work comes with yet another perk, and that is the fitness and high quantity of quality food I can ingest to sustain the energy output - everyone's dream, right?


Why Organic Farms? It was through my humbling past work in environmental development work with indigenous villages in rural Panama where I became in-tune with the utmost importance of wholesome, local food production. The paradigm shift continued from taking an introduction course on the U.S. food system through the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, reading enlightening books and credible publications such as Michael Pollan's The Omnivore's Dilemma, as well as being more in-tune with world happenings. 
Late Summer Harvest at Rolling Earth Farm and Retreat, British Columbia
I came to the realization that food is in a multitude of ways the very social and environmental essence which binds and separates us from one another as well as the physical world, and found a burning desire to dive into the realms of sustainable agriculture and food systems to not only in obtaining a fuller understanding of the complexity of getting food from farm to table, but also in promoting awareness in shifting towards a system that accounts for the long-term social, public health, economical, and environmental factors over the conventional, quantity-driven, fossil fuel-based system. 
I decided one of the best ways to go about this is to get my hands dirty with the very stewards of land and farmers who have been doing it for years, and have some fun while at it!

Day-to-day operations, Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) box, and shenanigans at 8th Street Greens CSA and Farm, Okanogan, Washington

I wish to take all that I am able to absorb, and in turn, convey the significance and share such experiences through my photographs and videos I have been and will continue to post. I have also conversed with many individuals, friends and strangers alike, about the elephant in the room:
How are we going to continue to sustainably feed 7+ billion people without significantly degrading our most valuable resources of land and water?
The answer is wildly complex, hugely interdisciplinary, but certainly not without solutions with our existing knowledge and ability, as well as continued evolution.

Happy cows on a green pasture, near Cowichan Bay, British Columbia

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------


The Journey

In the past 5 months, I have spent superbly quality time on 3 farms and intentional communities in British Columbia and Washington (Rolling Earth Farm & Retreat, Chuckleberry Community, and 8th Street Greens), met characters I will never forget, and gathered stories and experiences I would not have gained anywhere else. Some personal notes about this transformative journey can be read on my blog. Note: not a writer by any means, simply a reflective verbal spillage of thoughts ;)

Some of my many inspirational teachers

As autumn is beginning to set in, the big plan now is to take the ride of my life down the majestic west coast - from the coast of mainland British Columbia, down to Vancouver Island and towards the lush Olympic Peninsula, through the entirety of the Oregon coastline while visiting Alpha Farm, nestled in the coastal mountain ranges, for a week, then crossing the awe-inspiring Redwoods of northern California, down the Pacific Coast Highway 1 to San Francisco, followed by one more farm stop at Pasture 42 with the family which had hosted me on my very first WWOOF (Worldwide Opportunities on Organic Farms) experience. After that, I will return to the bay area to reconnect with friends, ride through the famous central and southern California coast to the San Diego/Mexico border, and finally return to where my family resides in Los Angeles. 
I foresee spending almost 7 million seconds, or 80 days, for this physical and mental trek of a lifetime. Below is the (tentative, and already revised) route:







Why Should I Contribute?

This journey has thus far been entirely self-funded, but in order to sustain this long solo trek, I need your financial and mental support! 
Your contributions will keep my stomach and body filled with wholesome calories and energy needed to sustain the 2000+ miles (3300+ km) venture across some of the most gorgeous coastline and temperature forests on our home planet.
And I will be capturing as much of that natural beauty on my cameras. So is there another incentive? You betcha! Read on...


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Photogenic Perks

In return for your contributions, a wide range of photographic/canvas prints and services are offered. The full list can be seen on the right column. A link to the full gallery of photographs to choose from will be accessible and continuously be added to soon! For now, please check out the 'Gallery' tab for just a sampler of the sceneries and moments I have captured.

Mount Rainier, Washington.


With the exception of "The Hat Tip," all perks come with an invitation to a Google Hangout-style session, where I will be presenting a number of favorite photographs, moments, personal commentaries, as well as a chance to AMA - Ask Me Anything - regarding the bicycle journey, the farming experience, and of course, about photography! Same goes with the workshops - we will no doubt have a great time and learn much about this art that I am absolutely passionate about, wherever the location may be! 
I greatly look forward to connecting with you, and your support for my art and multitude of motivations are so, so appreciated. 





But wait, there is more!
For a number of years, I have been a huge fan of 350.org, a grassroots movement empowering people worldwide for collective global climate action and environmental awareness, and Conservacion Patagonica, which is creating the future Patagonia National Park in the incredible Andes Mountains of Chile. I had the great opportunity to take part in a climate action rally in Los Angeles in earlier this year, and I can tell you, the empowering feeling and great sense of community 350.org and many other organizations brought forth are the driving force we as better stewards of this planet can have more of.
As part of my belief that we are collectively doing our part in the world to make this planet a better place for all inhabitants, it is therefore my pleasure to pitch in 20% (10% each) of the net proceeds to these momentous environmental organizations. 
Check out the awesome work they are doing on their websites:



350.org: http://www.350.org


Conservacion Patagonica: http://www.conservacionpatagonica.org

story:
My name is Carole Beaupre and I am from Quebec Canada. Outside has always been my favorite place on earth, and as an educator my desire to create, teach and leave a positive impact along the way has always been important to me. My love of the outdoors and education is currently being shared with my business I created in Costa Rica, Cantico Kayak and Ecotours (https://www.facebook.com/pages/CanTico-Kayaks-Eco-Tours/147781665239112) I spend my time guiding, teaching and sharing outdoor experiences with people of all ages (in and out of the classroom). I constantly strive to inspire people to reconnect with the outside world and to adopt a healthy lifestyle. 

My work goals in Costa Rica has been to contribute to important causes; (environmental, social), through adventure tourism, sport and education. With my four plus years of living in Costa Rica, I have fallen in love not only with the country but also with it's hard working people. 

With the skilled and experienced people I have connected with in Quebec, Canada to develop the mountain bike park project, we can clearly  achieve

(Frederic Asselin, director of Vallee Bras du Nord, Quebec, and I. First meeting in person to discuss the Costa Rica mountain bike project. August 10-11, 2013).

positive change for the community and the people of Santa Cecilia where the project will take place starting in November 2013. 

Call it the teacher in me, I have found my true inspiration and following my passion with combining sport and education. This is what I am all about!

Our campaign’s mission is to create a non-profit first class, sustainable mountain biking part on a Butterfly farm with 270 hectares of land in Santa Cecilia. 

www.elbosquenuevo.org

We are asking donors to be a part of this, through supporting our mountain bike project via our:  “Crank it up!” campaign goal of $ 50 000. In return this is what we commit to;

  • donate 100% of the mountain bike park’s profit to rain forest conservation and reforestation,
  • support sustainable tourism for the community, 
  • support education and positive goal setting for the community and its youth,
  • educate park users and the community on healthy lifestyle choices through mountain biking programs for local youth. The "Crank it up!" Campaign is seeking $50 000 dollars in funding to build this sustainable mountain biking park on 270 hectare of private land with an established project in conservation and reforestation. 

Why support “Crank it up!” campaign to create El Bosque Nuevo Mountain Bike Park?

Santa Cecilia is a beautiful and stunning area in the North West part of Costa Rica, just below Lake Nicaragua, less then 100 km form the Liberia International Airport. The area does not yet benefit from the ten of thousands of tourists that visit Costa Rica each year. The area has unparalleled natural beauty and terrain. It offers a unique experience for all visitors, with its dormant and active volcanoes, its diversity of flora and fauna, rivers and lush primary and secondary forests.


(Riding a road around the farm with Ernesto the Director of El Bosque Nuevo. March 2013)

Environmental Issues

Most people in the area are sustenance farmers or commercial growers of beans, oranges and pineapple and are consistently looking to expand their cultivation. Too often, once they have expanded, cleared the land, then fall into financial issues, they will walk away with the land stripped of forest. To often we can see land with old unproductive orange orchards that are not replaced, leaving the land with only one species of tree that does not support bio-diversity.

While rain-forests may seem like a distant concern, these ecosystems are critically important for our well-being. Rain-forests are often called the lungs of the planet for their role in absorbing carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, and producing oxygen upon which all animals depend for survival. Rain- forests also stabilize climate, house incredible amounts of plants and wildlife, and produce nourishing rainfall all around the planet.

Our Environmental Objectives:

  • create a non-profit mountain bike park for tourist and local,
  • donate our revenue to El Bosque Nuevo Organization in order to contribute to their ongoing project of conservation and reforestation,
  • teach about environmental issues in Costa Rica and how to contribute.

Social Issues

Another objective that is extremely important in this project is; since Santa Cecilia is bordering with Nicaragua the transportation and availability of drugs is a sad reality to young adult and youth, and can substantially impact them in this low income area. We are determined through education, to present other options in their life and to facilitate and encourage a healthy and positive development in the community.

Our Social Objectives:

  • teach positive and healthy life style choices and through sports and mountain biking program,
  • facilitate positive goal setting in education and higher education,
  • expose youth to different carriers through mountain biking,
  • develop necessary skills to take part in sustainable tourism,
  • teach about business,
  • to provide business opportunities around the park such as food and beverage, lodging, retail and service etc.

The mountain bike park will be built on El Bosque Nuevo Butterfly Farm’s land. The farm is an established non-profit organization owning 270 hectares of land with primary and secondary forest. The future bike park profit will be applied 100% to the existing reforestation and conservation project. El Bosque Nuevo’s organization started 10 years ago with 70 hectares and through selling butterflies internationally, including the beautiful blue morpho, they are able to accumulate more land to protect and reforest. The Montreal Botanical Garden is one of their clients. The farm supports directly and indirectly 80 families.

What will we do with the funds:

This non-profit initiative is to develop a mountain bike park and sustainable practice for maintaining it. All profit derived from the park once operational cost are used will go to El Bosque Nuevo Butterfly farm Organization.

Crank it up! Campaign purchasing goals:

  • to bring Frederic Asselin, Director Solidarity Co-op, Vallee Bras du Nord, and sustainable mountain bike park designer and park developer from Quebec, Canada to Costa Rica. www.valleebrasdunord.com
  • to purchase tools and rent small machinery to build trails,
  • to cover the cost of shipping and taxes from Canada for special trail building tools,
  • to feed and lodge volunteer workers while building the park,
  • to purchase first aid equipment for the park,
  • to purchase communication equipment,
  • to purchase 10 mountain bikes, shipping cost and taxes to Costa Rica,
  • to purchase maintenance part for bikes,
  • to have a marketing, website and advertising funds,
  • to obtain enough money to run the park for at least one year or more.

We will train a local team of Costa Ricans with the skills necessary to continue building, maintaining and improving single track trails in the park, for long term employment and sustainability.

As a Campaign supporter and sponsor of Crank it up!, you or your organisation will be entitle to different perks and a newsletter to follow our progress. 

In the case we do not achieve our financial goal, we are determined to start the work in Costa Rica with whatever amount we will have. Our team is extremely committed to help the people of Santa Cecilia enjoy the opportunities and  benefit tied to the tourism industry.

If you cannot contribute financially, please talk us up, we will greatly appreciate it! You can also use the share tool for us.

Thanks you from all the people that has been involved from the beginning when it was just an idea!

check us for updates on Facebook

https://www.facebook.com/pages/El-Bosque-Nuevo-Mountain-Bike-Park-Parc-VTT/545534338824920

of Crank it up!, you or your organisation will be entitle to different perks and a newsletter to follow our progress. 
In the case we do not achieve our financial goal, we are determined to start the work in Costa Rica with whatever amount we will have. Our team is extremely committed to help the people of Santa Cecilia enjoy the opportunities and  benefit tied to the tourism industry.
If you cannot contribute financially, please talk us up, we will greatly appreciate it! You can also use the share tool for us.
Thanks you from all the people that has been involved from the beginning when it was just an idea!check us for updates on Facebook
https://www.facebook.com/pages/El-Bosque-Nuevo-Mountain-Bike-Park-Parc-VTT/545534338824920

story:
OCT. 2019 UPDATE! We've closed this IGG campaign, but PLEASE CLICK HERE to help us get a jump on fundraising for some very special adventures in 2020!​

Overview

Washington To Washington brings city kids on a week-long adventure exploring the Great Outdoors! This year we're visiting Michigan's Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore, hiking Empire Dunes, swimming in Lake Michigan, canoeing, horseback riding, and much more. Since we're all volunteers, 100% of your donation helps to get kids out into nature for a trip they'll always remember. We've got a short time to raise the money – thanks so much for your generosity and for your help spreading the word!

Short Summary

Hello, Davy Rothbart, James Molenda, and Sarah Locke here! We're the editors of FOUND Magazine, and each summer for the past 9 years – with the generous help of friends like you – we put together a camping trip called Washington to Washington, where we bring kids who have grown up in the city to experience the Great Outdoors. Thank you so much for checking out the short video above, and contributing what you can to help this year's trip come to life!

Washington to Washington is an annual outdoors adventure bringing kids from Washington, D.C., Southeast Michigan (Detroit area), and New Orleans on a week-long camping and hiking trip to explore some of the country's most incredible wilderness areas. Along the way, these kids will hike up a mountain, walk through beautiful forests, see animals they didn't know existed, swim, canoe, and fish in pristine lakes and rivers, eat new foods, ride horses, watch the Perseid meteor shower, make S’mores and tell ghost stories around a campfire, learn camping and wilderness skills, and basically just have fun!

What have we done on previous W2W trips? We've hiked some of the tallest mountains in America at the Presidential Range in New Hampshire (2010); dropped by Luray Caverns and found secret swimming holes deep into the Shenandoah Valley (2011); found crawfish in the creek, tried some yoga, and hiked up Seneca Rocks in West Virginia (2012); drifted down a lazy river and explored Tracy Ridge in Allegheny National Forest (2013); completed a scavenger hunt, hit the beach, and hiked Bolar Mountain in George Washington National Forest (2014); went to a children's museum, played a pick-up game in Michigan Stadium, canoed tranquil lakes, and played in the sand around Warren Dunes in Michigan (2015); zip-lined, pet wild ponies, and trekked Mount Rogers in Virginia (2016); fished a nearby lake, rode on horseback, and hiked around Lake Sherando, Virginia (2017); and, last year, spent our ride tickets at the state fair, fished a little more, competed in camp Olympics, and hiked Twin Overlook in Virginia (2018).

For this year's trip – the 10th annual trip – we're heading to the jaw-droppingly gorgeous Sleeping Bear Dunes in northern Michigan and hiking the stunning Empire Dunes! Forests, sand dunes, and lakeshore beaches, all in one place! While we won't have to dodge bears and bulls like years past, we're looking forward to seeing deer, foxes, porcupines, and even bald eagles.

The trip was inspired by our friendship with D.C. native Emmanuel Durant, Jr. After his tragic death on New Year's Eve, 2009, we teamed up with Emmanuel's family to create these annual trips as a way to introduce city kids to the magic of nature, broaden perspectives, and pay tribute to Emmanuel.

What We Need & What You Get

We have 55 wonderful, deserving kids who are excited to go on the trip this summer (the farthest in W2W history – over 800 miles from D.C.!), but we would love to raise $30,000 by August 8th in order to make the trip happen. Thanks to some extremely generous donors, we were able to raise over $12,000 this spring to give us a head start; now, we're in the home stretch for the final $18,000. Our trips are run entirely by volunteers, so please know that 100% of your donation goes toward covering the hard costs of making the trip happen — food, gas, transportation, camping gear, etc.

Honestly, the biggest reward you'll receive from contributing is the knowledge that you've helped some awesome kids get out into nature — many for the first time in their lives — and have some new, life-enriching experiences. That said, we'll also be sending out photos of the trip, handmade Thank You cards, and all kinds of other special prizes to those who offer support. Check out the full range of Perks listed to the right.  Have a special Perks request that we didn't include?  Don't hesitate to email us and ask!

The Impact

Our trips have no specific agenda — we seek only to introduce kids who have rarely left D.C., Detroit and New Orleans (or even their own neighborhoods) to the joys of nature and wilderness hiking and give them a chance to experience something brand-new and have an exciting adventure.  On past Washington to Washington hikes, we trip leaders have seen that look of accomplishment and inspiration that fills the kids' faces when we've reached the top of a mountain.  It's amazing! You can check out photo galleries of our 2011 - 2018 trips to get a sense for just how special our Washington to Washington trips seem to be to these kids. And, here's a short, lovely video featuring camper David on his first trip in 2014 (he's a camper who has returned every year since).

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides contributing financially, there are other ways that you can help us make our 10th Annual Washington to Washington trip a reality:

- Email links to this IndieGoGo fundraising page and our Washington to Washington website to your family and friends. The URLs are below.

- Help us spread the word! Post links to this fundraising page and our Washington to Washington site on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. This makes an absolutely HUGE difference! The more people who learn about the trip, the better chance we have of raising the funds we need.

- Donate gear! We are always in need of tents, sleeping bags, flashlights, and other camping and hiking supplies. To arrange a contribution of this kind, email us at WashingtonToWashington@gmail.com.

So, please help us distribute these URLs and get the word out!

W2W IndieGoGo Fundraising Page short-link: https://igg.me/at/10thW2W

W2W Official Site: http://www.washingtontowashington.org/ 

Thank you so much for your support — it is hugely appreciated!

Much love & respect,

Davy, James, Margaret, Pat, Joshua, Nina, Barry, Ryan, Brandon, Avery, Nat, Hillary, Sam, Laura, Ethan, Lopez, Jason, Shawn, Kyland, Alessandra, Gazala, Alec, Denise, Tommy, Angela, Tim, Crystal, Zach, Callie, Maggie, Emily, Hannah, Ellyn, Denice, Smurf, Anna, Chris, Doug, Gwen, Talisha, Biju, Sierra, Mark, Katie, and the entire Washington to Washington crew.

Questions? Email us at WashingtonToWashington@gmail.com

All photos courtesy of the fantastic Callie Giovanna
