story:
Short Summary

We are a team of design engineers & marketing managers with a combined +50 years experience.  We got together a year ago and decided to run with the idea to find a way to communicate with our pets.  In our research, we discovered that "Dr Dolittle" had a great idea and we began the process to find a way to do this. Hence, the CatChatter project was launched! 

Using our US based development partners and our Asia based manufacturing  partners (Taiwan and China) we have started the planning and development of the first product. Our prototypes are showing good results and our exploration in the market suggest high success probability for the product.  We will need additional funding for mechanical tooling and marketing, so we launched Indiegogo. 

Together with your support, we can make this product a reality!  Please consider backing us and be one of the first to receive your CatChatter!  It is fun, innovative and opens a whole new market to help us better understand our pets!  Thanks for your consideration!

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support and with that you will receive a "Cat Chatter".  Our estimated retail is $49.95.  With a $25 contribution you will receive one Cat Chatter.  With a $50 contribution you will receive two Cat Chatters.  That is a 50% discount from retail!!

The Impact - An Overview of our Product

When a cat purrs, meows or hisses, “CatChatter” will sense the pitch, tone and duration.

“CatChatter” then will play one of ten prerecorded messages in response to the “feeling” the cat expressed at that time.

“CatChatter” is NOT intuitive (yet) , but predictive to interpret the sound.

HIGHLIGHTS

  • 10 recorded response messages
  • “CatChatter” responds to time/pitch (etc., hiss vs. meow vs. purr)
  • Messages are 2 seconds in duration
  • User can set to 2 basic functions: 1. Male/Female 2. Youthful/Mature

FEATURES

  • Personalize – 5 different device “skin” covers – White, Black, Brown, Blue and Pink
  • Settings – Male/Female, Youthful/Mature • Custom voices (w/App)
  • Tracker – “Where’s my cat?” iOS/Android (w/App) 
  • Make Intuitive – Program your actual cat sounds to actions and create your own “CatChatter” response. (w/App)

TECHNOLOGY

  • 20 Seconds Flash Memory,
  • 10 – 2 second flash memory WAV files
  • Integrated microphone to sense cat sounds (set to respond to frequency range of pet)
  • Replaceable 4.5VDC Battery
  • Prerecorded response messages
  • Clip-On to attach to any collar
  • Can be used on any type of cat
  • See how the "CatChatter" works.  Play videos below.
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eTo1CBimXuY
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5xcM5rdNNwY
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ntLnKEfQgRY

MARKET OPPORTUNITY

  • By the end of 2011 36.1 million households had at least one cat. Today that number is 42.9 million.
  • The average household has two cats.
  • 56.1 percent of cat owners consider their cats to be family members.
  • Source: http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/pet_overpopulation/facts/pet_ownership_statistics.html

TOP 10 CITIES FOR CAT OWNERSHIP

  •  1. Tampa, FL
  •  2. Phoenix, AZ
  •  3. San Francisco, CA
  •  4. Portland, OR
  •  5. Denver, CO
  •  6. Boston, MA
  •  7. Seattle, WA
  •  8. San Diego, CA
  •  9. Atlanta, GA
  • 10,Minneapolis, MN

TAM $ OPPORTUNITY

In 2014 $58.04 billion was spent on our cats in the U.S

  • Food $22.26 billion
  • Supplies/Products (“CatChatter”) $13.75 billion
  • Vet Care $15.04 billion Live animal purchases $ 2.15 billion
  • Pet Services: grooming & boarding $ 4.84 billion

Supplies based on APPA historical, BCC Research-The Pet Industry, Fountain Agricounsel 2013-2014 Situation Analysis, Pet Product News, Packaged Facts U.S. Pet Market Outlook 2014-2015, IBISWorld Industry Report Pet Stores in the US and Cleveland Research 2015 Forecast.

WHAT DO CAT SOUNDS MEAN

Cats can make more than 100 vocal sounds.

  • Chirps and trills are how a mother cat tells her kittens to follow her. Aimed at you, it probably means your cat wants you to follow him, usually to his food bowl. If you have more than one cat, you'll often hear them converse with each other this way. Purring is a sign of contentment (usually).
  • Cats purr whenever they're happy, even while they’re eating. Sometimes, however, a cat may purr when she's anxious or sick, using her purr to comfort herself, like a child sucking his thumb.
  • Growling, hissing or spitting indicate a cat who is annoyed, frightened, angry or aggressive. Leave this cat alone.
  • A yowl or howl (they sound like loud, drawn-out meows) tells you your cat is in some kind of distress—stuck in a closet, looking for you or in pain. Find your cat if he's making this noise. However, in unneutered and unspayed cats, these sounds are part of mating behavior (and very annoying). And if your cat is elderly, he may be suffering from a cognitive disorder (dementia) and may howl because he's disoriented.
  • Chattering, chittering or twittering are the noises your cat makes when she's sitting in the window watching birds or squirrels. Some experts think that this is an exaggeration of the "killing bite," when a cat grabs her prey by the neck and works her teeth through the bones to snap them.

PROJECT STATUS

a. Validation prototypes for response testing created August 2015 using voice record demo kits. Photo attached.
b. Testing and evaluation of pet response based on cat sounds measuring tone, pitch, duration and volume (db) September – November 2015.
c. Industrial Design initiated to house PCB, battery and collar/color clips started November 2015.
d. Initial quotes to manufacturing partners released December 2015.
e. Marketing and sales communications with target retailers/etailers with 1st generation prototypes/presentations initiated January 2016.

Risks & Challenges

We have built several prototypes and currently have functional units with some bugs. Our next step is to reduce the thickness dimension from 27mm to 13mm (currently our dimensions are 45mm x 27mm). The "CatChatter" has a microphone on the back of the unit to "listen" for the cat's meow/purr/etc.  When the sound is detected, we measure the pitch, the tone, duration and several other metrics and compare that against registered responses that suggest the pet’s intent.  Our challenge is to reduce the size of the unit without sacrificing power and audio quality.  

While we realize “CatChatter” could be thought of as a novelty product, we believe we can achieve a high level of accuracy in matching a cats sound to intent, then the “CatChatter” will play the appropriate phrased response.  We don't want to be considered a "toy", but we cannot claim to provide a device that actually makes your cat talk.  Our challenge is that we must prove a consistent response based on a repeated sound.   

We are on to an entirely new technology which has unlimited scale and depth not only in the U.S. but around the world.  We need this launch to be successful in order to continue our efforts to lead the market in wearable electronics for the pet industry.

Our challenge is that we must prove a consistent response based on a repeated sound.  We don't want to be considered a "toy", but cannot claim to provide a device that makes your cat talk.  We know we are on to new technology that has limitless scale and depth.  We need this launch to be successful to help us to continue our efforts to lead the market in wearable electronics in the pet market.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tweet, blog,email, text, call or whatever else you can think of to tell your friends about the "Cat Chatter".  Your help will insure our success.  Thank you so much.

story:
Here at Incarnation and Bushy Hill Nature Center, we are making great strides towards our Going Greener in 2015 campaign. Our latest effort is our switch to single- stream recycling across our entire 700+ acre campus. Additionally, we are hoping to build a 3-bin compost system which will not only reduce our waste and reuse it in a way that betters the environment, but will also function as a core component of our educational and camp programming going forward. To complete our efforts we are turning to our Incarnation and Bushy Hill Nature Center families for help! 

In order to properly institute single-stream recycling we need to purchase indoor and outdoor bins for our property. We will purchase 15 indoor bins with lids and 9 outdoor bins with lids to make it easier for our guests, campers and visitors to properly recycle! 

The indoor bins (23 gallons) with lids are $70.00 each and the outdoor bins (32 gallons) with lids are $52.00 each. Together, the bins cost $1,572. Here is what they look like:

                   Indoor Bins:                                          Outdoor Bins:

                                      

We will place the indoor recycling bins in the following buildings: the Welcome Center, the Lodge, Brooks Cottage, Bell Cottage, Katsanis, Lakeside, St. James, Arts and Crafts and T.I. (Tumble Inn). Our outdoor bins will be placed at Gibney Dining Hall, the Lodge kitchen, Katsanis field, AC field and the waterfront. Bushy Hill Nature Center will also be receiving a full compliment of bins, as part of a project launched by one of our summer staff members who is working toward her Gold Star Girl Scout award.

In order to build our 3-bin compost system, we need to raise money for the building materials (wood, wiring, cinder blocks). These large bins will accommodate food waste from our Gibney and Lodge kitchens as well as waste from property maintenance and our farm. Not only will composting reduce our waste at Incarnation and Bushy Hill Nature Center, but it will also allow us to add educational programming about compost and waste reduction to both our camp and school programs. We estimate that building our 3-bin compost system will cost us about $1,500. 

Switching to Single-Stream Recycling and composting our waste will help us become better caretakers of the earth, as well as promote life-long practices of environmental stewardship to campers and guests that consider Incarnation and Bushy Hill Nature Center a second home.

  


We ask you to support us in our efforts to be greener by contributing what you can. Every little bit helps! Any amount over our goal raised will be put aside for our next "going greener" project: a large educational organic garden. 

With Sincere Thanks,
story_txt: Here at Incarnation and Bushy Hill Nature Center, we are making great strides towards our Going Greener in 2015 campaign. Our latest effort is our switch to single- stream recycling across our entire 700+ acre campus. Additionally, we are hoping to build a 3-bin compost system which will not only reduce our waste and reuse it in a way that betters the environment, but will also function as a core component of our educational and camp programming going forward. To complete our efforts we are turning to our Incarnation and Bushy Hill Nature Center families for help! In order to properly institute single-stream recycling we need to purchase indoor and outdoor bins for our property. We will purchase 15 indoor bins with lids and 9 outdoor bins with lids to make it easier for our guests, campers and visitors to properly recycle! The indoor bins (23 gallons) with lids are $70.00 each and the outdoor bins (32 gallons) with lids are $52.00 each. story:
Circular Grocery Store

Overzicht (NL)

We verkopen sinds begin 2019 een verscheidenheid aan plantaardige, ethisch verantwoorde, biologische producten. Met jouw hulp zullen we onze producten in composteerbare verpakkingen leveren en veranderen we gebruikte verpakkingen en voedselafval in compost voor lokale boerderijen.

Wil je met iDeal doneren? Zie de instructies onderaan deze pagina​!

Summary

We are Winter and Maria, the founders of Amsterdam's first zero-waste grocery store. Since early 2019, we've sold a variety of plant-based organic products in our store but we now want to go further with our mission to develop a waste free delivery service. With your help, we will buy an industrial compost machine and implement a system for taking back and composting all food and packaging waste produced by our sales.

Would you like to donate with iDeal? See the instructions at the bottom of this page!

Business as a Platform for Change

Founded by Maria and Winter at the beginning of 2019, Little Plant Pantry is often referred to as the first “zero-waste” grocery store in Amsterdam. However we prefer the term “minimal-waste” since there is always some waste produced in the supply chain, even if it is a paper bag. Our goal is to develop a closed-loop circular system managing all waste produced directly and indirectly by our business activities, and repurposing it for future use. 

As a specialty grocery store with a focus on ethical consumerism, we purchase healthy natural products in bulk from organic wholesale suppliers and in small quantities from local food producers who can accommodate our packaging needs and meet our quality standards. We then offer these products for sale without packaging or with minimal packaging if required.

Eliminating plastic from our supply chain is something we work tirelessly towards. As of now, about 87% of our products are delivered to us plastic-free: in paper, cardboard or certified compostable packaging. The range of organic food ingredients grown and produced locally is relatively small. Many common food ingredients are imported, processed, repackaged and then branded for sale. Little Plant Pantry skips most of these steps by purchasing unprocessed ingredients in their original packaging (usually 25kg paper bags for dry goods) and sells them unpackaged, allowing customers to refill their own containers.

In line with our goals of supporting local communities, investing in sustainable agriculture and reducing our carbon-footprint, we aspire to cooperate with local organic food producers as much as possible. We believe that only by working together can we change existing production and distribution practices that are partially responsible for the current environmental crisis. 

Our store in Amsterdam Oud West has been very well received by the community. We are not a corporation but a small company that has been self-financed and maintained by two people and a number of dedicated volunteers. Yet, we are proving to be a viable and practical alternative to the supermarket chains. Our survival has been possible because there is a community of like-minded individuals who also recognize that production and consumption as we know it is no longer sustainable. We are now reaching out to the community with a proposal: to develop a model for an urban ecosystem with a community store at its heart that takes responsibility for both its products and its waste.

Circular Grocery Shopping Model

Already on the path to creating a sustainable alternative to standard grocery shopping, we want to go further with our mission to handle and re-purpose all food and packaging waste generated by our activity. We will do this by implementing a system for taking back all food and packaging waste produced by our sales and composting this waste on-site with the purpose of giving the compost to local farms that already supply us with healthy organic products. We call this system the Circular Grocery Shopping Model and Little Plant Pantry will be the first store to implement and test it. But for it to be successful, the active participation of all actors in the supply chain is needed, including the community we serve.

What Makes This Model Viable?

Sourcing locally is a priority because small scale producers can adapt their packaging practices more easily while we can build closer and stronger relationships with them and defend the accuracy of their sustainability claims. It also helps reduce the carbon footprint within our supply chain and supports local enterprises.  

When it is not possible to source locally, as is often the case, we use trusted organic wholesalers that understand and respect our values and supply us with quality organic goods in packaging that can in most cases be composted.

We always provide customers with the option of buying without packaging by refilling at the store. Along with the importance of developing community interaction and engagement, having the option of refilling is one of the main reasons why having a physical store is better than having just an online presence. 

However, in order to ensure the survival of our business in the long term, we have to provide our customers with the convenient option of home deliveries. Thus we must ensure that the packaging we use will not end up in landfill but will be further utilized within our eco-system.

Composting food and packaging waste on-site will allow us to provide compost free of charge to local community farms and food producers, who will then use it to enrich the soil from which they produce healthy organic products sold around Amsterdam.

Closing the Loop

Having an industrial composting unit will allow us to convert the waste of 100 households into 700 liters of stabilized, ready-to-use organic compost every week. The unit is made of stainless steel and recycled polythene and its dual chamber design ensures that the quality of the compost is consistent over time. The output of the machine can be used as fertilizer for food crops or for soil rehabilitation in areas where the ground is depleted of nutrients.

Having this machine closes the loop in our circular grocery shopping model and brings us closer to our ultimate goal of creating an urban zero-waste ecosystem. It also provides us with the opportunity to contribute to the city of Amsterdam by preventing not only our own waste from going into landfill or incineration but also the organic food waste of our customers and the community we serve.

We Need Your Support

Back this project and join our community! When composting is small-scale and locally based, community participation and education can flourish. Taking part in community projects can inspire others to follow a sustainable path and encourage our members to share their experience with the wider community.

Acknowledgements

This campaign has only been possible with the help of the following people who have all volunteered their time and energy to make this happen:

Zuza Kurzawa, Feef Anthony, Angela, Domonkos Molnar, Bernadett Suhaj, Valentina Manera, Justin Baker, Annekee Wagemaker, Jennifer Sun, Stefanie Behrendt, Danika Moore, Sylvia Huang & Honorine Schaeffer

We sincerely thank everybody for their efforts. A special thank you to Feef and Zuza who have carried this campaign through from the beginning to the end and have devoted an immense amount of work to it. It could not and would not have happened without you all!

……………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………

Residents in the Netherlands use 26 billion pieces of plastic food packaging per year - 1,500 pieces of plastic per person per year, or 4 pieces per day, according to a study by ING Economic Bureau. 

Plastic consumption continues to grow by around 100 million pieces of packaging every year, NOS reports. (nltimes.nl)

Donating with iDeal / Doneren met iDeal

You can donate to the campaign using tikkie! Scan the QR code or tap the link below to get started. Please mention your name, email address, and any perk(s) you'd like to receive to reward your contribution:

Je kunt met tikkie doneren aan de campagne! Scan de QR-code of tik op de onderstaande link om aan de slag te gaan​. Vermeld uw naam, e-mailadres en eventuele extraatjes die u wilt ontvangen om uw bijdrage te belonen:

https://tikkie.me/pay/q0cnpm26k6bg886mde67
